PREFACE 
This Code constitutes a complete republication of the general and permanent resolutions, general resolutions and ordinances of Hall County, Georgia. 
Source materials used in the preparation of the Code were the 1991 Official Code, as supplemented through June 30, 1995, and resolutions, general resolutions and ordinances subsequently adopted by the board of commissioners of Hall County, Georgia. The source of each section is included in the history note appearing in parentheses at the end thereof. The absence of such a note indicates that the section is new and was adopted for the first time with the adoption of the Code. By use of the comparative tables appearing in the back of this Code, the reader can locate any section of the 1991 Official Code, as supplemented, and any subsequent resolution, general resolution or ordinance included herein. 
The titles of the Code have been conveniently arranged and the various sections within each chapter have been catchlined to facilitate usage. Notes which tie related sections of the Code together have been included. A table listing the amendments and setting forth their location within the Code is included at the back of this Code. 
Obvious misspellings, punctuation errors and errors in grammar have been corrected without notation. Additions made for clarity are indicated by brackets. 
Title, Chapter and Section Numbering System 
The title, chapter and section numbering system used in this Code is the same system used in many state and local government codes. Each section number consists of three parts separated by periods. The first number is the title number, the second number is the chapter number, and the third number is the section number. To allow room for expansion, chapters and sections have been numbered in increments of ten. Therefore, if new material consisting of one section is enacted which would logically come between sections 10.30.120 and 10.30.130 it could be numbered as section 10.30.125. New chapters may be included in the same manner, or at the ends of titles. 
Page Numbering System 
The page numbering system used in this Code is a prefix system. The letters to the left of the colon are an abbreviation which represents a certain portion of the volume. The number to the right of the colon represents the number of the page in that portion. In the case of a title of the Code, the number to the left of the colon indicates the number of the title. In the case of an appendix to the Code, the letter immediately to the left of the colon indicates the letter of the appendix. The following are typical parts of codes of ordinances, and their corresponding prefixes, which may or may not appear in this Code at this time: 

 
Indexes 
The indexes have been prepared with the greatest of care. Each particular item has been placed under several headings, some of which are couched in lay phraseology, others in legal terminology, and still others in language generally used by local government officials and employees. There are numerous cross references within the indexes themselves which stand as guideposts to direct the user to the particular item in which the user is interested. 
Looseleaf Supplements 
A special feature of this publication is the looseleaf system of binding and supplemental servicing of the publication. With this system, the publication will be kept up-to-date. Subsequent amendatory legislation will be properly edited, and the affected page or pages will be reprinted. These new pages will be distributed to holders of copies of the publication, with instructions for the manner of inserting the new pages and deleting the obsolete pages. 
Keeping this publication up-to-date at all times will depend largely upon the holder of the publication. As revised pages are received, it will then become the responsibility of the holder to have the amendments inserted according to the attached instructions. It is strongly recommended by the publisher that all such amendments be inserted immediately upon receipt to avoid misplacing them and, in addition, that all deleted pages be saved and filed for historical reference purposes. 
Acknowledgments 
This republication was under the direct supervision of Mary Grace Tavel, Supervising Editor, and Connie Timmons, Editor, of the Municipal Code Corporation, Tallahassee, Florida. Credit is gratefully given to the other members of the publisher's staff for their sincere interest and able assistance throughout the project. 
The publisher is most grateful to Mark Lane, Commission Clerk and Communications Director, and William H. Blalock, Jr., County Attorney, for their cooperation and assistance during the progress of the work on this publication. It is hoped that their efforts and those of the publisher have resulted in a Code of Ordinances which will make the active law of Hall County readily accessible to all citizens and which will be a valuable tool in the day-to-day administration of the county's affairs. 
Copyright 
All editorial enhancements of this Code are copyrighted by Municipal Code Corporation and Hall County, Georgia. Editorial enhancements include, but are not limited to: organization; table of contents; section catchlines; prechapter section analyses; editor's notes; cross references; numbering system; code comparative table; and index. Such material may not be used or reproduced for commercial purposes without the express written consent of Municipal Code Corporation and the County of Hall, Georgia.

ADOPTING RESOLUTION 
A Resolution Adopting and Enacting a New Code for Hall County, Georgia; To Provide for the Repeal of Certain Resolutions Not Included Therein; To Provide a Penalty for the Violation Thereof; To Provide for the Manner of Amending Such Code; To Provide for an Effective Date for the Code and This Resolution; To Repeal Conflicting Ordinances and Resolutions, and for Other Purposes. 
Whereas, the Board of Commissioners of Hall County adopted by resolution on May 28, 1991, the codification of Resolutions, General Resolutions and Ordinances passed by the Board of Commissioners of Hall County as "The Official Code of Hall County, Georgia;" and further provided for the adoption and incorporation of any Resolution, General Resolution or Ordinance passed subsequent to May 28, 1991, to automatically become a part of The Official Code of Hall County, Georgia; and 
Whereas, the Board of Commissioners of Hall County desires to adopt a new Code entitled "The Official Code of Hall County, Georgia" published by Municipal Code Corporation consisting of titles 1 through 17, inclusive; and 
Whereas, the Board of Commissioners of Hall County desires to adopt a uniform penalty provision for every person convicted of a violation of any provision of the Code or any resolution, ordinance, rule or regulation adopted unless another penalty is expressly provided; and 
Now, Therefore, Be It Resolved by the Board of Commissioners of Hall County, Georgia, and it is hereby resolved by the authority of the same as follows: 
Section 1. The Code entitled "The Official Code of Hall County, Georgia," published by Municipal Code Corporation, consisting of titles 1 through 17, each inclusive, is adopted. 
Section 2. All resolutions and ordinances of a general and permanent nature enacted on or before December 14, 1995, and not included in the Code or recognized and continued in force by reference therein, are repealed. 
Section 3. The repeal provided for in Section 2 hereof shall not be construed to revive any resolution or ordinance or part thereof that has been repealed by a subsequent resolution or ordinance that is repealed by this resolution. 
Section 4. Unless another penalty is expressly provided, every person convicted of a violation of any provision of the Code or any resolution, ordinance, rule or regulation adopted or issued in pursuance thereof shall be punished by a fine not exceeding one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) or imprisonment for a term not exceeding 60 days, or both. Each act of violation and each day upon which any such violation shall occur shall constitute a separate offense. The penalty provided by this section, unless another penalty is expressly provided, shall apply to the amendment of any Code section, whether or not such penalty is reenacted in the amendatory resolution or ordinance. In addition to the penalty prescribed above, the Board of Commissioners of Hall County may pursue other remedies such as abatement of nuisances, injunctive relief and revocation of licenses or permits. 
Section 5. Additions or amendments to the Code, when passed in the form as to indicate the intention of the Board of Commissioners of Hall County to make the same a part of the Code, shall be deemed to be incorporated in the Code, so that reference to the Code includes the additions and amendments. 
Section 6. Resolutions or ordinances adopted after December 14, 1995, that amend or refer to resolutions or ordinances that have been codified in the Code shall be construed as if they amend or refer to like provisions of the Code. 
Section 7. A copy of The Official Code of Hall County, Georgia, shall be kept on file in the Office of the Clerk to the Hall County Board of Commissioners, preserved in looseleaf form, or in such other form as the Clerk may consider most expedient. It shall be the express duty of the Clerk or someone authorized by the Clerk to insert in their designated places all Resolutions, General Resolutions and Ordinances which indicate the intention of the Hall County Board of Commissioners to make the same a part of The Official Code of Hall County, Georgia, when the same have been printed or reprinted in page form, and to extract from The Official Code of Hall County, Georgia, all provisions which may be from time to time repealed by the Hall County Board of Commissioners. This copy of The Official Code of Hall County, Georgia, shall be available for all persons desiring to examine the same and shall be considered The Official Code of Hall County, Georgia. 
Section 8. It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, or corporation to change or amend, by additions or deletions, any part or a portion of The Official Code of Hall County, Georgia, or to insert or delete pages or portions thereof, or to alter or tamper with The Official Code of Hall County, Georgia, in any manner whatsoever which will cause the law of Hall County, Georgia, to be misrepresented thereby. 
Section 9. All Resolutions, or Ordinances, or parts thereof, in conflict with the terms of this Resolution are hereby repealed, but it is hereby provided that any resolution, ordinance or law, which may be applicable hereto and aid in carrying out and making effective the intent, purpose and provisions hereof, which shall be liberally construed to be in favor of Hall County, is hereby adopted as part hereof. 
Section 10. If any paragraph, sub-paragraph, sentence, clause, phrase, or any portion of this Resolution shall be declared invalid or unconstitutional by any court of competent jurisdiction or if the provisions of any part of this Resolution as applied to any particular situation or set of circumstances shall be declared invalid or unconstitutional, such invalidity shall not be construed to affect the portions of this Resolution not so held to be invalid. It is hereby declared to be the intent of the Board of Commissioners of Hall County, Georgia, to provide for separable and divisible parts, and it does hereby adopt any and all parts hereof as may not be held invalid for any reason. 
Section 11. This Resolution adopting "The Official Code of Hall County, Georgia," published by Municipal Code Corporation shall become effective on the 1st day of July, 1996, at 12:00 A.M. 
This 27th day of June, 1996. 
HALL COUNTY BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS

SUPPLEMENT HISTORY TABLE 
The table below allows users of this Code to quickly and accurately determine what ordinances have been considered for codification in each supplement. Ordinances that are of a general and permanent nature are codified in the Code Book and are considered "Included." Ordinances that are not of a general and permanent nature are not codified in the Code Book and are considered "Omitted." 
In addition, by adding to this table with each supplement, users of this Code of Ordinances will be able to gain a more complete picture of the Code's historical evolution. 

 
PART I - OFFICIAL CODE 
Title 1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

 
CHAPTER 1.10. - CODE ADOPTION 

 

1.10.010. - Adoption of Code; name. 
The codification of resolutions, general resolutions and ordinances passed by the Hall County Commission is adopted as "The Official Code of Hall County, Georgia." 
(Res. of 5-28-91, § 1; Code 1991, § 1.04.010) 
1.10.020. - Incorporation of resolutions, general resolutions and ordinances. 
Any resolution, general resolution or ordinance not presently included in the Official Code of Hall County, Georgia, and passed subsequent to the preparation of said codification is automatically included and incorporated herein by reference. Any resolution, general resolution or ordinance passed subsequent to May 28, 1991, shall automatically become a part of the Official Code of Hall County, Georgia. 
(Res. of 5-28-91, § 2; Code 1991, § 1.04.020) 
1.10.030. - Form of Code; designated place for Code to be kept on file; method of up-dating. 
A copy of the Official Code of Hall County, Georgia, shall be kept on file in the office of the clerk to the Hall County Board of Commissioners, preserved in looseleaf form, or in such other form as the clerk may consider most expedient. It shall be the express duty of the clerk or someone authorized by the clerk to insert in their designated places all resolutions, general resolutions and ordinances which indicate the intention of the Hall County Board of Commissioners to make the same a part of the Official Code of Hall County, Georgia, when the same have been printed or reprinted in page form, and to extract from the Official Code of Hall County, Georgia, all provisions which may be from time to time repealed by the Hall County Board of Commissioners. This copy of the Official Code of Hall County, Georgia, shall be available for all persons desiring to examine the same and shall be considered the Official Code of Hall County, Georgia. 
(Res. of 5-28-91, § 3; Code 1991, § 1.04.030) 
1.10.040. - Alteration of Code. 
It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, or corporation to change or amend, by additions or deletions, any part or a portion of the Official Code of Hall County, Georgia, or to insert or delete pages or portions thereof, or to alter or tamper with the Official Code of Hall County, Georgia, in any manner whatsoever which will cause the law of Hall County, Georgia, to be misrepresented thereby. Any person, firm, corporation, association or partnership violating any provision of this chapter as the same exists or as it may hereinafter be amended, or shall fail to do anything required by this chapter as the same exists or as it may hereafter be amended, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, amenable to the process of the Magistrate or State Court of Hall County, and upon conviction, shall be punished as provided in the Official Code of Hall County, Georgia section 1.50.020 for each violation in the discretion of the court. 
(Res. of 5-28-91, § 4; Code 1991, § 1.04.040; Res. of 6-10-04(1), § 1) 
CHAPTER 1.20. - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

 

1.20.010. - Definitions. 
For the purposes of this Code: 
Administrator means the person employed by the commission to fulfill the duties of county administrator as then defined. 
Commission means the Hall County, Georgia, Board of Commissioners. "All its members" or "all commissioners" means the total number of commissioners holding office. 
Commissioner or commissioners means one or more members of the commission. 
County means Hall County, Georgia. 
Hall County Zoning Board of Adjustment shall mean the Hall County Planning Commission. 
Law denotes applicable federal law, the constitution and statutes of the State of Georgia, the resolutions of the county, and, when appropriate, any and all rules and regulations which may be promulgated thereunder. 
May is permissive. 
Month means a calendar month. 
Must and shall are each mandatory. 
Oath includes an affirmation or declaration in all cases in which, by law, an affirmation may be substituted for an oath, and in such cases the words "swear" and "sworn" shall be equivalent to the words "affirm" and "affirmed." 
Owner, applied to a building or land, includes any part owner, joint owner, tenant in common, joint tenant, or tenant by the entirety, of the whole or a part of such building or land. 
Person includes a natural person, joint venture, joint stock company, partnership, association, club, company, corporation, business, trust, organization, or the manager, lessee, agent, servant, officer or employee of any of them. 
Personal property includes money, goods, chattels, things in action and evidences of debt. 
Preceding and following mean next before and next after, respectively. 
Property includes real and personal property. 
Real property includes lands, tenements and hereditaments. 
Road or street includes all roads, streets, highways, avenues, lanes, alleys, courts, places, squares, curbs, or other public ways in this county which have been or may hereafter be dedicated and open to public use, or such other public property so designated in any law of this state. 
Sidewalk means that portion of a street between the curbline and the adjacent property line intended for the use of pedestrians. 
State means the State of Georgia. 
Tenant and occupant, applied to a building or land, include any person who occupies the whole or a part of such building or land, whether alone or with others. 
Written includes printed, typewritten, mimeographed, multigraphed, or otherwise reproduced in permanent visible form. 
Year means a calendar year. 
(Res. of 10-9-89, § 1; Code 1991, § 1.08.010; Res. of 3-27-03, § 5) 
Editor's note— Section 5 of Resolution of March 27, 2003, states, "As of the effective date of this resolution and forward, all references to the Hall County Zoning Board of Adjustment contained in the Official Code of Hall County, Georgia, shall be understood to refer to the Hall County Planning Commission." Therefore, at the discretion of the editor, a definition as been added to § 1.20.010 restating the provisions and intent of said § 5. 
1.20.020. - References to titles of officers, employees or public bodies. 
Use of the title of any officer, employee, department, board or commission means that officer, employee, department, board or commission of the county. 
(Res. of 10-9-89, § 2; Code 1991, § 1.08.020) 
1.20.030. - Interpretation of language. 
All words and phrases shall be construed according to the common and approved usage of the language, but technical words and phrases and such others as may have acquired a peculiar and appropriate meaning in the law shall be construed and understood according to such peculiar and appropriate meaning. 
(Res. of 10-9-89, § 2; Code 1991, § 1.08.030) 
1.20.040. - Grammatical interpretation. 
The following grammatical rules shall apply in the resolutions of the county unless it is apparent from the context that a different construction is intended: 
A.  Gender. Each gender includes the masculine, feminine and neuter genders. 
B.  Singular and plural. The singular number includes the plural and the plural includes the singular. 
C.  Tenses. Words used in the present tense include the past and the future tenses and vice versa, unless manifestly inapplicable. 
(Res. of 10-9-89, § 2; Code 1991, § 1.08.040) 
1.20.050. - Acts by agent. 
When an act is required by resolution, the same being such that it may be done as well by an agent as by the principal, such requirement shall be construed to include all such acts performed by a designated agent. 
(Res. of 10-9-89, § 2; Code 1991, § 1.08.050) 
1.20.060. - Causing, permitting, abetting or concealing prohibited act. 
Whenever in the resolutions of the county any act or omission is made unlawful, it shall include causing, allowing, permitting, aiding, abetting, suffering, or concealing the fact of such act or omission. 
(Res. of 10-9-89, § 2; Code 1991, § 1.08.060) 
1.20.070. - Computation of time. 
Except when otherwise provided, the time within which an act is required to be done shall be computed by excluding the first day and including the last day, unless the last day is Sunday or a holiday, in which case it shall also be excluded. 
(Res. of 10-9-89, § 2; Code 1991, § 1.08.070) 
1.20.080. - Construction of provisions. 
The provisions of the resolutions of the county and all proceedings under them are to be construed with a view to effect their objects and to promote justice. 
(Res. of 10-9-89, § 2; Code 1991, § 1.08.080) 
1.20.090. - Repeal shall not revive any ordinances. 
The repeal of an ordinance shall not repeal the repealing clause of an ordinance or revive any ordinance which has been repealed thereby. 
(Res. of 10-9-89, § 2; Code 1991, § 1.08.090) 
CHAPTER 1.30. - OFFICIAL MAP[1] 

 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Administration generally, tit. 2. 

1.30.010. - Adopted; copies. 
A.  The map attached to the resolution codified in this chapter is adopted as the official map of Hall County, Georgia. 
B.  Copies of the map shall be made and furnished to all departments of the county having need of them. 
C.  Copies of the map shall be printed and sold to the general public of the county, the charges therefor being sufficient to cover the expense of printing the maps and the cost of distribution. 
D.  A copy of the resolution codified in this chapter, together with a copy of the official map, shall be certified to the clerk of the superior court of the county. 
(Res. of 3-26-73; Code 1991, § 1.12.010) 
CHAPTER 1.40. - GENERAL PENALTY[2] 

 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Penalties imposed by magistrate court, ch. 1.50. 

1.40.010. - Violations; penalty. 
Each and every county resolution which has been or will be duly passed and enacted by the board of commissioners of the county to protect and preserve the public health, safety and welfare, to provide traffic regulations, to regulate and control litter, or to provide for the implementation and enforcement of any power or duty vested in the county governing authority, shall, in the discretion of the court or courts having jurisdiction over such violations of county resolutions, have a penalty or punishment up to the maximum penalty or punishment provided by the Official Code of Hall County, Georgia section 1.50.020. 
(Res. of 8-12-85, § 1; Code 1991, § 1.16.010; Res. of 6-10-04(1), § 1) 
CHAPTER 1.50. - PENALTIES IMPOSED BY MAGISTRATE COURT[3] 

 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference— General penalty, ch. 1.40. 

1.50.010. - Authority granted to magistrate court. 
A.  O.C.G.A. § 36-1-20 gives the governing authority of each county, for the purpose of protecting and preserving the public health, safety and welfare, authorization to adopt ordinances for the governing and policing of the unincorporated areas of the county, violations of which ordinances may be punished by fine or imprisonment or both. 
B.  O.C.G.A. §§ 15-10-60 and 36-1-20 provide for the punishment that may be imposed by a court exercising jurisdiction over a county ordinance violation. 
C.  O.C.G.A. § 36-1-20 gives jurisdiction over violations of such county ordinances to the Magistrate Court of the County. However, pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 36-1-20(c), jurisdiction over ordinances having to do with traffic offenses shall be in the court or courts having jurisdiction over state traffic offenses. 
(Res. of 4-13-92; Code 1991, § 1.18.010; Res. of 6-10-04(1), § 1) 
1.50.020. - Maximum punishment for violation of resolutions or ordinances. 
(a)  Maximum sentence. By virtue of the authority of O.C.G.A. §§ 15-10-60 and 36-1-20, the maximum punishment for the violation of any ordinance or resolution previously passed by the Board of Commissioners of Hall County shall be as follows: It shall be unlawful for any person to violate or fail to comply with any resolution or ordinance applicable to the unincorporated area of Hall County, Georgia; and where no specific penalty is provided therefore or where there is a penalty that is less than a fine not exceeding $1,000.00 or imprisonment for a term not exceeding 60 days or both, the violation of any such provision shall be punished by a fine not exceeding $1,000.00 or imprisonment for a term not exceeding six months' imprisonment or both, provided the judge shall probate not less than 120 days of any sentence imposed, except as otherwise provided by general law. In the event a sentence is revoked, a defendant shall not serve more than 60 days in a county jail. 
(b)  Suspended sentences. The trial court may suspend the service of the sentence imposed in the case upon such terms and conditions as it may prescribe for the payment of the fine, for performance of community service in lieu of a fine or incarceration, for the payment of restitution to a victim, or other condition relating to the underlying offense. Service of the sentence, when so suspended, shall not begin unless and until ordered by the court having jurisdiction thereof, after a hearing as in cases of revocation of probated sentences, because of the failure or refusal of the defendant to comply with the terms and conditions upon which service of a sentence was suspended. 
(c)  Duration of conditions. Service of all or any part of any sentence suspended upon such conditions may be ordered to commence by the trial court any time before the expiration of one year from the date of the sentence after a hearing and a finding by the court that the defendant has failed or refused to comply with the terms and conditions upon which service of the sentence was suspended. 
(d)  Violations per day. Each day any violation of any provision of this Code shall continue shall constitute a separate offense. 
(e)  Misdemeanor punishment. Where in this Code any violation shall be deemed punishable as a "misdemeanor," "misdemeanor" shall be defined as an offense, the violation of which shall be punishable as specified for ordinance violations in this section. 
(Res. of 4-13-92, § 1; Code 1991, § 1.18.020; Res. of 6-10-04(1), § 1) 
1.50.030. - Incorporation of O.C.G.A. § 36-1-20 into the Official Code of Hall County, Georgia. 
Official Code of Georgia Annotated O.C.G.A. §§ 15-10-60 and 36-1-20 shall be incorporated as a part of the Official Code of Hall County, Georgia. 
(Res. of 4-13-92, § 2; Code 1991, § 1.18.030; Res. of 6-10-04(1), § 1)

CHAPTER 2.10. - BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS 

 

2.10.010. - Commission meetings; Robert's Rules of Order adopted. 
Robert's Rules of Order are implemented as the official rules governing all meetings of the board of commissioners of the county. 
(Res. of 10-9-89, § 1; Code 1991, § 2.04.010) 
2.10.020. - Commission meetings; participation of chairman of county commissioners. 
Notwithstanding any provision to the contrary contained in Robert's Rules of Order, the chairman of the county board of commissioners may participate in all deliberations, make, second, and vote on all motions to come before the commission, and the chairman shall have the same and equal rights of any other member of the county board of commissioners to fully participate in the legislative progress of county government. 
(Res. of 10-9-89, § 2; Code 1991, § 2.04.020) 
2.10.030. - Operative uniform policy for boards and commissions. 
A.  As per O.C.G.A. Title 50, Chapter 14 Section 1(d)(1)(1) every board or committee created by the Hall County Board of Commissioners shall prescribe the time, place, and dates of regular meetings of the board or committee and this information shall be available to the general public and a notice containing such information shall be posted at least one week in advance and maintained in a conspicuous place available to the public at the regular meeting place of the board or committee meeting. 
B.  As per O.C.G.A. Title 50, Chapter 14 Section 1(d)(1)(2) every board or committee created by the Hall County Board of Commissioners that meet outside of the regularly scheduled meeting dates will notify the legal organ, currently the Gainesville Times, of any scheduled meeting at least 24 hours prior to said meeting. 
C.  As per O.C.G.A. Title 50 Chapter 14 Section 1(e)(1) every board or committee created by the board of commissioners will have available an agenda of all matters expected to come before the board or committee at such meeting. Said agenda shall be posted at the meeting site within the two week period prior to the meeting but no later than 24 hours prior to the meeting. 
D.  As per O.C.G.A. Title 50 Chapter 14 Section 1(e)(2)(A) a summary of the subjects acted on and those members present at a meeting of any board or commission shall be written and made available to the public for inspection within two business days of the adjournment of the meeting. 
E.  As per O.C.G.A. Title 50 Chapter 14 Section 1(e)(2)(B) every board or committee created by the board of commissioners will promptly record minutes of said meetings and have those available for inspection by the public once approved but no later than immediately following the next regular meeting. Said minutes shall, at a minimum, include the names of the members present at the meeting, a description of each motion or other proposal made, the identity of the persons making and seconding the motion or other proposal and a record of all votes. 
F.  Every board or committee will be required to forward an original signed copy of the approved minutes to the Hall County Commission Clerk for permanent retention. 
(Res. of 5-10-12, § 1) 
Editor's note— Res. of 5-10-12, § 1, did not specifically amend the Code; therefore these provisions have been added as § 2.10.030, at the editor's discretion. 
CHAPTER 2.20. - COUNTY ADMINISTRATOR 

 

2.20.010. - Position created; purpose. 
There is created the position of county administrator to provide administrative assistance to the board in the performance of its duties and responsibilities. 
(Res. of 5-12-69; Code 1991, § 2.08.010) 
2.20.020. - Powers and duties. 
The county administrator as the chief executive officer of the government of the county shall be responsible to the board of commissioners for the proper and efficient administration of the affairs of the county, and shall have the following powers and duties: 
A.  To direct and supervise the administration of all county offices and departments for which the board is responsible, or may hereafter be responsible, including specifically the construction, maintenance and operation of all county roads, bridges, drains, buildings and other public works, and the care and maintenance of all real and personal property owned by the county; 
B.  To appoint and, when in his discretion the welfare of the county requires it, suspend, discharge, transfer or remove all employees for whom the board is responsible, excepting the warden and the county attorney, who are appointed directly by the board, but he may delegate to any department head such powers with respect to subordinates within the officer's department or office; 
C.  To see that all ordinances, resolutions and orders of the board and all laws of the state subject to enforcement by him or by officers or department heads subject, under this resolution [chapter], to his direction and supervision are faithfully executed; 
D.  To prepare and submit the annual budget and capital program to the board and to execute the budget and capital program adopted by the board, approving all disbursements and expenditures as budgeted and/or authorized by the board; 
E.  To confer with and assist the heads of all departments, such as the county health department, library and the county welfare department, whose missions are not under the direct control and supervision of the board, but who are dependent upon appropriations of the board for their continued operation; 
F.  To confer with and advise all elected or appointed officials of the county who are not under the immediate control of the board, but who receive financial support from the board, such as the sheriff, clerk of court, ordinary, tax commissioner, hospital authority, county agricultural and home demonstration agents and the like; 
G.  To examine regularly at periods fixed by the board the accounts, records and operations of every county board, commission, department, office and agency which receives appropriations from the board; to make regular monthly reports to the board on county fiscal and other affairs; to keep the board fully advised on the financial condition of the future needs of the county; and to make such recommendations on county affairs as he deems necessary for the efficient operation of the county; 
H.  To supervise the keeping of all records, books of account, bookkeeping, etc., of the county; 
I.  To supervise and approve the issuance of all purchase orders of the county; 
J.  To submit to the board at the end of each fiscal year a complete report on the finances and administrative activities of the county for the preceding year; 
K.  To carry into execution such other powers and duties as may be prescribed from time to time by the board; 
L.  All reports by the administrator shall be made to the full board in either a regular or called meeting of the board. 
(Res. of 5-12-69; Code 1991, § 2.08.020) 
CHAPTER 2.30. - HALL COUNTY MARSHALS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. of 1-14-10, § 1(Exh. A), amended Ch. 2.30 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Ch. 2.30, §§ 2.30.10—2.30.30, pertained to enforcement division of Hall County. See the Code Comparative Table for complete derivation. 

2.30.010. - Name created. 
The position of marshal, a/k/a the Hall County Marshals was originally created by the Hall County Board of Commissioners on January 26, 1981. The name was changed to the Enforcement Division of Hall County Public Safety Department on October 28, 1991 and to the Enforcement Division of Hall County on December 14, 1995. The Enforcement Division of Hall County shall now hereafter be known as the Hall County Marshals, and any reference to the enforcement division within this Code shall be deemed to refer to the Hall County Marshals. 
(Ord. of 1-14-10, § 1(Exh. A)) 
2.30.020. - Powers and duties. 
The Hall County Marshals shall have the powers and duties as well as other statutory authority as set out in O.C.G.A. §§ 36-8-1 through 36-8-7 as well as any other powers and duties that may have been heretofore or hereafter will be conferred upon positions of this nature. 
(Ord. of 1-14-10, § 1(Exh. A)) 
2.30.030. - Chain of command. 
The chain of command for the Hall County Marshals enforcing the regulations of the Official Code of Hall County, Georgia, shall be as follows: 
A.  The Hall County Board of Commissioners. 
B.  The Hall County Administrator. 
(Ord. of 1-14-10, § 1(Exh. A)) 
CHAPTER 2.40. - BOARD OF TAX ASSESSORS 

2.40.010. - Creation of board of tax assessors. 
The Hall County Board of Tax Assessors shall consist of five members, who shall be residents of the county, shall be appointed by the Board of Commissioners of Hall County, upon the recommendation of the Commissioner whose District is served by the Tax Assessor, and shall comply with the additional provisions of O.C.G.A. § 48-5-290 et seq. 
(Res. of 11-14-2013, § 2(Exh. A)) 
2.40.020. - Qualifications, appraisal courses, rules and regulations. 
A.  The requirements for qualifications for Tax Assessors are set forth in O.C.G.A. § 48-5-291(a); and each Tax Assessor appointed by the Board of Commissioners of Hall County shall comply with the same. 
B.  Each Tax Assessor shall complete 40 hours of training either prior to or within 180 days of appointment. Additionally, each Tax Assessor must successfully complete an additional 40 hours of approved appraisal courses during each two calendar years of tenure as a member of the county board of tax assessors as provided for in O.C.G.A. § 48-5-291(b). 
C.  The Tax Commissioner shall promulgate such rules and regulations as may be necessary for the administration of this Chapter and O.C.G.A. § 48-5-291. 
D.  No Tax Assessor shall be eligible to hold any state, county, or municipal office during the time he holds such office pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-5-292. 
(Res. of 11-14-2013, § 2(Exh. A)) 
2.40.030. - Terms of appointment. 
A.  The provision in O.C.G.A. § 48-5-292, gives the Board of Commissioners of Hall County the authority to select the length of terms of office for members of the Board of Tax Assessors by resolution. In the resolution, all new appointments and reappointments shall be for the term lengths specified in the resolution; however, such resolution shall not have the effect of shortening or extending the terms of office of the current members of the Board of Assessors whose terms have not yet expired. 
B.  As of January 1, 2013, the following chart specifies the terms of office of the appointed Tax Assessor to overlap with the terms of office of the recommending Hall County Commissioner according to his or her District after said Commissioner has been in office for one year or more: 

 
C.  The recommendation for appointment of a Tax Assessor to the Board of Tax Assessors as made by a District Commissioner shall be considered by the Board of Commissioners of Hall County as advisory, but still shall not be binding upon the Board of Commissioners of Hall County if a majority of the Board of Commissioners of Hall County does not agree with such recommendation. 
D.  Any member of the Board of Tax Assessors shall be eligible for reappointment after review of his or her service on the Board of Tax Assessors by the Board of Commissioners of Hall County. 
E.  In the case of a vacancy on the Hall County Board of Tax Assessors at any time, whether caused by death, resignation, removal, or otherwise, the vacancy shall be immediately filled upon recommendation by the County Commissioner from the district the vacancy has occurred and upon approval of the Hall County Board of Commissioners. 
F.  Any person appointed to fill a vacancy shall be appointed only to serve for the remainder of the unexpired term of the assessor he or she replaces and shall possess the same qualifications required under this Chapter for regular appointment to a full term of office. 
G.  Any member of the Board of Tax Assessors may be removed by the Board of Commissioners of Hall County only for cause shown for the failure to perform the duties or requirements or meet the qualifications imposed upon such member by law, including, but not limited to, the duties, requirements and qualifications specified pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-5-295.1 and subsection (e) of O.C.G.A. § 48-5-262. 
H.  All other provisions of O.C.G.A. § 48-5-295 pertaining to terms of office, vacancies and removal from office are incorporated herein by reference and made a part of this Section. 
(Res. of 11-14-2013, § 2(Exh. A)) 
2.40.040. - Adoption of O.C.G.A. § 48-5-290 through O.C.G.A. § 48-5-314. 
All Sections of O.C.G.A. § 48-5-290 through O.C.G.A. § 48-5-314 pertaining to the Board of Tax Assessors are incorporated herein by reference and made a part of Chapter 2.40 of the Official Code of Hall County, Georgia, as if specifically set forth herein. 
(Res. of 11-14-2013, § 2(Exh. A)) 
CHAPTER 2.50. - RECREATION AND PARKS[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference— Streets, sidewalks and public places, tit. 12. 

ARTICLE I. - ADMINISTRATION AND GENERAL PROVISIONS 

2.50.010. - Definitions and interpretation of provisions. 
A.  Interpretation of provisions. 
1.  Words used in the singular include the plural and words used in the plural include the singular. 
2.  Words used in the present tense include the future tense. 
3.  The word "building" includes the word "structure." 
B.  Definitions. For the purpose of this chapter certain words or terms used in this chapter shall be defined as follows: 
1.  Alcoholic beverages means intoxicating beverages, malt beverages, wine or any other beverage containing any alcohol whatsoever. 
2.  Building means any structure attached to the ground which has a roof and which is designed for the shelter, housing or enclosure of persons, animals, or property of any kind. 
3.  Litter means garbage, refuse, paper, rubbish, debris, trash and all other waste material, whether natural or artificial. 
4.  Person. The word "person" includes the words "individuals," "firms," "partnerships," "corporations," "associations," and "governmental bodies" and all other legal entities. 
5.  Recreation facilities means all recreation areas and parks, including land, buildings, lakes, swimming pools, and all other property and buildings owned, leased or managed by the county or the county recreation authority or their designated agents or department. 
6.  Vehicle means any motor driven equipment, automobile, truck, motorcycle, bicycle or sled. 
7.  Weapon means a pistol, firearm, rifle, hatchet, ax, shotgun, air gun, slingshot or other similar device. 
8.  Consumer fireworks means any small fireworks devices containing restricted amounts of pyrotechnic composition, designed primarily to produce visible or audible effects by combustion, that comply with the construction, chemical composition, and labeling regulations of the United States Consumer Product Safety Commission as provided for in Parts 16 CFR 1500 and 1507, the United States Department of Transportation as provided for in 49 CFR 172, and the American Pyrotechnics Association as provided for in the 2001 American Pyrotechnics Association Standard 87-1, and additionally shall mean Roman candles. 
9.  Fireworks means any combustible or explosive composition or any substance or combination of substances or article prepared for the purpose of producing a visible or audible effect by combustion, explosion, deflagration, or detonation, including blank cartridges, firecrackers, torpedoes, skyrockets, bombs, sparklers and other combustibles and explosives of like construction, as well as articles containing any explosive or flammable compound and tables and other devices containing an explosive substance. 
(Res. of 3-12-84, § 1; Code 1991, § 2.20.010; Res. of 9-10-15(1), §§ 1, 2) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1.20.010 et seq. 
2.50.020. - Recreation and parks department created; purpose. 
The Hall County Recreation and Parks Department is created to function as a line department directly responsible to the board of commissioners of the county. The primary purpose of the county recreation and parks department is to provide, maintain and conduct parks, playgrounds, recreation centers, and to carry out all other recreational activities and services within the geographical boundaries of the county. 
(Res. of 12-8-80, § 2; Code 1991, § 2.20.020) 
2.50.030. - Authority of board of commissioners; purchasing and contracts. 
The board of commissioners of the county reserves sole and exclusive authority to buy, sell, lease and convey real estate, and to enter into all contracts for all recreational and park purposes. All goods and services shall be purchased in accordance with the county's purchasing manual, and the county purchasing department shall be utilized on all such acquisitions. 
(Res. of 12-8-80, § 3; Code 1991, § 2.20.030) 
Cross reference— Revenue and finance, tit. 3. 
2.50.040. - Recreation and parks director. 
The top administrative officer of the county recreation and parks department shall be the recreation and parks director. The director shall exercise overall responsibility and management of the department, and shall be directly responsible to the county administrator. The recreation and parks director shall be appointed by the county administrator. 
(Res. of 12-8-80, § 4; Code 1991, § 2.20.040) 
2.50.050. - Composition of parks and leisure services board. 
A.  The parks and leisure services board is composed of eight persons serving without pay, each member being appointed by the Hall County Board of Commissioners. 
B.  The five voting members are to be appointed individually by the chairman and each of the four district commissioners. 
C.  The three ex-officio members are nominated by the group they individually represent and the nominees are then confirmed by the commissioners. The ex-officio members consist of a sitting commissioner, an active Hall County School Board member and a member of the agricultural center advisory committee. The board members may not be a full time regular county employee; however, the board member may be an elected official of the county. 
(Res. of 4-22-2010, § 1) 
Editor's note— Res. of Apr. 22, 2010, § 1, deleted former § 2.50.050, and enacted a new § 2.50.050 as set out herein. Former § 2.50.050 pertained to composition of recreation and parks board. See the Code Comparative Table for complete derivation. 
2.50.060. - Terms of parks and leisure services board members. 
A.  The terms of office for the members of the parks and leisure services board shall be for four years, or until their successors are appointed and qualified. The terms may be staggered in order to maintain continuity of service; 
B.  The board will be composed of residents of Hall County; 
C.  Each member will serve one four-year term and will be eligible to serve additional, consecutive four-year terms if appointed by the county commission; 
D.  The board member terms will coincide with the commissioner's term who selected the individual for appointment to the board; 
E.  The ex-officio appointment will be made annually by the body they represent. 

 
(Res. of 4-22-2010, § 2) 
Editor's note— Res. of Apr. 22, 2010, § 2, deleted former § 2.50.060, and enacted a new § 2.50.060 as set out herein. Former § 2.50.060 pertained to terms of recreation and parks board members. See the Code Comparative Table for complete derivation. 
2.50.061. - Meetings. 
A.  The parks and leisure services board meetings will be held on a monthly basis. 
B.  The first regular meeting in January of each year shall be called the organizational meeting. The purpose of the meeting shall be the election and installation of officers and other business that may need to come before such meetings. 
C.  The parks and leisure services board shall meet and organize by electing one of their members as chairman and such other officers as may be necessary; vacancies in such board occurring otherwise than by expiration of term shall be filled by the county board of commissioners only for the unexpired term. 
D.  The procedure for conducting all meetings shall be in accordance with Robert's Rules of Order. 
E.  Any agenda items to be considered should submitted to the chairman of the parks and leisure services board and the parks and leisure services director no later than three business days prior to the scheduled meeting date. 
F.  Special meetings may be called by the chairman of the board, the parks and leisure services director, or on the written request of at least three members of the board. Notice of such special meetings shall be served on other members by phone or in writing at least 24 hours in advance of the meeting. 
G.  Three voting members shall constitute a quorum at any regular or special meeting. 
H.  The absence for three consecutive regular meetings of any member of the board without due and acceptable excuse, shall constitute a vacancy on the board. 
I.  All meetings are open to the public. 
(Res. of 4-22-2010, § 3) 
2.50.070. - Powers and duties of parks and leisure services board. 
The parks and leisure services board shall act in an advisory capacity to the parks and leisure services director and the Hall County Board of Commissioners to assist in determining the best, most effective, and most economical manner in which to provide recreational activities and parks to meet the various leisure interests of the citizens of the county. The specific duties of the parks and leisure services board shall include the following: 
A.  To promote recreation to the citizens of the county of all ages and interests; 
B.  To solicit input from citizens and bring their requests and concerns to the board and/or parks and leisure services director, and communicate to citizens information and/or concerns relative to matters involving parks and recreation in Hall County. 
C.  To assist in formalizing and in overseeing the implementation of policies regarding programs of both athletic and general recreation through coordination with the parks and leisure services director; 
D.  To review and advise the commissioners of the county on matters of park development, park location, personnel selection, and purchasing; 
E.  To advise the parks and leisure services director in the formulation of the parks and leisure services department budget; 
F.  To seek public input as to parks and leisure services development and programs, and to assure the basic elements of the master plan are followed; 
G.  To review and approve the official minutes of all board meetings as prepared by the parks and leisure services department, prior to the transmittal of such minutes to the county administrator's office; 
H.  To act in an advisory capacity to the parks and leisure services department in promoting, marketing, programming, planning and other leisure services related aspects of the parks and leisure services program including the long range planning for resources for capital projects for rehabilitation, design and/or development of recreation and park facilities. 
I.  To assist and advise the parks and leisure services director in the establishment of essential policies, rules and regulations relating to the planning, acquisition, disposition, operation, use, care and maintenance of areas and structures owned, leased or otherwise acquired by Hall County for use as parks; 
J.  To assist and advise the parks and leisure services department staff liaison in the development of a continuing plan for the parks and leisure services program; 
K.  To assist and advise the parks and leisure services department in establishing priorities at budget time for those items other than administrative functions relating to parks and leisure services policy; 
(Res. of 4-22-2010, § 4) 
Editor's note— Res. of Apr. 22, 2010, § 4, deleted former § 2.50.070, and enacted a new § 2.50.070 as set out herein. Former § 2.50.070 pertained to powers and duties of recreation and parks board. See the Code Comparative Table for complete derivation. 
2.50.071. - Staff support. 
Staff support will be assigned by the parks and leisure services director to process the administrative work of the board, prepare agendas, record meeting minutes and to provide staff guidance/update. The director shall prepare or cause to be prepared a manual for each member of the board to include the following information: 
A.  Copy of ordinance authorizing the parks and leisure services board. 
B.  By-laws of the board. 
C.  List of fees and charges used by the department. 
D.  Copy of current annual budget. 
E.  Site plans of each park area owned and operated by the county and list of their facilities and equipment. 
F.  Any other information helpful in acquainting new board members of the procedures and operation of the park and leisure services board. 
(Res. of 4-22-2010, § 5) 
ARTICLE II. - PARKS REGULATIONS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference— Health and safety generally, tit. 8. 

2.50.080. - Littering prohibited. 
It is unlawful for any person to throw or deposit litter on the grounds, streets, sidewalks, fountain, pond, lake, swimming pool, stream or other body of water in any recreation facility, except within public receptacles and in such a manner that the litter will be prevented from being carried or deposited by the elements upon any part of the recreation facility. Where public receptacles are not provided, all such litter shall be carried away from the park by the person responsible for its presence and shall be properly disposed of elsewhere. 
(Res. of 3-12-84, § 2; Code 1991, § 2.20.080) 
Cross reference— Littering, § 8.60.090 et seq. 
2.50.090. - Weapons prohibited. 
It is unlawful for any person to take on a recreational facility any weapon; or to shoot, use, carry or employ any weapon or similar device in a recreation facility. 
(Res. of 3-12-84, § 3; Code 1991, § 2.20.090) 
2.50.091. - Consumer fireworks and fireworks prohibited. 
Without a valid permit issued by the Hall County Fire Services Department, it shall be unlawful for any person to take into or onto a Hall County park or Hall County recreation facility any consumer fireworks or fireworks as defined in this chapter. It is also unlawful to shoot, explode, use, ignite, carry or employ any consumer fireworks or fireworks or similar devices in any Hall County park or recreation facility without a valid permit. 
(Res. of 9-10-15(1), § 3) 
2.50.100. - Throwing objects prohibited. 
It is unlawful for any person to throw any stone or missile at any person or at any public or private building or sign in a recreation facility. 
(Res. of 3-12-84, § 4; Code 1991, § 2.20.100) 
2.50.110. - Obscene language and fighting words. 
It is unlawful for any person, without provocation, to use obscene language or fighting words in a recreation facility. 
(Res. of 10-9-89, § 1; Code 1991, § 2.20.110) 
2.50.120. - Fires restricted. 
It is unlawful for any person to build or maintain a fire in a recreation facility except in designated areas which are clearly marked by signs. 
(Res. of 3-12-84, § 6; Code 1991, § 2.20.120) 
2.50.130. - Damaging vegetation prohibited. 
It is unlawful for any person to cut trees, tree limbs, shrubbery, flowers or other vegetation or dig up or damage trees, flowers, or shrubbery or other vegetation in a recreation facility. 
(Res. of 3-12-84, § 7; Code 1991, § 2.20.130) 
2.50.140. - Alcoholic beverages prohibited generally. 
It is unlawful for any person to possess, use or consume any alcoholic beverage in a recreation facility located in Hall County, except as may be specifically authorized for professional sporting events, pursuant to chapters 5.10, 5.30 and 5.60 of title 5 of the Official Code of Hall County. However, alcoholic beverages may be allowed in a recreation facility located in Hall County for events that are approved by the Hall County Board of Commissioners and licensed or permitted by the Hall County Business License Director. 
(Res. of 3-12-84, § 8; Code 1991, § 2.20.140; Res. of 2-11-10(1), § 1; Res. of 4-26-12(1), § 1) 
Cross reference— Alcoholic beverages prohibited at Corps of Engineers operated parks, § 2.50.260; open containers of alcoholic beverages in vehicles, ch. 9.10. 
2.50.150. - Alcoholic beverage advertising prohibited. 
It is unlawful for any person to advertise any alcoholic beverage either on uniforms or by public display in a recreation facility. 
(Res. of 3-12-84, § 9; Code 1991, § 2.20.150) 
Cross reference— Malt beverages and wine, ch. 5.30. 
2.50.160. - Vehicles restricted to designated areas. 
It is unlawful for any person to drive any vehicle in a recreation facility except upon roadways and paths constructed, designated and maintained for vehicular traffic. Recreation facility employees whose duties require them to drive maintenance vehicles and equipment shall be exempt from the limitations set forth in this section. 
(Res. of 3-12-84, § 10; Code 1991, § 2.20.160) 
Cross reference— Vehicles and traffic, tit. 10. 
2.50.170. - Parking restricted to designated areas. 
It is unlawful to park a vehicle in a recreation facility except in those areas designated by appropriate signs as vehicle parking areas. 
(Res. of 3-12-84, § 11; Code 1991, § 2.20.170) 
Cross reference— Vehicles and traffic, tit. 10. 
2.50.180. - Parking limited to facility users. 
It is unlawful for any person to park in a recreation area if the person is not utilizing the recreation facility. 
(Res. of 3-12-84, § 12; Code 1991, § 2.20.180) 
Cross reference— Vehicles and traffic, tit. 10. 
2.50.190. - Commercial activity restricted. 
It is unlawful for any person to sell or offer for sale any merchandise or operate a concession or engage in any commercial activity in a recreation facility without written authorization of the board of commissioners. 
(Res. of 3-12-84, § 13; Code 1991, § 2.20.190) 
Cross reference— Business licenses and regulations, tit. 5. 
2.50.200. - Hours open to public restricted. 
It is unlawful for any person to enter or be within a recreation facility between the hours of 12:01 a.m. and 7:00 a.m. daily except as follows: 
A.  Authorized recreation facility personnel; 
B.  Overnight campers who are within officially designated overnight camping areas only. Use of a recreation facility may be further restricted in those areas where the county recreation and parks board shall from time to time designate by posting on the affected premises the time the facilities are available for public use. 
(Res. of 3-12-84, § 14; Code 1991, § 2.20.200) 
2.50.210. - Hours for vehicles restricted. 
It is unlawful for any person to drive a vehicle in or on a recreation facility or attempt to park or park a vehicle on any of the streets, avenues, or parking areas or at any location within a recreation facility between the hours of 12:01 a.m. and 7:00 a.m. daily except as follows: 
A.  Authorized recreation facility personnel; 
B.  Overnight campers who are within officially designated overnight camping areas only. Use of a recreation facility may be further restricted in those areas where the county recreation and parks board shall from time to time designate by posting on the affected premises the time the facilities are available for public use. 
(Res. of 3-12-84, § 15; Code 1991, § 2.20.210) 
Cross reference— Vehicles and traffic, tit. 10. 
2.50.220. - Use of recreation facilities. 
It is unlawful for any person to use or attempt to use any of the facilities within a recreation facility except during the hours and in accordance with the rules and regulations established by the recreation authority. 
(Res. of 3-12-84, § 16; Code 1991, § 2.20.220) 
2.50.230. - Interference with use prohibited. 
It is unlawful for any person to engage in any activity within a recreation facility that could cause injury to other persons or interfere with the use and enjoyment of the recreation facility by other persons. 
(Res. of 3-12-84, § 17; Code 1991, § 2.20.230) 
2.50.240. - Compliance with rules and regulations. 
It is unlawful for any person to violate any rules or regulations relating to the use of the recreation area as established by the recreation authority where such rules and regulations have been approved and adopted by the board of commissioners. 
(Res. of 3-12-84, § 18; Code 1991, § 2.20.240) 
2.50.250. - Violations; penalty. 
Any person, firm, corporation, association or partnership violating any provision of this chapter as the same exists or as it may hereinafter be amended, or shall fail to do anything required by this chapter as the same exists or as it may hereafter be amended, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, amenable to the process of the Magistrate or State Court of Hall County, and upon conviction, shall be punished as provided in the Official Code of Hall County, Georgia section 1.50.020 for each violation in the discretion of the court. 
(Res. of 3-12-84, § 19; Code 1991, § 2.20.250; Res. of 6-10-04(1), § 1) 
2.50.260. - Alcoholic beverages prohibited at Corps of Engineers operated parks. 
A.  For the purposes of this section, certain words or terms used in this section shall be defined as follows: 
Alcoholic beverages means intoxicating beverages, malt beverages, wine or any other beverage containing any alcohol whatsoever. 
Person includes the words "individuals," "firms," "partnership," "corporation," "associations," and governmental bodies and all other legal entities. 
B.  Consumption, possession or the use of alcoholic beverages is prohibited in all posted park locations operated by the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers. 
C.  Pursuant to a cooperative law enforcement contract between the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers and Hall County, Georgia, Hall County Sheriff's Department personnel shall have authority to enforce, as a County resolution, Corps of Engineers regulations prohibiting alcoholic beverage consumption, possession, and use in Corps of Engineers operated parks where so posted. 
D.  1.  Any person who violates or fails to comply with any provision of this ordinance [section] shall be guilty of a violation of a county ordinance and shall be amenable to the process of the Magistrate or State Court of Hall County, Georgia. 
2.  Any person, firm, corporation, association or partnership violating any provision of this section as the same exists or as it may hereinafter be amended, or shall fail to do anything required by this section as the same exists or as it may hereafter be amended, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, amenable to the process of the Magistrate or State Court of Hall County, and upon conviction, shall be punished as provided in the Official Code of Hall County, Georgia section 1.50.020 for each violation in the discretion of the court. 
(Res. of 11-15-91; Code 1991, § 2.20.260; Res. of 12-12-96, § 1; Res. of 6-10-04(1), § 1) 
Cross reference— Alcoholic beverages prohibited in recreation facilities, § 2.50.140; open containers of alcoholic beverages in vehicles, ch. 9.10. 
CHAPTER 2.60. - PLANNING COMMISSION[5] 

 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note— Res. of March 27, 2003, § 2, repealed Ch. 2.60, in its entirety, which pertained to the planning commission. Section 3 of said resolution added provisions designated as a new Ch. 2.60, to read as herein set out. See the Code Comparative Table for a detailed analysis of inclusion. Also, it should be noted that the provisions of Ch. 2.60 are printed both in title 2 and in appendix A to title 17. When future amendments to the chapter are incorporated in the Code, the provisions should be updated at both locations. 
Cross reference— Subdivisions, tit. 16; zoning regulations, tit. 17; uses subject to approval of planning commission or zoning board of adjustment, ch. 17.350. 

2.60.010. - Membership. 
The Hall County Planning Commission shall consist of five members, who shall be residents of the county, appointed by the board of commissioners. The current members are reappointed to terms expiring on January 31, 2005. Beginning February 1, 2005, and every two years thereafter, each member of the Hall County Board of Commissioners shall appoint one member for a two-year term to the planning commission. Each two-year term will begin February 1, and expire January 31, or continue until his or her successor is appointed. Any vacancy in membership shall be filled for the unexpired term by the board of commissioners who shall have the authority to remove any member for cause on written charges after a public hearing. The unexcused absence of a planning commission member from three consecutive regularly scheduled meetings without prior notice to the chairman of the planning commission or the planning commission staff office shall terminate said member's appointment. Members of the planning commission shall be reimbursed and/or compensated for their services pursuant to direction and approval of the Hall County Commission. 
(Res. of 3-27-03, § 3) 
2.60.020. - Organization; proceedings. 
The chairman of the planning commission shall be elected from its members and approved by the board of commissioners. The term of the chairman shall be one year with eligibility for re-election. The planning commission shall appoint a secretary, who may be an officer or employee of the county. The planning commission shall adopt its own rules of procedure and determine its time of meeting. All meetings of the planning commission at which official action is taken shall be open to the public and all records of the planning commission shall be a public record. 
(Res. of 3-27-03, § 3) 
2.60.030. - Powers and duties. 
The planning commission shall have the following powers and duties: 
A.  To accept applications and make findings and recommendations at a public hearing for all amendments to Title 17 and forward said recommendations to the county board of commissioners. (See Chapter 17.370 of this Code); 
B.  To grant application for all conditional uses, site plan review as specified by Title 17 and uses subject to the approval of the planning commission, provided that the standards and requirements of Title 17 are met. (See Chapter 17.350 of this Code). If a public hearing is required by Title 17 for a particular use or amendment, a sign shall be posted at least 15 days prior to said public hearing in a conspicuous place on the property and shall state the nature of the request and the time and place of said public hearing. Further, the staff shall notify each adjoining property owner at their address, as shown by the records of the board of tax assessors, by mail postmarked at least five days prior to said planning commission hearing on the application; 
C.  To review preliminary subdivision plats and grant development approval for same when required under the provisions of Titles 16 and 17; 
D.  To review final subdivision plats and grant recording and approval permits for subdivision when required under the provisions of Titles 16 and 17; 
E.  To initiate, direct and review from time to time a study of the provisions of Title 17 and to make reports of its findings and recommendations as to amendments to the board of commissioners of the county; 
F.  To investigate and make recommendations to the county commission regarding the acceptance and classification of county roads; 
G.  To accept and determine requests regarding unclassified uses as per Chapter 17.330; 
H.  To hear and take action on appeals of determinations and decisions made by the planning department as specified by Title 17; 
I.  The planning commission shall make such determinations, shall investigate such matters relating to the planning and development of the county and take such action as required by Title 17 and the laws of the state. 
J.  To authorize upon appeal in specific cases such variances as will not be contrary to the public interest where, owing to special conditions, a literal enforcement of the provisions of Title 17 will, in an individual case, result in unnecessary hardship and so that the spirit of Title 17 shall be observed, public safety and welfare secured, and substantial justice done. In cases involving requests for variances from the building setback standards, a plat or survey of the property is required. In cases involving setback variances for commercial or industrial uses of land, a site plan of the property in question prepared by a registered land surveyor, architect, landscape architect or engineer shall be required. The authority to grant such variances shall be limited to variances from the following requirements: 
1.  Setbacks from property lines. 
2.  Planted buffers and vision clearance requirements. 
3.  Off-street parking space requirements. 
4.  Other requirements where the granting of a variance is specifically authorized. 
K.  Such variances may be granted in such individual cases of unnecessary hardship upon a finding of the board that: 
1.  There are extraordinary and exceptional conditions pertaining to the particular lot in question because of its size, shape or topography (the hardship must relate to the physical character of the lot and not to a personal or economic hardship); 
2.  The application of the requirements of this Title 17 to this particular piece of property would create an unusual hardship; 
3.  Such conditions are peculiar to the particular piece of property involved and are not common to other properties in the neighborhood; and 
4.  Such conditions are not the result of any actions of the property owner; and 
5.  Relief, if granted, would not cause substantial detriment to the public good or impair the purposes and intent of Title 17; provided, however, that no variance may be granted for a use of land or building or structure that is prohibited by Title 17 or for a conditional use which has been denied by the county planning commission. 
L.  To hear and decide such conditional uses as the board is required to act upon under the terms of Title 17. 
M.  To receive and act upon applications for the change, continuance and/or enlargement of a nonconforming use as provided in Chapter 17.340 of these regulations. 
N.  To hear and decide appeals where it is alleged there is error in any order, requirement, decision or determination made by an administrative official in the enforcement of Title 17. 
O.  To perform other duties as from time to time may be delegated by the Hall County Commission. 
(Res. of 3-27-03, § 3) 
2.60.040. - Actions by planning commission. 
A.  From the effective date of this chapter, forward, all references to the zoning board of adjustment as found in the Official Code of Hall County, Georgia, shall be understood to refer to the Hall County Planning Commission. 
B.  In all actions or decisions of the planning commission, three members being present shall constitute a quorum with a majority vote of the quorum constituting an official action or decision of the planning commission. Each official action, with the full text of the motion and record of members' votes shall be incorporated in the minutes of the planning commission. If an application for a conditional use or a use permitted subject to approval of the planning commission is denied by the planning commission, then the same property may not again be considered for any zoning application and no application shall be filed until the expiration of at least six months immediately following the denial of the application and may not be considered for an application of the same type, and no application shall be filed (conditional use, etc.) until the expiration of at least six months immediately following the denial of the application. 
(Res. of 3-27-03, § 3) 
2.60.050. - Deadline for applications for appeals. 
All applications for proposed appeals, whether an appeal for a variance from the building setback standards, conditional use, a nonconforming use or an appeal of a decision by an administrative official, shall be submitted to the office of the planning department at least 15 working days in advance of the next regular meeting of the planning commission. 
(Res. of 3-27-03, § 3) 
2.60.060. - Effective period of approved applications. 
All applications approved by the board, whether a request for variance from the terms of Title 17, a request for conditional use, a request for the enlargement, change or continuance of a nonconforming use or a request to appeal a decision by an administrative official in the enforcement of Title 17, shall be effective for a period of six months. If no action is taken by the applicant to implement the purpose of the application by obtaining the proper permit and/or license and proceeding with the building, occupancy or establishment of business within six months from the date of approval by the board, said approval shall become null and void. 
(Res. of 3-27-03, § 3) 
2.60.070. - Exercise of planning commission powers. 
In exercising the above powers, the planning commission may, in conformity with the provisions of Title 17, reverse or affirm, wholly or in part, or may have all powers of the officer from whom the application is taken, and may direct the issuance of a building permit, occupancy permit or certificate of zoning compliance. In no case shall the powers of the board be construed to include authority to reclassify use zones. 
(Res. of 3-27-03, § 3) 
2.60.080. - Conditions of planning commission decisions. 
In exercising the above powers, the planning commission may place any reasonable conditions or stipulations upon a conditional use, variance, etc., as deemed necessary (such as hours of operation, parking, maximum building size, outside displays, time limits, etc.) to further insure the orderly operation of the proposed use and its compatibility with the surrounding properties. 
(Res. of 3-27-03, § 3) 
2.60.090. - Appeal of planning commission decisions. 
Any decision of the planning commission may be appealed to the board of commissioners in accordance with Chapter 17.370 of this Code. 
(Res. of 3-27-03, § 3) 
CHAPTER 2.70 - HALL COUNTY EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT[6] 

 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Editor's note— Res. of July 8, 2010, §§ 1, 2(Exh. A), deleted former Ch. 2.70, §§ 2.70.010—2.70.100, and enacted a new Ch. 2.70 as set out herein. Former Ch. 2.70 pertained to emergency management and civil defense. See the Code Comparative Table for complete derivation. 

2.70.010. - Definitions. 
Contractor(s) means individuals, partnerships, corporations, and other legal entities engaging in the construction trade industry or providing services related thereto such as the sale of building supplies and materials. 
Disaster means any natural, technological, civil emergency or threat thereof that causes or has the potential to cause damage of sufficient severity and magnitude to result in a declaration of a state of emergency declared by the Governor or the President of the United States. 
Emergency means any natural or manmade event requiring the activation of the local emergency operations plan (LEOP). 
Emergency management means the preparation for the carrying out of all emergency functions other than functions for which military forces are primarily responsible to prevent, minimize, and repair injury and damage resulting from emergencies, energy emergencies, disasters, or the imminent threat thereof, of manmade or natural origin. These functions include, without limitation, fire-fighting services; police services; medical and health services; rescue; engineering; warning services; communications; defense from radiological, chemical, and other special weapons; evacuation of persons from stricken areas; emergency welfare services; emergency transportation; nuclear or electric power plant protection; temporary restoration of public utility services; and other functions related to civilian protection, together with all other activities necessary or incidental to the preparation for and carrying out of the foregoing functions. 
Governing bodies means, unless otherwise specified, the board of commissioners of Hall County, Georgia and the city councils or board of commissioners of the municipalities with any part of its municipal boundaries within Hall County, Georgia. 
Hall County Emergency Operations Center shall mean that designated facility to be used as a command center in the event of a state of emergency as declared by the governor. 
Local emergency management director means the person nominated in accordance with section 2.70.020 of this chapter and appointed by the state emergency management director to implement the LEOP. 
Local emergency operations plan (LEOP) means a comprehensive plan or program for emergency management within Hall County and the municipalities, any part of which is located within Hall County. 
Overcharging means the charging of prices for goods, materials, services, or housing which prices are substantially in excess of the customary charges or, in applicable cases, substantially in excess of the suppliers' or providers' costs for such goods, materials, services, or housing. The existence of overcharging shall be presumed from a substantial increase in the price after which the merchandise or cost/rental of housing was offered in the usual course of business immediately prior to the onset of the emergency, but shall not include increases in cost to the suppliers directly attributable to the higher cost of materials, supplies and labor resulting from the emergency. 
State of emergency is defined pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 38-3-3(7) and means the condition declared by the Governor when, in his judgment, the threat or actual occurrence of a disaster, emergency, or energy emergency in any part of the state is of sufficient severity and magnitude to warrant extraordinary assistance by the state to supplement the efforts and available resources of the several localities and relief organizations in preventing or alleviating the damage, loss, hardship, or suffering threatened or caused thereby. 
State emergency management director means the person appointed by the Governor to head the Georgia Emergency Management Agency. 
Subsequent recovery period means that period during which the disaster continues to cause disruption in the disaster area, but shall not exceed three months after the emergency declaration has been terminated. 
(Res. of 7-8-10, § 2(Exh. A)) 
2.70.020. - Hall County Emergency Management Agency; powers and duties. 
A.  The Hall County Emergency Management Agency created by resolution of the Hall County Commission on December 13, 1982, by agreement with the governing officials within the county shall continue as created in said resolution subject to the operation in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. 
B.  The chairperson of the Hall County Commissioners, with the concurrence of a majority of the governing bodies of the cities within Hall County, shall nominate, for appointment by the state emergency management director, a director of the Hall County Emergency Management Agency. 
C.  Upon appointment, the Hall County Emergency Management Agency Director shall have direct responsibility for the organization, administration, and operations of the local organization for emergency management, subject to the direction and control of the chairman of the board of commissioners of Hall County and shall serve at the pleasure of the board of commissioners of Hall County. 
D.  When appointed, the Hall County Emergency Management Agency Director is charged with the following duties: 
1.  Represent the governing officials of the county on matters pertaining to emergency management. 
2.  Assist governing officials in organizing county departments for emergency operations. 
3.  Develop, in conjunction with county and city departments, the LEOP for emergency functions. Such plan will be consistent with the Georgia Emergency Operations Plan and shall be submitted for approval to the board of commissioners of Hall County and the cities with any municipal jurisdiction in Hall County, and thence to the Georgia Emergency Management Agency for approval. 
4.  Maintain the Hall County Emergency Management Agency and carry out the day-to-day administration of the Hall County Emergency Management Agency Program, including the submission of required reports, to the Georgia Emergency Management Agency. 
5.  Submit reports as required by the Hall County Board of Commissioners in keeping with good management practices, e.g., financial, daily activities, etc. 
6.  Obtain, with the approval of Hall County Board of Commissioners, a facility to be used as the Hall County Emergency Operations Center. 
7.  Coordinate the activities of the Hall County Emergency Operations Center staff during periods of emergency, and under the supervision of the Hall County Board of Commissioners. 
(Res. of 7-8-10, § 2(Exh. A)) 
2.70.030. - Hall County Emergency Management Agency organization functions. 
A.  The Hall County Emergency Management Agency shall be established around existing county and city departments. The emergency support functions (ESFs) and department/agency assignments shall be as set forth in the LEOP approved pursuant to subsection 2.70.020D.3. above.
