The notice shall set forth the measures necessary to achieve compliance and shall state the time within which such measures must be completed. If the person engaged in the land-disturbing activity fails to comply within the time specified, he shall be deemed in violation of this chapter. If there is any reasonably notable and visible quantity of sediment leaving or that has left the property lot lines, impacting other property or any stream buffer zone, no verbal or written notice shall be required, and the person engaged in land-disturbing activities shall be deemed in violation of this chapter. 
B.  The local issuing authority shall have the power to conduct such investigations as it may reasonably deem necessary to carry out duties as prescribed in this chapter, and for this purpose to enter at reasonable times upon any property, public or private, for the purpose of investigation and inspecting the sites of land-disturbing activities. 
C.  Once a verbal or written warning or a citation has been issued for a violation of this chapter, no additional warning will need to be given for any violation on that site for enforcement action relating to this chapter. 
D.  No person shall refuse entry or access to any authorized representative or agent of the local issuing authority, the commission, the district, or division who requests entry for the purposes of inspection, and who presents appropriate credentials, nor shall any person obstruct, hamper, or interfere with any such representative while in the process of carrying out his official duties. 
E.  The district or the commission or both shall semi-annually review the actions of counties and municipalities which have been certified as local issuing authorities pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 12-7-8(a). The district or the commission or both may provide technical assistance to any county or municipality for the purpose of improving the effectiveness of the county's erosion and sedimentation control program. The district or the commission shall notify the division and request investigation by the division if any deficient or ineffective local program is found. 
F.  The division may periodically review the actions of counties and municipalities which have been certified as local issuing authorities pursuant to code section 12-7-8(a). Such review may include, but shall not be limited to, review of the administration and enforcement of a governing authority's ordinance and review of conformance with an agreement, if any, between the district and the governing authority. If such review indicates that the governing authority of any county or municipality certified pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 12-7-8(a) has not administered or enforced its ordinances or has not conducted the program in accordance with any agreement entered into pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 12-7-7(e), the division shall notify the governing authority of the county or municipality in writing. The governing authority of any county or municipality so notified shall have 90 days within which to take the necessary corrective action to retain certification as a local issuing authority. If the county or municipality does not take necessary correction action within 90 days after notification by the division, the division may revoke the certification of the county or municipality as a local issuing authority. 
(Ord. of 6-10-10(1), § 1(Exh. A)) 
8.40.070. - General offenses. 
A.  No person shall remove, deface, obstruct or move any postings, notices, stickers, stop-work orders, or other material left on-site by the local issuing authority unless by the local issuing authority or its agent. 
B.  It shall be unlawful for any person to dump, deposit or cause any reasonably notable and visible quantity of sedimentation, mud or related debris to come onto any public highway, road, street, alley or thoroughfare. 
C.  With the exception of land-disturbing activity exempted under this chapter, it shall be unlawful for any person to cause any mud or sediment to impact any other property or any stream buffer as a result of any land-disturbing activity where best management practices are not properly designed, installed and maintained. 
(Ord. of 6-10-10(1), § 1(Exh. A)) 
8.40.080. - Penalties and incentives. 
A.  Failure to obtain a permit for land-disturbing activity. If any person commences any land-disturbing activity requiring a land-disturbing permit as prescribed in this chapter without first obtaining said permit, the person shall be subject to double permit fees at the time the permit is obtained and/or revocation of his business license, work permit or other authorization for the conduct of a business and associated work activities within the jurisdictional boundaries of the local issuing authority. It is the responsibility of the property owner to ensure that the proper permit is obtained. 
B.  Stop-work orders. 
1.  For the first and second violations of the provisions of this chapter, the director or the local issuing authority shall issue a written warning to the violator. The violator shall have five days to correct the violation. If the violation is not corrected within five days, the director or local issuing authority shall issue a stop-work order requiring that land-disturbing activities be stopped until necessary corrective action or mitigation has occurred; provided, however, that, if the violation presents an imminent threat to public health or waters of the state, the director or local issuing authority shall issue an immediate stop-work order in lieu of a warning; 
2.  For a third and each subsequent violation, the director or local issuing authority shall issue an immediate stop-work order; and 
3.  All stop-work orders shall be effective immediately upon issuance and shall be in effect until the necessary corrective action or mitigation has occurred. 
4.  When a violation in the form of taking action without a permit, failure to maintain a stream buffer, or significant amounts of sediment, as determined by the local issuing authority or by the director or his or her designee, have been or are being discharged into state waters and where best management practices have not been properly designed, installed, and maintained, a stop-work order shall be issued by the local issuing authority or by the director or his or her designee. All such stop-work orders shall be effective immediately upon issuance and shall be in effect until the necessary corrective action or mitigation has occurred. Such stop-work orders shall apply to all land-disturbing activity on the site with the exception of the installation and maintenance of temporary or permanent erosion and sediment controls. 
5.  While a stop-work order is in effect, the building inspection department shall conduct no inspection on the property except for soil erosion inspections, and all work on the site, except that work necessary to achieve compliance with this chapter, shall cease until compliance is achieved. 
C.  Bond forfeiture. If, through inspection, it is determined that a person engaged in land-disturbing activities has failed to comply with the approved plan, a written notice to comply shall be served upon that person. The notice shall set forth the measures necessary to achieve compliance with the plan and shall state the time within which such measures must be completed. If the person engaged in the land-disturbing activity fails to comply within the time specified, he shall be deemed in violation of this chapter and, in addition to other penalties, shall be deemed to have forfeited his performance bond, if required to post one under the provisions subsection 8.40.050 B.2(g)(2). The local issuing authority may call the bond or any part thereof to be forfeited and may use the proceeds to hire a contractor to stabilize the site of the land-disturbing activity and bring it into compliance. 
D.  Civil penalties. Any person who violates any provisions of this chapter, or any permit condition or limitation established pursuant to this chapter, or who negligently or intentionally fails or refuses to comply with any final or emergency order of the county issued as provided in this chapter shall be liable for a civil penalty not to exceed $2,500.00 per day. For the purpose of enforcing the provisions of this chapter, notwithstanding any provisions of the Official Code of Hall County, the Magistrate Court of Hall County shall be authorized to impose a penalty not to exceed $2,500.00 for each violation. Notwithstanding any limitation of law as to penalties which can be assessed for violations of county ordinances, any other court of competent jurisdiction trying cases brought as violations of this chapter likewise shall be authorized to impose penalties for such violations not to exceed $2,500.00 for each violation. Each day during which a violation or failure or refusal to comply continues shall be a separate violation. 
E.  Penalty. Any person, firm, corporation, association or partnership violating any provision of this chapter as the same exists or as it may hereinafter be amended, or shall fail to do anything required by this chapter as the same exists or as it may hereafter be amended, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, amenable to the process of the Magistrate or State Court of Hall County, and upon conviction, shall be punished as provided in the Official Code of Hall County, Georgia section 1.50.020 for each violation in the discretion of the Court. 
(Ord. of 6-10-10(1), § 1(Exh. A)) 
8.40.090. - Education and certification. 
A.  Persons involved in land development design, review, permitting, construction, monitoring, or inspection of any land-disturbing activity shall meet the education and training certification requirements, dependent on their level of involvement with the process, as developed by the commission in consultation with the division and the stakeholder advisory board created pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 12-7-20. 
B.  For each site on which land-disturbing activity occurs, each entity or person acting as either a primary, secondary, or tertiary permittee, as defined in the state general permit, shall have as a minimum one person who is in responsible charge of erosion and sedimentation control activities on behalf of said entity or person and meets the applicable education or training certification requirements developed by the commission present on site whenever land-disturbing activities are conducted on that site. A project site shall herein be defined as any land-disturbance site or multiple sites within a larger common plan of development or sale permitted by an owner or operator for compliance with the state general permit. 
C.  Persons or entities involved in projects not requiring a state general permit but otherwise requiring certified personnel on site may contract with certified persons to meet the requirements of this chapter. 
D.  If a state general permittee who has operational control of land-disturbing activities for a site has met the certification requirements of paragraph (1) of subsection (b) of O.C.G.A. § 12-7-19, then any person or entity involved in land-disturbing activity at that site and operating in a subcontractor capacity for such permittee shall meet those educational requirements specified in paragraph (4) of subsection (b) of O.C.G.A § 12-7-19 and shall not be required to meet any educational requirements that exceed those specified in said paragraph. 
(Ord. of 6-10-10(1), § 1(Exh. A)) 
8.40.100. - Administrative appeal judicial review. 
A.  Administrative remedies. The suspension, revocation, modification or grant with condition of a permit by the local issuing authority upon finding that the holder is not in compliance with the approved erosion, sedimentation and pollution control plan; or that the holder is in violation of permit conditions; or that the holder is in violation of any ordinance; shall entitle the person submitting the plan or holding the permit to a hearing before the Board of Commissioners of Hall County within 30 days after receipt by the local issuing authority of written notice of appeal. 
B.  Judicial review. Any person, aggrieved by a decision or order of the local issuing authority, after exhausting his administrative remedies, shall have the right to appeal de novo to the Superior Court of Hall County. 
(Ord. of 6-10-10(1), § 1(Exh. A)) 
8.40.110. - Liability. 
A.  Neither the approval of a plan under the provisions of this chapter, nor the compliance with provisions of this chapter shall relieve any person from the responsibility for damage to any person or property otherwise imposed by law nor impose any liability upon the local issuing authority or district for damage to any person or property. 
B.  The fact that land-disturbing activity for which a permit has been issued results in injury to the property of another shall neither constitute proof of nor create a presumption of a violation of the standards provided for in this chapter or the terms of the permit. 
C.  No provision of this chapter shall permit any persons to violate the Georgia Erosion and Sedimentation Act of 1975, the Georgia Water Quality Control Act, or the rules and regulations promulgated and approved thereunder or pollute any waters of the state as defined thereby. 
(Ord. of 6-10-10(1), § 1(Exh. A)) 
APPENDIX I. - HALL COUNTY PLAN REVIEW AND INSPECTION FEE SCHEDULE 

 
(Res. of 8-22-13(1), § 1(Exh. A); Res. of 5-25-17(1), § 2(Exh. B)) 
CHAPTER 8.50. - HAZARDOUS WASTE[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Cross reference— Solid waste generally, ch. 8.60; incineration of solid waste and biomedical waste, ch. 8.70; sewage collection and disposal, ch. 13.10. 

8.50.010. - Purpose. 
The purpose of this chapter shall be to prevent the disposal of hazardous wastes into the surface and subsurface waters within the county limits, or without the county limits when hazardous wastes are carried within the county limits by waters flowing into the county, when such disposal poses substantial hazards to public health, safety or welfare or to the environment. 
(Res. of 10-21-94; Code 1991, § 8.20.010) 
8.50.020. - Definitions. 
For the purposes of this chapter: 
Contaminate means to create undesired environmental effects. 
County means Hall County, Georgia. 
Designated hazardous wastes means any solid waste identified as such in regulations promulgated by the board of natural resources of the State of Georgia. The board may identify as "designated hazardous waste" any solid waste which the board concludes is capable of posing a substantial present or potential hazard to human health or the environment when improperly treated, stored, transported, or disposed of or otherwise managed, based on the factors set forth in regulations promulgated by the administrator of the United States Environmental Protection Agency pursuant to the federal act which is codified as 40 C.F.R. section 261.11(a)(3), in force and effect on February 1, 1991, if such solid waste contains any substance which is listed on any one or more of the following lists: 
A.  List of Hazardous Constituents, codified as 40 C.F.R. part 261, appendix VIII, in force and effect on February 1, 1991; 
B.  Groundwater Monitoring List, codified as 40 C.F.R. part 264, appendix IX, in force and effect on February 1, 1991; 
C.  List of Hazardous Substances and Reportable Quantities, codified as 40 C.F.R. table 302.4, and all appendices thereto, in force and effect on February 1, 1991; 
D.  List of Regulated Pesticides codified as 40 C.F.R. part 180, in force and effect on February 1, 1991; 
E.  List of Extremely Hazardous Substances and Their Threshold Planning Quantities, codified as 40 C.F.R. part 355, appendix A, in force and effect on February 1, 1991; or 
F.  List of Chemicals and Chemical Categories, codified as 40 C.F.R. part 372.65, in force and effect on February 1, 1991. 
Hazardous wastes means any solid waste which has been defined as a hazardous waste in regulations promulgated by the administrator of the United States Environmental Protection Agency pursuant to the federal act which is in force and effect on February 1, 1991, codified as 40 C.F.R. section 261.3, and any designated hazardous waste. 
Solid waste means any garbage or refuse; sludge from a wastewater treatment plant, water supply treatment plant, or air pollution control facility; and other discarded material including solid, liquid, semisolid, or contained gaseous material resulting from industrial, commercial, mining and agricultural operations and from community activities, but does not include recovered materials, solid or dissolved materials in domestic [sewage]; solid or dissolved materials in irrigation return flows or industrial discharges that are point sources subject to permit under 33 U.S.C. section 1342; or source, special nuclear, or by-product material as defined by the Federal Atomic Energy Act of 1954, as amended (68 Stat. 923). 
Solid waste handling facility means any facility, the primary purpose of which is the storage, collection, transportation, treatment, utilization, processing, or disposal, or any combination thereof, of solid waste. 
Surface water, subsurface water, or waters means any and all rivers, streams, creeks, branches, lakes, reservoirs, ponds, drainage systems, springs, wells, aquifers, and all other bodies of surface or subsurface waters, natural or artificial, within the county, which are not entirely confined and retained completely upon the property of an individual person, partnership, corporation or other entity. 
(Res. of 10-21-94; Code 1991, § 8.20.020) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1.20.010 et seq. 
8.50.030. - Prohibited disposal. 
The act of disposing in, causing to be disposed in or failing to take adequate precautions to prevent the accidental disposal of any hazardous waste into or onto the waters or subsurface waters of the county, or into or onto waters that could reasonably be expected to flow or carry hazardous wastes into or onto the waters of the county, shall be a violation of this chapter. Each and every day that such violation exists shall be deemed a separate offense. Adequate precaution as used herein shall mean the use of the best practicable control technology currently available for the containment of hazardous waste at the time the violation of this chapter occurred. 
(Res. of 10-21-94; Code 1991, § 8.20.030) 
8.50.040. - Enforcement. 
The enforcement officers of public safety department, enforcement division, of the county and any duly authorized law enforcement officer shall have the duty to cite any violator of this chapter. 
(Res. of 10-21-94; Code 1991, § 8.20.040) 
8.50.050. - Judicial disposition. 
The magistrate's court of the county shall have jurisdiction over all alleged violations of this chapter. The prosecuting officer shall give proper citation to all alleged violators of this chapter to appear before and have disposition of the alleged violation before the magistrate's court of the county in the manner provided by law. 
(Res. of 10-21-94; Code 1991, § 8.20.050) 
8.50.060. - Violations; penalty. 
Any person, firm, corporation, association or partnership violating any provision of this chapter as the same exists or as it may hereinafter be amended, or shall fail to do anything required by this chapter as the same exists or as it may hereafter be amended, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, amenable to the process of the Magistrate or State Court of Hall County, and upon conviction, shall be punished as provided in the Official Code of Hall County, Georgia § 1.50.020 for each violation in the discretion of the court. 
(Res. of 10-21-94; Code 1991, § 8.20.060; Res. of 6-10-04(1), § 1) 
CHAPTER 8.60. - SOLID WASTE GENERALLY[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Cross reference— Hazardous waste, ch. 8.50; incineration of solid waste and biomedical waste, ch. 8.70; rubbish fires, ch. 8.110; abatement of nuisances, ch. 8.140; public services, tit. 13; sewage collection and disposal, ch. 13.10. 

8.60.010. - Solid waste management district established. 
A solid waste management district is created and established composed of all that unincorporated area within the county. 
(Res. of 5-26-94; Code 1991, § 8.24.010) 
Cross reference— Administration generally, tit. 2. 
8.60.020. - Intent. 
The intent of this chapter is: 
A.  To prevent the dumping of solid waste along and on the public streets, public rights-of-way, alleys and highways in all the county and the shoulders thereof; 
B.  To prevent the dumping of solid waste on public and private property in the county. 
(Res. of 5-26-94; Code 1991, § 8.24.020) 
8.60.030. - Definitions. 
For purposes of this chapter, the following terms shall have these meanings: 
Commissioners means board of commissioners of the county. 
Construction/demolition waste means waste building materials and rubble resulting from construction, remodeling, repair, and demolition operations on pavements, houses, commercial buildings, or other structures. Such wastes include, but are not limited to, asbestos-containing waste, wood, bricks, metal, concrete, wall board, paper cardboard, inert waste landfill material, and other nonputrescible wastes which have a low potential for groundwater contamination. 
Debris means sand, dirt, broken brick, blocks, broken pavement or other similar materials suitable for fill. The term shall not include household garbage or other types of solid waste such as wood or wood products which are subject to decomposition or decay. 
Designated hazardous waste means any solid waste identified as such in regulations promulgated by the board of natural resources of the State of Georgia. The board may identify as "designated hazardous waste" any solid waste which the board concludes is capable of posing a substantial present or potential hazard to human health or the environment when improperly treated, stored, transported, or disposed of or otherwise managed, based on the factors set forth in regulations promulgated by the administrator of the United States Environmental Protection Agency pursuant to the federal act which are codified as 40 C.F.R. section 261.11(a)(3), in force and effect on February 1, 1991, if such solid waste contains any substance which is listed on any one or more of the following lists: 
(A)  List of Hazardous Constituents, codified as 40 C.F.R. part 261, appendix VIII, in force and effect on February 1, 1991; 
(B)  Groundwater Monitoring List, codified as 40 C.F.R. part 264, appendix IX, in force and effect on February 1, 1991; 
(C)  List of Hazardous Substances and Reportable Quantities, codified as 40 C.F.R. table 302.4, and all appendices thereto, in force and effect on February 1, 1991; 
(D)  List of Regulated Pesticides, codified as 40 C.F.R. part 180, in force and effect on February 1, 1991; 
(E)  List of Extremely Hazardous Substances and Their Threshold Planning Quantities, codified as 40 C.F.R. part 355, appendix A, in force and effect on February 1, 1991; or 
(F)  List of Chemicals and Chemical Categories, codified as 40 C.F.R. part 372.65, in force and effect on February 1, 1991. 
Disposal facility means any facility or location where the final disposition of solid waste occurs, and includes, but is not limited to, landfilling and solid waste thermal treatment technology facilities. 
Domestic sewage means the liquid wastes from kitchens or laundries in dwelling units. 
Garbage means food waste including waste accumulations of animal or vegetable matter used or intended for use as food, or that attends the preparation, use, cooking, dealing in or storing of meat, fish, fowl, fruit or vegetables. 
Harborage means the enclosed spaces which afford rats hidden or partly hidden shelter, and suitable facilities for breeding and protecting their young until maturity. 
Hauler means any person, firm or corporation which collects or transports solid waste in the unincorporated areas of the county, including sanitary contractors and municipalities. 
Hazardous waste means any solid waste which has been defined as a hazardous waste in regulations promulgated by the administrator of the United States Environmental Protection Agency pursuant to the federal act which are in force and effect on February 1, 1991, codified as 40 C.F.R. section 261.3, and any designated hazardous waste. 
Household garbage means all solid waste accumulation resulting from normal daily activities of private residents attendant to food preparation, personal hygiene, housekeeping and property maintenance, with certain exceptions. This definition does not include furniture or other wood products, yard trimmings, debris, concrete, paint containers, clothes, appliances, riding toys, liquid wastes or oversized material that cannot be containerized in plastic disposable bags (including household trash compactor bags) no larger than 39-gallon capacity size. 
Industrial liquid wastes means liquid or water-borne waste from an industrial process. 
Inert waste landfill means a disposal facility accepting only waste that will not or is not likely to cause production of leachate of environmental concern. Such wastes are limited to earth and earth-like products, concrete, cured asphalt, rock, bricks, yard trimmings, and land clearing debris such as stumps, limbs, and leaves. This definition excludes industrial and demolition waste not specifically listed. Said term also excludes household garbage, liquid waste, hazardous waste and other similar types of refuse. 
Liquid waste means any waste material that is determined to contain "free liquids" as defined by method 9095 (Paint Filter Liquids Test), as described in Test Methods for the Evaluation of Solid Wastes, Physical/Chemical Methods (EPA Pub. No. SW-846). 
Litter means all garbage, rubbish, solid waste or any such noxious or offensive material improperly discarded or abandoned. 
Person means any person, firm, partnership, corporation, association or agency. 
Public or private highway property means the right-of-way of any road or highway; any body of water or watercourse or the shores or beaches thereof; any park, playground, building, refuge, or conservation or recreation area; and residential or farm properties, timberlands or forests. 
Putrescible means that which is capable of being quickly decomposed by microorganisms. Examples of putrescible wastes include but are not limited to kitchen wastes, animal manure, offal, hatchery and poultry processing plant wastes, dead animals, garbage and wastes which are contaminated by such wastes. 
Recovered materials means those materials which have known use, reuse, or recycling potential; can be feasibly used, reused or recycled; and have been diverted or removed from the solid waste stream for sale, use, reuse, or recycling, whether or not requiring subsequent separation and processing. 
Recyclable corrugated cardboard shall mean that grade of paper composed of a three-layer construction having smooth inner and outer layers and a corrugated medium of kraft paper. Excluded would be any wax or plastic coated material as well as any recyclable corrugated cardboard that is soiled or otherwise contaminated so as to render it non-recyclable (grease, food waste, blood, or chemicals), or adhered to polystyrene or other plastic. 
Recycling means any process by which materials which would otherwise become solid waste are collected, separated, or processed and reused or returned to use in the form of raw materials or products. 
Refuse includes all putrescible solid wastes, with the exception of body waste. Such waste includes garbage, rubbish, ashes, street sweepings, dead animals and solid commercial and industrial waste. 
Rubbish means solid waste which does not result from commercial or business activities. 
Sanitary contractor means a person, firm, or corporation which collects or transports solid waste in the unincorporated areas of the county for a fee. This shall not include municipalities or the county. 
Septic tank pumpings shall mean waste removed from any septic tank. 
Sewage means sanitary sewage, domestic sewage, and industrial liquid wastes, separate or in any combination. 
Solid waste means any garbage or refuse; sludge from a waste water treatment plant, water supply treatment plant, or air pollution control facility; and other discarded material including solid, liquid, semisolid, or contained gaseous material resulting from industrial, commercial, mining, and agricultural operations and from community activities, but does not include recovered materials, solid or dissolved materials in domestic sewage; solid or dissolved materials in irrigation return flows or industrial discharges that are point sources subject to permit under 33 U.S.C. section 1342; or source, special nuclear, or by-product material as defined by the federal Atomic Energy Act of 1954, as amended (68 Stat. 923). 
Solid waste handling facility means any facility, the primary purpose of which is the storage, collection, transportation, treatment, utilization, processing, or disposal, or any combination thereof, of solid waste. 
Waste means solid waste and liquid waste. 
Yard trimmings means vegetative matter, including but not limited to leaves, grass clippings, trees (and parts thereof), prunings, and other natural organic matter, commonly accepted at inert waste landfills, resulting from landscaping maintenance and land clearing operations, both residential and commercial. 
(Res. of 5-26-94; Code 1991, § 8.24.030) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1.20.010 et seq. 
8.60.040. - System of household garbage collection. 
A.  The primary purpose of the district is to establish, maintain and operate within the district a system of household garbage collection. 
B.  The system of solid waste management shall be as follows: 
1.  The county shall locate, maintain and operate one or more landfills for the disposal of solid waste or enter into contracts for the services of other legally permitted solid waste handling facilities. 
2.  The county shall locate, maintain and operate household garbage containers for the deposit of household garbage by individuals within the county. 
3.  The county shall transport the household garbage placed in the containers to the landfill or other legally permitted solid waste handling facility. 
4.  The county may implement other measures as called for in the county's Comprehensive Solid Waste Management Plan. 
(Res. of 5-26-94; Code 1991, § 8.24.040) 
8.60.050. - Solid waste contracts. 
The county may enter into contracts to perform all or a part of the solid waste collection and/or disposal system; provided such contracts are entered into in accordance with Hall County bidding procedures. 
(Res. of 5-26-94; Code 1991, § 8.24.050) 
Cross reference— County contracts, ch. 3.10. 
8.60.060. - Rules and regulations governing solid waste system. 
From time to time, the board of commissioners may form and establish rules and regulations governing the use and operation of the solid waste system and to carry out the intention of this chapter, and instruct the administrator and other county personnel to carry out the same. 
(Res. of 5-26-94; Code 1991, § 8.24.060) 
8.60.070. - Solid waste director. 
The solid waste director shall be under the general direction of the director of public works, who shall be assisted by a position to be deemed solid waste director. The collection, transportation, and disposal of waste shall be under the supervision and control of the solid waste director. The solid waste director shall be responsible for the administration and enforcement of the provisions of this chapter. For assistance and support, he may call upon whatever agency or department is necessary, with the approval of the public works director and the county administrator. Examples would be the office of the director of public safety, director of public health or any other local law enforcement agencies. The solid waste director shall have the right to appoint sanitation inspectors, who shall have authority, and whose duties shall be, to make routine inspections of matters within this chapter. All regulatory actions of the sanitation director must be approved, and are subject to review, by the public works director and county administrator, and are also subject to further review and approval by the commissioners. 
(Res. of 5-26-94; Code 1991, § 8.24.070) 
Cross reference— Administration and employees, tit. 2. 
8.60.080. - Inspections. 
The solid waste director is authorized to call upon the director of public safety and his staff to conduct inspections of the county sanitary landfill, disposal sites approved under sections 8.60.200 through 8.60.230, public rights-of-way leading to the disposal sites, county container collection sites, and other locations where unlawful dumping of wastes may have occurred. 
(Res. of 5-26-94; Code 1991, § 8.24.080) 
8.60.090—8.60.120. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Res. of December 14, 2006(2), § 2, repealed §§ 8.60.090—8.60.120, which pertained to unlawful littering; exceptions; collection of litter by depositor; littering from conveyance; and tracing litter. See also the Code Comparative Table. 
8.60.130. - Authorized solid waste haulers. 
Solid waste may only be collected for disposal by the county, by municipalities, or by sanitary contractors. 
(Res. of 5-26-94; Code 1991, § 8.24.130) 
8.60.140. - Sanitary contractors; license required. 
All sanitary contractors shall obtain business licenses from the county. 
(Res. of 5-26-94; Code 1991, § 8.24.140) 
8.60.150. - Sanitary contractors; truck identification. 
All haulers must number their trucks and list the weight of each truck and capacity of the same. 
(Res. of 5-26-94; Code 1991, § 8.24.150) 
8.60.160. - Haulers to secure waste in vehicles. 
It is unlawful for any hauler to haul, convey, or cause to be conveyed any waste upon or along the public streets and roadways except when the material transported is adequately covered in such a manner as to prevent it from falling, leaking or being blown from the transporting vehicle. The operator and/or owner of the offending vehicle shall be personally responsible for any violation of this section. 
(Res. of 5-26-94; Code 1991, § 8.24.160) 
Cross reference— Vehicles and traffic, tit. 10. 
8.60.170. - Disposal of dead animals. 
If a domestic or companion animal or fowl shall die, the owner must bury the carcass deep enough to prevent stench therefrom after notice of the death and location of the carcass. 
(Res. of 5-26-94; Code 1991, § 8.24.170) 
Cross reference— Animals, tit. 6. 
8.60.180. - Deposit of waste by haulers. 
Haulers shall only deposit solid waste, except prohibited waste, at the county sanitary landfill in accordance with the regulations of the landfill. In no event shall haulers, except individuals transporting household garbage, deposit solid waste at county container collection sites. 
(Res. of 5-26-94; Code 1991, § 8.24.180) 
8.60.190. - Recovery of recyclable corrugated cardboard. 
A.  The purposes of recovering recyclable corrugated cardboard are as follows: 
1.  To encourage generators and solid waste haulers operating within Hall County, Georgia to reduce the amount of waste requiring deposition in disposal facilities located within Hall County; 
2.  To help meet the goals and objectives outlined in the Georgia Comprehensive Solid Waste Management Act and the Comprehensive Solid Waste Management Act for Hall County and its municipalities; and 
3.  To work cooperatively with solid waste haulers in identifying, when possible, violating contributors of recyclable corrugated cardboard. It is not the intent of this section to act as a ban on the disposal of recyclable corrugated cardboard, but to provide incentives not to deposit this material for disposal. 
B.  Provisions for recycling corrugated cardboard and violations of this section are as follows: 
1.  In the event of contaminated loads of otherwise recyclable corrugated cardboard believed to be contaminated, a solid waste hauler may elect to have the questionable load inspected, provided the collection vehicle allows adequate inspection of the load on board the vehicle, prior to dumping, by county personnel at the Hall County recycling center. Inspection shall be available from 8:30 a.m. to 3:30 p.m., Monday through Friday, for an official determination as to a degree of contamination sufficient to render the material non-recyclable. If the load can be satisfactorily inspected and is determined to be contaminated, a report will be completed to that effect and a copy given to the hauler to accompany the load to any disposal facility in Hall County permitted to accept such material. 
2.  Disposal facility operators, permitted by state law to accept corrugated cardboard for disposal, shall provide suitable containers at their property for accepting for recycling recyclable corrugated cardboard. 
3.  It shall be considered to be a violation of this section for private disposal facility operators to accept for disposal recyclable corrugated cardboard in excess of the ten percent allowance. 
4.  In cases where violating loads are dumped at private disposal facilities, the facility operator shall notify Hall County Resource Recovery immediately, providing the time dumped and the solid waste hauler who brought in the violating load in order to avoid penalty. Disposal facility operators not adhering to these reporting and other requirements shall be subject to penalties as enumerated in section D.1 through 3 herein. 
C.  Penalties for the disposal of recyclable corrugated cardboard at the Hall County landfill and all other disposal facilities in unincorporated Hall County shall be determined as follows: 
1.  For the first violation by any given solid waste hauler, a written warning and charged the prevailing rate. 
2.  For the second and subsequent violations by any given solid waste hauler, a written warning and charged a surcharge three times the prevailing rate. 
D.  Penalties for knowingly permitting the disposal of recyclable corrugated cardboard at private disposal facilities shall be determined as follows: 
1.  The first violation as determined by inspection by county personnel: Written warning. 
2.  The second violation as determined by inspection by county personnel: Written warning and $500.00 penalty. 
3.  The third and subsequent violations as determined by inspection by county personnel: Written warning and $1,000.00 penalty. 
E.  User/tipping fees for the disposal of solid wastes at the county landfill shall be determined as follows: 
1.  All trucks, roll offs, flat beds (compacted or uncompacted), containers of solid waste or construction/demolition waste with trace amounts of recyclable corrugated cardboard or totally lacking same: Charge/surcharge is the prevailing rate. 
2.  All trucks, roll offs, flat beds (compacted or uncompacted), containers of solid waste or construction/demolition waste with ten percent or greater of recyclable corrugated cardboard: Charge/surcharge is three times prevailing rate. 
F.  The Hall County Department of Public Works shall have the right to conduct such investigations as it may reasonably deem necessary and to inspect privately owned disposal facilities at its discretion to ensure that private disposal facilities comply with the laws, ordinances, rules and regulations of Hall County and the State of Georgia. 
(Res. of 5-26-94; Code 1991, § 8.24.185) 
8.60.200. - Unlawful disposal of solid waste. 
It is unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to dump, or cause to be dumped, any solid waste anywhere in the unincorporated area of the county except as provided by this chapter, as amended from time to time, or by the express written approval of the board of commissioners under such terms and conditions as it may invoke from time to time. 
(Res. of 5-26-94; Code 1991, § 8.24.190) 
8.60.210. - Permits required prior to waste disposal at landfill. 
In addition to all other requirements of this chapter, no sanitary landfill, inert waste landfill or other landfill dump shall be used unless the owner of property used for such a purpose and the person causing the material to be dumped have first obtained all permits as may be required by the laws of the state and a permit from Hall County, Georgia. 
(Res. of 5-26-94; Code 1991, § 8.24.200) 
8.60.220. - Private landfills. 
A.  Privately owned inert waste landfills, other landfills or dumps shall meet waste reduction goals of the Hall County Comprehensive Solid Waste Management Plan. 
B.  Privately owned inert waste landfills shall be allowed in the unincorporated area of Hall County provided that all interested parties fulfill the requirements of this section, and comply with the following regulations: 
1.  Access to a privately owned inert waste landfill located on property fronting on a road which is part of the county road maintenance system shall be approved by the Hall County Department of Engineering and the board of commissioners. 
2.  The road accessing the inert waste landfill from a road which is part of the county road maintenance system shall meet class C standard requirements, as set forth in the Hall County Guidelines for County Road Acceptance. The county will not maintain said road, and the owner of an inert waste landfill shall sign an affidavit and agreement to maintain all portions of said road to meet the standards recited herein. 
3.  Access to the inert waste landfill site shall be limited to authorized entrances, which shall be closed when the site is not in operation. 
4.  The applicant for a permit to use property as a privately owned inert waste landfill shall be responsible for providing evidence that the property is properly zoned for the desired purpose and that a site acceptability permit has been issued by the State of Georgia approving the use of said property as a privately owned inert waste landfill. 
5.  The applicant shall pay a $100.00 fee with each application for a permit to use property as a privately owned inert waste landfill, said fee to be used to defray the cost of processing the application. An additional $100.00 fee per year for renewal of the permit will be required. Permit and renewal of permit approval is at the discretion of the Hall County Board of Commissioners. 
6.  The owner(s) or permit holder shall be responsible for leveling the dumped material with appropriate grading equipment and obtaining maximum practical compaction. 
7.  A uniform compacted layer of clean earth cover no less than one foot in depth shall be placed over all exposed inert waste material at least monthly. 
8.  The inert waste landfill site shall be graded and drained to minimize runoff onto the landfill surface, to prevent erosion, and to drain water from the surface of the landfill. 
9.  Appropriate means shall be provided to prevent and control fires. Stockpiled soil is considered to be the most satisfactory fire fighting material. 
10.  A uniform compacted layer of final cover not less than two feet in depth and a vegetative cover shall be placed over the final lift not later than one month following final placement of inert waste within that lift. 
11.  The applicant for a permit to use property as a privately owned inert waste landfill site must furnish site plans and operational plans showing that the facility is consistent with the waste reduction goals of the Hall County Comprehensive Solid Waste Management Plan. Such plans shall be reviewed by the Hall County Department of Engineering for compliance. Annual reporting of weights of materials accepted, origin of wastes and weights, and weights processed (diverted from disposal for reuse) shall be required. Reporting shall be on a fiscal year basis (July 1 to June 30) to Hall County Department of Engineering. 
12.  The board of commissioners or its designee shall have the right to inspect privately owned inert waste landfill at its discretion to insure that said site complies with the laws, ordinances, rules and regulations of Hall County and the State of Georgia. 
13.  Within 30 days of commencing solid waste handling activities, the operator will provide to the Hall County Department of Engineering a copy of the notice having been placed on the recorded property deed that the property will be used for landfilling operations. Upon final closure, all deeds for real property which have been used for inert waste landfilling shall include notice of the landfill operations, the date the landfill operation commenced and terminated, an accurate legal description of the actual location of the landfill, and a description of the type of solid wastes which have been deposited in the landfill. The owner or operator must submit concurrent with the submission of notice of final closure to the Hall County Department of Engineering confirmation that the information required in this section has been recorded on the property deed. 
14.  Notice of final closure must be provided to the Hall County Department of Engineering within 30 days of receiving the final load of waste. Any site not receiving waste for in excess of 180 days shall be deemed abandoned and in violation of this ordinance [chapter] unless properly closed. Notice of closure must include the date of final waste receipt and an accurate legal description of the boundaries of the landfill. 
15.  There shall be no less than two public hearings in regular meetings of the Hall County board of commissioners to consider whether or not to issue a permit for the operation of a privately owned inert waste landfill. The applicant shall be responsible for providing evidence of notice of a public hearing of said matter. Said notice shall state the dates, times and locations of the hearings, must be published in a local newspaper of general circulation at least 15 days in advance of the first such hearing and must be posted on the property as required by the Hall County Planning Department. 
C.  No person, firm or corporation shall willfully empty, dump or otherwise place any solid waste, garbage, dead animals, other discarded materials or refuse upon the right-of-way of any public road, state highway, state aid road or public property, or upon the lands of another. 
(Res. of 5-26-94; Code 1991, § 8.24.210) 
Cross reference— Zoning regulations, tit. 17. 
8.60.230. - Identification of illegally dumped solid waste. 
If any of the matter or material dumped in violation of the provisions of section 8.60.200 can be identified as having last belonged to, been in the possession of, sent to or received by, or to have been the property of any person, firm, or corporation prior to its being dumped as prohibited herein, this identification shall be presumed to be prima facie evidence that the owner dumped, or caused to be dumped, this matter and material in violation of this chapter. 
(Res. of 5-26-94; Code 1991, § 8.24.220) 
8.60.240. - Operating hours of county landfill. 
Solid waste can only be deposited at the sanitary landfill under the supervision of the solid waste director during normal working hours, except by specific written permission of the county administrator. Normal working hours shall be as designated from time to time by the board of commissioners. The sanitary landfill is closed on Sunday and county holidays. At all other times access to the sanitary landfill is prohibited, and a gate at the entrance shall be kept locked. 
(Res. of 5-26-94; Code 1991, § 8.24.230) 
8.60.250. - Sanitary landfill; operation regulations. 
The sanitary landfill shall be operated in a safe and sanitary manner, and shall conform with all appropriate state and federal laws and regulations. Included among these regulations and requirements are the following: 
A.  All solid waste shall be compacted and covered with a minimum of six inches of clean soil or state approved alternative daily cover at the end of each day of operation; 
B.  No burning of waste is permitted; 
C.  When each portion of the sanitary landfill reaches its final grade, two feet of final cover will be placed on top of the lift, graded to drain and minimize erosion, and seeded to establish a stable vegetative cover. 
(Res. of 5-26-94; Code 1991, § 8.24.240) 
8.60.260. - Sanitary landfill; control of noise, odor and vermin. 
The sanitary landfill will be operated in a professional manner with due regard for controlling litter, noise, odor and vermin. The solid waste delivered to the sanitary landfill shall only be deposited at a location on the working face of the landfill operation under the direction of a county employee. In accordance with county ordinances and resolutions, no waste shall be deposited at the entrance or along the access road to the site. As necessary, a fence shall be erected at the site to limit access and to trap blowing litter. The entrance access road, and public rights-of-way leading to the site, shall be policed as necessary to control all litter which would give the landfill an unsightly appearance. 
(Res. of 5-26-94; Code 1991, § 8.24.250) 
8.60.270. - Sanitary landfill; sorting of materials. 
It will be the responsibility of the solid waste director to designate areas in which heavy scrap metals such as steel, iron, aluminum, etc., can be placed in an area in which the private individuals, firms or corporations, as well as the county, may deposit this these materials. These areas are to be clearly defined and clearly marked, and it will be under the general supervision of the landfill personnel. It will be the responsibility of the sanitary contractor or private individual, firm or corporation to separate materials reclaimable by the county. Failure to comply with this regulation will be deemed a violation of this chapter. 
(Res. of 5-26-94; Code 1991, § 8.24.260) 
8.60.280. - Sanitary landfill; fees. 
The solid waste director will be responsible for posting landfill fees at the direction of the board of commissioners and the county administrator. All persons, haulers, sanitary contractors, firms, or corporations, will be charged on a fee basis to be determined by the board of commissioners of the county. The fee shall be paid on-site, or the person, hauler, sanitary contractor, firm, or corporation may be billed on a monthly basis if an account has been established with the county in accordance with procedures established by the Hall County Comptroller with the approval of the Hall County Commission. The fee for the dumping of rubbish, garbage and other solid waste shall be as established by the board of commissioners from time to time. In lieu of point-of-purchase disposal fees collected by the county for designated wastes requiring special handling, the county shall levy fees at the point of disposal necessary to recover the true cost of disposal. Such wastes shall include but not be limited to tires, CFC/HCFC (chlorofluorocarbon/hydro- chlorofluorocarbon) containing appliances and other wastes as designated by the board of commissioners from time to time. 
(Res. of 5-26-94; Code 1991, § 8.24.270) 
8.60.290. - Solid waste compactor sites. 
A.  The purpose of special districts within the geographical boundaries of Hall County, Georgia, which special districts correspond with the geographical boundaries of Hall County, Georgia, shall be to provide for solid waste collection and disposal as effected through compactor site operations and such districts shall specifically be composed of all parcels or tracts of residential real property within Hall County, Georgia, upon which improvements have been made for the purpose of single- or multifamily dwellings, including but not limited to manufactured home parks, apartment complexes, condominiums, duplexes and single home subdivisions. Each separate residence within this special district shall be assessed an annual fee as established by the board of commissioners from time to time. Such fee shall be assessed residences located within the unincorporated portion of Hall County, Georgia, which does not provide garbage and solid waste collection services, and no fee shall be assessed if such dwelling is located within the municipal boundaries of any municipality within Hall County, Georgia, which provides a garbage and solid waste collection service. 
B.  The assessment shall be made by inclusion as a separate item with the ad valorem tax bill as sent to each Hall County residential owner annually and shall be due and payable upon or before the same date designated for the payment of ad valorem taxes therein. In the case of manufactured home owners who do not receive ad valorem tax bills due to the fact that their manufactured homes are not taxed as real property, the assessment shall be paid and collected at the time of the purchase or renewal of the manufactured home owner's annual location permit. 
C.  Hall County, Georgia, is further authorized to enforce the collection of such fees or assessments that become delinquent and unpaid in the same manner as authorized by Chapter 3 of Title 48 of the Official Code of Georgia and O.C.G.A. § 48-2-44, or other applicable law, for the enforcement of the collection and payment of taxes, fees or assessments. 
D.  The proceeds of the assessment provided for herein shall be used only to defray the cost of maintaining and operating the solid waste compactor sites located in Hall County, Georgia; provided, however, that such fees and assessments may be used to defray the cost of other solid waste disposal services operated by Hall County, Georgia, to the extent not required to meet the abovencompactor site management and operational needs. 
E.  The following provisions shall govern the use of the sites: 
1.  The sites may be used only by private individuals; residents or property owners in the county may deposit household garbage and/or recyclables at these sites. Non-residents of Hall County may deposit only recyclables. 
2.  Only household garbage and/or recyclables may be deposited at these collection sites. 
3.  All household garbage and/or recyclables shall be placed inside the containers. 
4.  Any person, firm or corporation engaged in the business of hauling household garbage for a charge of any kind shall not place the household garbage or recyclables in the containers. 
5.  No person, firm or corporation, other than authorized personnel of the county, shall scavenge or sort the contents of the containers or remove anything from the containers or from around the containers. 
6.  No person, firm or corporation shall set fire to the contents of any container or place highly inflammable liquids in the containers. 
7.  All household garbage deposited at these sites must be contained in sturdy paper or plastic, disposable bags (including, but not limited to, paper grocery bags, empty consumer product bags, or household trash compactor bags) no larger than 39-gallon capacity size. Animal feed bags may also be deposited. Any bags used for household garbage must be securely closed. All garbage contained in the bags shall be placed inside the containers provided by the county at the collection sites. No loose garbage will be accepted. 
8.  Persons, firms, or corporations who need to dispose of solid waste that is not household garbage must transport the solid waste to the county landfill. 
9.  Businesses wishing to deposit recyclables shall be directed to transport them to the county's recycling center. All residents (unincorporated or within municipal jurisdictions) and nonresidents may use this facility andthe recycling containers available at the site. 
(Res. of 3-26-09(2), § 1(Exh. A); Res. of 01-11-2018(1), § 1(Exh. A)) 
Editor's note— Res. of Mar. 26, 2009(2), deleted former § 8.60.290, and enacted a new § 8.60.290 as set out herein. The former § 8.60.290 pertained to similar subject matter. See the Code Comparative Table for complete derivation. 
8.60.300. - Forbidden deposits and prohibited actions at county disposal sites; deposit or storage of junk. 
A.  None of the following shall be deposited or dumped at the sanitary landfill or at any county solid waste compactor site: 
1.  Waste originating outside of Hall County; 
2.  Liquid waste, except used motor oil for recovery; 
3.  Regulated quantities of hazardous waste as defined in the rules promulgated by the board of natural resources, chapter 391-3-11; 
4.  Septic tank pumpings and sewage; 
5.  Tires; 
6.  Yard trimmings; 
7.  Sludges which, upon certified laboratory testing, meet the definition of hazardous waste as defined herein. Industrial and commercial generators wishing to dispose of sludges in Hall County solid waste handling facilities shall first furnish test results, due annually January 1 of each year, certifying that such sludges are deemed non-hazardous. 
B.  It shall be unlawful to place, abandon, leave, keep or store junk and salvage material, including non-functioning motor vehicles, appliances, machinery, equipment or parts thereof, out of doors upon any public or private land, except within the confines of a permitted junk or salvage yard or designated public disposal area. All such materials shall be stored in such manner that will preclude the harborage of rodents and insects. 
(Res. of 5-26-94; Code 1991, § 8.24.290) 
Cross reference— Storage of junk, § 8.140.020; zoning regulations, tit. 17; screening, fencing and outdoor storage requirements, ch. 17.260; screening of junk yards, § 17.260.030. 
8.60.310. - Landfill pilfering. 
A.  Prohibition. No person shall pilfer, steal, or take any item which has been discarded and placed in the public landfill of the county. An exemption to this shall be provided to any items, which, in the opinion of the solid waste director, have obvious reuse potential. Such items shall be diverted from disposal by county personnel if such is safe and practical to do so. It shall be unlawful for any county employee to personally benefit from the recovery of any such diverted materials. 
B.  Enforcement. The enforcement officers of the public safety department, enforcement division, of the county or any duly authorized law enforcement officer shall have the duty to arrest and cite any violator of this section. 
C.  Judicial disposition. The magistrate's court of the county shall have jurisdiction over all alleged violations of this section. The prosecuting officer shall give proper citation to all alleged violators of this section to appear before and have disposition of the alleged violation before the magistrate's court of the county in the manner provided by law. 
(Res. of 5-26-94; Code 1991, § 8.24.300) 
8.60.320. - Enforcement; violations; penalty. 
A.  All law enforcement agencies, officers, and officials of the state or any political subdivision thereof, including enforcement officers of the public safety department, enforcement division, or any enforcement agency, officer, or any official of any commission of the state or any political subdivision thereof, are authorized, empowered and directed to enforce compliance with this chapter. 
B.  In the event that any person, firm, or corporation violates any provisions of this chapter, the county attorney or other appropriate authority of the county may, in addition to other remedies, institute injunction, mandamus, or other appropriate action or proceeding to prevent such unlawful act or to correct or abate such violation. 
C.  Any person, firm, corporation, association or partnership violating any provision of this chapter as the same exists or as it may hereinafter be amended, or shall fail to do anything required by this chapter as the same exists or as it may hereafter be amended, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, amenable to the process of the Magistrate or State Court of Hall County, and upon conviction, shall be punished as provided in the Official Code of Hall County, Georgia section 1.50.020 for each violation in the discretion of the court. 
(Res. of 5-26-94; Code 1991, § 8.24.310; Res. of 6-10-04(1), § 1) 
CHAPTER 8.65. - SCRAP TIRE MANAGEMENT 

 

8.65.010. - Purpose. 
The purpose of this chapter is to protect and enhance the quality of the environment of Hall County, Georgia, to revise and update existing laws, and to institute and maintain a comprehensive county-wide program for all scrap tire management which will assure that the storage, transportation, collection, processing and disposal of scrap tires does not adversely affect the health, safety, and well-being of the public and does not degrade the quality of the environment in furtherance of Hall County's responsibility to protect the public health, safety, and well being of its citizens. 
(Res. of 6-10-04(3), § 1) 
8.65.020. - Definitions. 
The following definitions shall apply in the interpretation and enforcement of this chapter, unless otherwise specifically stated: 
Dump means to throw, discard, place, deposit, discharge, bury, burn, or dispose of a substance. 
Manifest means a form or document used for identifying the quantity and composition and the origin, routing, and destination of scrap tires during transportation from the point of generation, through any intermediate points, to an end user, processor or disposer approved by the Georgia Environmental Protection Division (EPD). 
Person means the State of Georgia or any other state or agency or institution thereof, and any municipality, county, political subdivision, public or private corporation, solid waste authority, special district empowered to engage in solid waste management activities, individual, partnership, association, or other entity in Georgia or any other state. This term also includes any officer or governing or managing body of any municipality, political subdivision, solid waste authority, special district empowered to engage in solid waste activities, or public or private corporation in Georgia or any other state. This term also includes employees, departments, and agencies of the federal government. 
Retail tire dealer means a person actively engaged in the business of selling new replacement tires. 
Scrap tire means a tire that is no longer suitable for its original intended purpose because of wear, damage, or defect. 
Scrap tire carrier means any person engaged in picking up or transporting scrap tires not otherwise exempted in the Georgia Rules for Solid Waste Management for the purpose of removal to a scrap tire processor, end user, or disposal facility. 
Scrap tire generator means any person who generates scrap tires. Generators may include, but are not limited to, retail tire dealers, retreaders, scrap tire processors, automobile dealers, private company vehicle maintenance shops, garages, service stations, and city, county, and state governments. 
Scrap tire processor means any person who is approved by the environmental protection division to receive scrap tires from scrap tire generators or scrap tire carriers for the purpose of scrap tire processing. 
Scrap tire sorter means any person, other than the original scrap tire generator, who handles mixed tires by separating used tires and retreadable casings from scrap tires. 
(Res. of 6-10-04(3), § 1) 
8.65.030. - Property owner's responsibility. 
The owner or occupant of any premises shall be responsible for the sanitary handling and disposal of all scrap tires on the premises used or occupied by such person. 
(Res. of 6-10-04(3), § 1) 
8.65.040. - Disposal of scrap tires. 
A.  It shall be unlawful to cause, suffer or allow the dumping of scrap tires at any place in Hall County including, and without limitations, in or on any public highway, road, street, alley, or thoroughfare, including any portion of the right of way thereof, any public or private property in the county or any waters in Hall County unless such scrap tires originate in Hall County or other areas authorized by the Hall County Board of Commissioners and: 
1.  The property is designated by the board of commissioners or its duly designated agent and the Georgia Environmental Protection Division for the collection or disposal of scrap tires and the person is authorized to use such property; 
2.  The scrap tires are placed into a receptacle or container installed specifically for such property; and 
3.  The property has a valid solid waste handling permit or other applicable identification numbers, approvals and/or permits issued by the Georgia Environmental Protection Division (EPD) when required. 
B.  All persons defined as scrap tire generators, scrap tire carriers, scrap tire processors, including scrap tire sorters, and retail tire dealers shall be subject to rules as defined in Chapter 391-3-4, et seq. of the Georgia Rules for Solid Waste Management and handle scrap tires in accordance with the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 12-8-20 et seq. and the Georgia Rules for Solid Waste Management, Chapter 391-3-4, et seq. applicable to solid waste, except where requirements of this ordinance are more stringent. 
(Res. of 6-10-04(3), § 1) 
8.65.050. - Scrap tire accumulation and storage. 
A.  It shall be unlawful for any person in a residential zone to accumulate any amount of scrap tires on or around property, which they own or occupy. 
B.  A retail tire dealer may hold up to 100 scrap tires per garage bay in storage, up to a maximum of 1,000 scrap tires. 
C.  Tires must be stored in covered or enclosed areas to prevent the accumulation of water. 
(Res. of 6-10-04(3), § 1) 
8.65.060. - Scrap tire disposal certification. 
A.  A scrap tire disposal certification form shall be completed: 
1.  By any scrap tire generator each time that solid waste is transported to a solid waste disposal facility, 
2.  By any solid waste disposal facility each time any scrap tires are delivered, or 
3.  At the request of any officer empowered to enforce this chapter. 
B.  Said scrap tire disposal certification forms shall be maintained and made available for inspection by any scrap tire generator or solid waste disposal facility upon the request of any officer empowered to enforce this chapter. 
C.  Each scrap tire generator shall at least supply their full name, mailing address including city and state, street address including city and state, phone number, name of entity for which scrap tires are destined, street address including city and state of entity for which scrap tires are destined, the county of generation of the scrap tires as well as a signature of a legally authorized representative for the scrap tire generator on the scrap tire disposal certification form. Other information as may be specified by an authorized representative of Hall County may also be required on the scrap tire disposal certification form. 
D.  Each solid waste disposal facility shall at least supply their full name, mailing address including city and state, street address including city and state, phone number, name of entity from which scrap tires were received, street address including city and state of entity from which scrap tires are received, the county of generation of the scrap tires as well as a signature of a legally authorized representative for the solid waste disposal facility on the scrap tire disposal certification form. Other information as may be specified by an authorized representative of Hall County may also be required on the scrap tire disposal certification form. 
(Res. of 6-10-04(3), § 1) 
8.65.070. - Abatement and expenses recovery. 
A.  In the event that any person violates any provision of this ordinance, the county or other appropriate authority may, in addition to other remedies, institute an action for injunction, cleanup or stop-work orders, mandamus, irreversible damage fines, lien on property or other appropriate action or proceeding to prevent such unlawful acts or to correct or abate any such violation. In addition, the county may immediately revoke or suspend any and all business, building, development or any and all other county issued permits related to the property or properties involved with the violation until such time that compliance is met, or until the ruling of a court of competent jurisdiction is obtained, at which time respective permits may be reissued. 
B.  Upon failure, neglect or refusal of any person so notified to properly address any violation of this chapter on their premises within 20 days after receipt of notice to correct said violation, the board of commissioners is hereby authorized and empowered to cause the cleanup, removal or disposal of scrap tires, dumped, deposited, thrown, or left on public or private property in violation of the ordinance on behalf of the county. The expenses incurred by the county shall be chargeable to the violator and the board of commissioners and/or the court shall send a statement of the amount due for said expenses by registered mail. 
C.  When the full amount of such charges are not paid by the violator within 30 days after receipt of said statement as provided for in this section, the board of commissioners shall cause to be recorded in the execution docket a sworn statement showing the cost and expense incurred by the county, the dates of county action, the location of the property for which action was taken, and the name of the person to be charged for the expenses incurred. The recordation of such statement shall constitute a lien on the personal and real property of the person to be charged and shall remain in full force and effect until final payment is received in full, including accrued interest from the date of recording and any and all costs. Such amount as shall constitute final payment shall be subject to collection in the manner fixed by law for the collection of taxes. 
D.  This section shall apply with full force and effect regardless of the provisions of any order of the court in which the violator was convicted. This section should not be construed as an excuse for failure on the part of the violator to perform any cleanup ordered by the court, nor shall it be considered as a mitigating factor in any contempt action against a violator who has failed to obey the order of the court. 
(Res. of 6-10-04(3), § 1) 
8.65.080. - Enforcement. 
A.  All law enforcement agencies, officers, and officials of the state or any political subdivision thereof, including the enforcement division, any environmental compliance officer, the Hall County Sheriff's Office or any enforcement agency, officer, or any official of any commission of the state or any political subdivision thereof, are authorized, empowered and directed to enforce compliance with this chapter. 
B.  Any person authorized to enforce this ordinance shall be empowered to enter any property, upon reasonable cause, at reasonable or necessary times in order to properly inspect for violations of this ordinance, subject to the condition that to allow entry onto private property for inspection, the alleged violation of this ordinance must be visible from a public road or right of way, or upon said person having received a valid complaint alleging a violation of this ordinance, or by a judge's order upon said person having received information/allegations that constitute reasonable suspicion that an unlawful act or threat to the health and safety of the community and/or the environment has occurred or is about to occur. 
(Res. of 6-10-04(3), § 1) 
8.65.090. - Violations and penalties. 
Any person, firm, corporation, association or partnership violating any provision of this chapter as the same exists or as it may hereinafter be amended, or shall fail to do anything required by this chapter as the same exists or as it may hereafter be amended, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, amenable to the process of the Magistrate or State Court of Hall County, and upon conviction, shall be punished as provided in the Official Code of Hall County, Georgia section 1.50.020 for each violation in the discretion of the court. Each day the violation continues shall constitute a separate offense. This section shall not preclude the county from choosing to seek civil redress in a court of competent jurisdiction in addition to the criminal prosecution, it being the intent of the county to have both the civil and criminal rights of prosecution in this area. 
(Res. of 6-10-04(3), § 1) 
CHAPTER 8.70. - INCINERATION OF SOLID WASTE AND BIOMEDICAL WASTE[9] 

 

Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
Cross reference— Business licenses and regulations, tit. 5; hazardous waste, ch. 8.50; solid waste generally, ch. 8.60; bonfires and rubbish fires, ch. 8.110. 

8.70.010. - Title. 
This chapter shall be known as the "Hall County Solid Waste Incinerator Ordinance." 
(Res. of 8-27-90, § 1; Code 1991, § 8.25.010) 
8.70.020. - Purpose. 
The purpose of this chapter is to: 
A.  Regulate the importation of solid waste into Hall County, Georgia, for disposal purposes in a manner so as to protect the public health, safety and welfare and to preserve the environmental resources of the county and to conserve the county landfill capabilities. 
B.  Regulate the location, operation and management of incineration facilities dealing with the storage, transfer, treatment or disposal of waste where the total incinerator capacity is greater than 250 pounds per hour. 
C.  Regulate the disposal of biomedical wastes which require special handling in order to protect the public health, safety and welfare of the citizens of Hall County. 
(Res. of 8-27-90, § 2; Code 1991, § 8.25.020) 
8.70.030. - Definitions. 
As used herein, the following definitions shall apply: 
(1)  Principal use incinerator facility is an incinerator or incinerators at a single location where the incineration process is the primary business and where the facility has the total capacity of burning greater than 250 pounds per hour. 
(2)  Biomedical waste shall mean and include the following: 
(a)  Pathological waste, which means all recognizable human tissues and body parts which are removed during surgery, obstetrical procedures, autopsy, and laboratory procedures. 
(b)  Biological waste, which means bulk blood and blood products, exudates, secretions, suctionings, and other bulk body fluids which cannot or are not directly discarded into a municipal sewer system. 
(c)  Cultures and stocks of infectious agents and associated biologicals, including cultures from medical and pathological laboratories, cultures and stocks of infectious agents from research and industrial laboratories, wastes from the production of biologicals, discarded live and attenuated vaccines, and culture dishes and devices used to transfer, inoculate, and mix cultures. 
(d)  Contaminated animal carcasses, body parts, their bedding, and other wastes from such animals which have been exposed to infectious agents, capable of causing disease in man, during research, production of biologicals, or testing of pharmaceuticals. 
(e)  Sharps, which means any discarded article which may cause punctures or cuts. Such waste includes, but is not limited to, items such as needles, IV tubing and syringes and needles attached, and scalpel blades. 
(f)  Chemotherapy waste, which means any disposable material which has come in contact with cytotoxic/antineoplastic agents (agents toxic to cells) and/or antineoplastic agents (agents that inhibit or prevent the growth and spread of tumors or malignant cells) during the preparation, handling, and administration of such agents. Such waste includes, but is not limited to, masks, gloves, gowns, empty IV tubing bags and vials, and other contaminated materials. The above waste must first be classified as empty, which means such quantity that it is not subject to other federal or state waste management regulations prior to being handled as biomedical waste. 
(g)  Discarded medical equipment and parts, not including expendable supplies and materials which have not been decontaminated, that were in contact with infectious agents. 
(3)  Incineration shall mean a controlled process by which solid, liquid and gaseous combustible wastes are burned and changed into gases and a residue produced which is relatively free of combustible materials. 
(4)  Incinerator shall mean all devices intended or used for the reduction or destruction of solid, liquid or gaseous wastes by burning. 
(5)  Incineration facility shall mean the combined incinerators under one ownership at a single location. 
(6)  Operator shall mean the person having direct supervision of daily field operations of an incineration facility to insure that the site operates in compliance with the permit. 
(7)  County commission shall mean the Hall County Board of Commissioners. 
(8)  Environmental quality board (EQB) shall mean a board of five citizens appointed by the Hall County Board of Commissioners to assist in the administration of this chapter. 
(9)  Uncontrolled emissions of dioxins shall mean the dioxins emissions measured from the incinerator at a location downstream of the last combustion chamber, but prior to the air pollution control equipment. 
(10)  Person shall mean the State of Georgia or any other state, or any agency or institution thereof, and any municipality, political subdivision, public or private corporation, special district empowered to engage in solid waste management activities, individual, partnership, association or other entity in Georgia or any other state. The term also includes any officer or governing or managing body of any municipality, political subdivision, special district empowered in solid waste activities, or public or private corporation in Georgia or any other state. This term also includes employees, departments, and agencies of the federal government. 
(11)  Incinerator ash shall mean the residue remaining after the incineration of solid waste. 
(Res. of 8-27-90, § 3; Code 1991, § 8.25.030) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1.20.010 et seq. 
8.70.040. - Permits required. 
A.  Owners and operators of incinerators shall be permitted as required by the rules and regulations of the Georgia Department of Natural Resources. Any violation of the conditions of the Georgia Department of Natural Resources permit shall also be a violation of the conditions of any Hall County permit. 
B.  No person [shall] engage in the operation of a principal use incinerator and no person shall construct or operate a principal use incineration facility without having a permit issued by the Hall County Board of Commissioners pursuant to these regulations. 
C.  No person shall operate a biomedical waste incinerator or shall construct or operate a principal use medical waste incineration facility without having a valid principal use biomedical incinerator permit issued by the Hall County Board of Commissioners pursuant to these regulations. 
(Res. of 8-27-90, § 4; Code 1991, § 8.25.040) 
8.70.050. - Contents of permit application. 
A permit applicant shall prepare and file an incineration permit [application] with the Hall County Board of Commissioners. The permit application shall include all related documents submitted to the United States government and to the State of Georgia. 
A.  An application shall contain the following information: 
1.  A description of the company, information on its financial capability, and a detailed history of all its past activities in the field of incineration, including a synopsis of every other facility it has operated, and including a detailed account of all past and pending litigation, favorable and unfavorable. Include the record of any subsidiary or parent corporation having an interest greater than five percent of the outstanding shares of the applicant corporation. Also include a list of all past and present litigation, favorable and unfavorable, the subsidiary or parent corporation has been involved in.
