CHAPTER 10.40. - STOP INTERSECTIONS 

 

10.40.010. - Kenimer Road and Ransom Free Road. 
A.  The intersection of Kenimer Road and Ransom Free Road shall be a four-way stop with traffic from each direction coming to a complete stop before proceeding through the intersection. 
B.  The county engineer shall direct and place additional stop signs at the intersection in order to accomplish the purpose of this section. 
C.  Motorists who violate this section will be subject to the same penalties as exist for violations of other county resolutions. 
(Res. of 8-11-86, §§ 1—3; Code 1991, § 10.16.010) 
10.40.020. - Nancy Creek Road and Turtle Back Road/Ed Dodd Trail. 
A.  The intersection of Nancy Creek Road and Turtle Back Road/Ed Dodd Trail shall be a four-way stop with traffic from each direction coming to a complete stop before proceeding through the intersection. 
B.  The county traffic engineer shall direct and place additional stop signs at said intersection in order to accomplish the purpose of this resolution [section]. 
C.  Motorists who violate this resolution [section] will be subject to the same penalties as exist for violations of other county resolutions. 
(Res. of 8-11-94; Code 1991, § 10.16.011) 
10.40.030. - McEver Road and Gaines Ferry Road. 
A.  The intersection of McEver Road and Gaines Ferry Road shall be a signalized intersection with traffic being controlled by said signal. 
B.  The traffic engineering division of the Hall County Public Works Department shall install, operate and maintain the traffic signal at said intersection in order to accomplish the purposes of this section. 
C.  Motorists who violate this resolution [section] will be subject to the same penalties as exist for violations of other county resolutions. 
(Res. of 9-22-94; Code 1991, § 10.16.012) 
10.40.040. - McEver Road and Stephens Road. 
A.  The intersection of McEver Road and Stephens Road shall be a signalized intersection with traffic being controlled by said signal. 
B.  The traffic engineering division of the Hall County Public Works Department shall install, operate and maintain the traffic signal at said intersection in order to accomplish the purposes of this section. 
C.  Motorists who violate this resolution [section] will be subject to the same penalties as exist for violations of other county resolutions. 
(Res. of 9-22-94; Code 1991, § 10.16.013) 
10.40.050—10.40.190. - Reserved. 
10.40.200. - Violations; penalty. 
Any person, firm, corporation, association or partnership violating any provision of this chapter as the same exists or as it may hereinafter be amended, or shall fail to do anything required by this chapter as the same exists or as it may hereafter be amended, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, amenable to the process of the Magistrate or State Court of Hall County, and upon conviction, shall be punished as provided in the Official Code of Hall County, Georgia section 1.50.020 for each violation in the discretion of the court. 
(Res. of 6-10-04(1), § 1) 
CHAPTER 10.50. - BRIDGES 

 

10.50.010. - Jumping off bridges prohibited. 
No person shall voluntarily jump off, dive off, leap off, fall off, swing off, flip off or in any manner leave the structure of any public bridge within the county, except in a manner otherwise expressly allowed by law. 
(Res. of 8-13-85, § 1; Code 1991, § 10.20.010) 
Cross reference— Health and safety, tit. 8. 
10.50.020. - Enforcement. 
The county marshal of the county and any duly authorized law enforcement officer shall have the duty to arrest and cite any violator of this chapter. 
(Res. of 8-13-85, § 2; Code 1991, § 10.20.020) 
10.50.030. - Judicial disposition. 
The magistrate's court of the county shall have jurisdiction over all alleged violations of this chapter. The prosecuting officer shall give proper citation to all alleged violators of this chapter to appear before and have disposition of the alleged violation before the magistrate's court of the county in the manner provided by law. 
(Res. of 8-13-85, § 3; Code 1991, § 10.20.030) 
10.50.040. - Exceptions. 
No violation of this resolution [chapter] will be held to have occurred when a person involuntarily leaves the structure of a public bridge in the county, or leaves the structure in order to protect the health, safety or welfare of that person or anyone else. 
(Res. of 8-13-85, § 5; Code 1991, § 10.20.040) 
10.50.050. - Violations; penalty. 
Any person, firm, corporation, association or partnership violating any provision of this chapter as the same exists or as it may hereinafter be amended, or shall fail to do anything required by this chapter as the same exists or as it may hereafter be amended, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, amenable to the process of the Magistrate or State Court of Hall County, and upon conviction, shall be punished as provided in the Official Code of Hall County, Georgia section 1.50.020 for each violation in the discretion of the court. 
(Res. of 8-13-85, § 4; Code 1991, § 10.20.050; Res. of 6-10-04(1), § 1) 
CHAPTER 10.60. - PARKING ON COUNTY PROPERTY[2] 

 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— County parking deck, ch. 10.90. 

10.60.010. - Prohibited parking. 
Except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic, or in compliance with law or directions of a law enforcement officer or official traffic control device, no person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle: 
A.  On a sidewalk; 
B.  Within an intersection; 
C.  On a designated crosswalk; 
D.  At any place where official signs prohibit stopping or parking; 
E.  In any designated parking space for a time period in excess of the time period posted on the official sign marking the parking space, which time period may not be restricted to less than 15 minutes; 
F.  In any designated parking space when the person is not transacting business in the county courthouse or its annex or serving as a juror or witness in the courthouse; 
G.  In any parking space which is designated by an official sign for the use of county officials, employees or jurors, unless they qualify as a designated party for the space. 
(Res. of 2-27-78, § 1; Code 1991, § 10.24.010) 
10.60.020. - Enforcement. 
The sheriff of the county and his deputies, and such other persons as shall be designated by the board of commissioners of the county, shall enforce the provisions of this chapter. 
(Res. of 2-27-78, § 2; Code 1991, § 10.24.020) 
10.60.030. - Towing of vehicles. 
Any vehicle that is left unattended and in violation of the provisions of section 10.60.010 of this resolution [chapter] may be removed to the area maintained by the sheriff of the county for abandoned vehicles or such other area as may be designated by the board of commissioners of the county. The owner of such vehicles or such other person or persons as shall lawfully reclaim such vehicles shall pay to the county the cost of removing the vehicle and a storage fee of $3.00 per day for each day the vehicle was stored by the county, before the vehicle may be reclaimed. 
(Res. of 2-27-78, § 3; Code 1991, § 10.24.030) 
10.60.040. - Violations; penalty. 
Any person, firm, corporation, association or partnership violating any provision of this chapter as the same exists or as it may hereinafter be amended, or shall fail to do anything required by this chapter as the same exists or as it may hereafter be amended, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, amenable to the process of the Magistrate or State Court of Hall County, and upon conviction, shall be punished as provided in the Official Code of Hall County, Georgia section 1.50.020 for each violation in the discretion of the court. 
(Res. of 2-27-78, § 3; Code 1991, § 10.24.040; Res. of 6-10-04(1), § 1) 
CHAPTER 10.70. - PARKING ON PUBLIC RIGHT-OF-WAY 

 

10.70.010. - Prohibited parking. 
Except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic, or in compliance with law or directions of a law enforcement officer or official traffic control device, no person shall stop, stand, or park a vehicle in or along any public road right-of-way which has been designated by the board of commissioners of the county as a no parking area pursuant to the provisions of this chapter. 
(Res. of 4-28-86, § 1; Code 1991, § 10.28.010) 
10.70.020. - Enforcement. 
The sheriff of the county and his deputies, the county marshals, and such other persons as shall be designated by the board of commissioners of the county shall enforce the provisions of this chapter. 
(Res. of 4-28-86, § 2; Code 1991, § 10.28.020) 
10.70.030. - Towing of vehicles. 
Any vehicle that is left unattended and in violation of the provisions of section 10.70.010 of this chapter may be removed to the area maintained by the sheriff of the county for abandoned vehicles or such other area as may be designated by the board of commissioners of the county. The owner of such vehicle or such other person or persons as shall lawfully reclaim the vehicle shall pay to the county the cost of removing the vehicle and a storage fee of $3.00 per day for each day the vehicle was stored by the county, before the vehicle may be reclaimed. 
(Res. of 4-28-86, § 3; Code 1991, § 10.28.030) 
10.70.040. - Violations; penalty. 
Any person, firm, corporation, association or partnership violating any provision of this chapter as the same exists or as it may hereinafter be amended, or shall fail to do anything required by this chapter as the same exists or as it may hereafter be amended, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, amenable to the process of the Magistrate or State Court of Hall County, and upon conviction, shall be punished as provided in the Official Code of Hall County, Georgia section 1.50.020 for each violation in the discretion of the court. 
(Res. of 4-28-86, § 4; Code 1991, § 10.28.040; Res. of 6-10-04(1), § 1)

CHAPTER 10.90. - COUNTY PARKING DECK[3] 

 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference— Parking on county property, ch. 10.60. 

10.90.010. - Prohibited parking. 
Except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic, or in compliance with directions of a law enforcement officer or official traffic control device, no person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle: 
A.  In any aisle or driveway outside marked parking spaces; 
B.  Within an intersection connecting parking levels; 
C.  On a designated crosswalk; 
D.  At any place where official signs prohibit stopping or parking; 
E.  In any parking space which is designated by an official sign for the use of county government officials, employees, jurors, or U.S. government employees unless they qualify as a designated party for the space. 
(Res. of 8-28-89, § 1; Code 1991, § 10.36.010) 
10.90.020. - Towing of vehicles. 
Any vehicle that is left unattended or in violation of the provisions of section 10.90.010 of this chapter may be removed to the area maintained by the sheriff of the county for abandoned vehicles, or such other area as may be designated by the board of commissioners of the county. The owner of such vehicle or such other person or persons as shall lawfully reclaim the vehicle shall pay to the county the cost of removing the vehicle and a storage of $3.00 per day for each day the vehicle was stored by the county before the vehicle may be reclaimed. 
(Res. of 8-28-89, § 2; Code 1991, § 10.36.020) 
10.90.030. - Enforcement. 
The sheriff of the county and his deputies, the county marshals and such other persons as shall be designated by the board of commissioners of the county shall enforce the provisions of this chapter. 
(Res. of 8-28-89, § 4; Code 1991, § 10.36.030) 
10.90.040. - Violations; penalty. 
Any person, firm, corporation, association or partnership violating any provision of this chapter as the same exists or as it may hereinafter be amended, or shall fail to do anything required by this chapter as the same exists or as it may hereafter be amended, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, amenable to the process of the Magistrate or State Court of Hall County, and upon conviction, shall be punished as provided in the Official Code of Hall County, Georgia section 1.50.020 for each violation in the discretion of the court. 
(Res. of 8-28-89, § 3; Code 1991, § 10.36.040; Res. of 6-10-04(1), § 1)

Footnotes:

CHAPTER 12.10. - HOUSE NUMBERING SYSTEM[2] 

 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Buildings and construction, tit. 15. 

12.10.010. - Title. 
This chapter shall be further referred to as the "Structure Numbering Resolution." 
(Res. of 3-11-85, art. I; Code 1991, § 12.02.010) 
12.10.020. - Designation of street names and numbers. 
Streets now being maintained by the Hall County Board of Commissioners and other public agencies within unincorporated Hall County shall in the future be named and numbered as now designated on the official map and official index of the board of commissioners as amended by each implementing resolution. Every other street within unincorporated Hall County shown on the official index shall hereafter be referred to as designated on the official index for structure numbering purposes. 
(Res. of 3-11-85, art. II; Code 1991, § 12.02.020) 
12.10.030. - Designation of structure numbers. 
Structure numbers for dwelling units, places of business, industrial locations and all other structures and uses requiring same shall be assigned by: 
A.  The department of special services in conjunction with the United States Postal Service during the implementation stage of the system. 
B.  The planning and zoning department following the implementation phase of the system in each area of the unincorporated area of the county. 
C.  The planning and zoning department shall keep a record of all numbers assigned under this chapter. Such records may be maintained in data processing storage systems if so desired. 
(Res. of 3-11-85, art. III; Code 1991, § 12.02.030) 
12.10.040. - Posting of designated structure numbers. 
A.  The owner or occupant or person in charge of any dwelling unit, structure or use to which a number has been assigned shall be notified in writing by the implementing agency of the number assigned to the same. 
B.  Within 60 days after receipt of such written notification, the owner, occupant or person in charge of any dwelling unit, structure or use to which a number has been assigned shall cause the same to be posted in either one or two locations depending upon the following conditions: 
1.  If the mailbox is located on the same side of the street and adjacent to the driveway or curb cut, the number shall be affixed to the mailbox in letters two inches in height or larger and of a color contrasting with the color of the mailbox. This section does not preclude an individual from also numbering the front entrance of the structure if so desired. 
2.  If the mailbox is not on the same side of the street and adjacent to the driveway or curb cut, the number shall be posted at two locations: 
(a)  On the mailbox as prescribed by the U.S. Postal Service regulations; 
(b)  Either on the structure front if visible from the street or on an above-ground sign attached to a post or other object at the driveway or curb cut. The numbers shall be two inches in height or larger and of a color contrasting with the color of the background. This section does not preclude an individual from also numbering the front entrance of his structure if so desired. 
3.  In the case that a building is served by two or more driveways or curb cuts, the number shall be assigned and posted to the front entrance of driveway. 
4.  It shall be the duty of the owner, occupant or person in charge of the dwelling unit, structure or use, upon affixing the new number, to remove any different number which might be mistaken for or confused with the number assigned to the structure. 
5.  In such cases where the assigned number cannot be posted as required above, the number shall be posted as prescribed by the department of planning and zoning after consultation with the owner. 
(Res. of 3-11-85, art. IV; Code 1991, § 12.02.040) 
12.10.050. - Types of numbers. 
Two types of numbers are used under this chapter: 
A.  A primary number to be assigned to each street frontage of each parcel of land, whether or not the parcel is occupied. The primary number is required to be posted only if the parcel is occupied by a dwelling unit, structure or active use and the owner, occupant or person in charge is notified under section 12.10.040 of this chapter. Other primary numbers are reserved for future development of the numbered parcels and will be assigned at the time of development. 
B.  Secondary numbers may be used when a number of units, structures and uses co-exist on the same parcel of land. Examples of parcels requiring secondary numbers include apartment projects, condominium projects, mobile home parks, office parks, planned unit developments, recreational vehicle parks, recreational areas, shopping centers and other uses where the use of secondary numbers would clarify the location of a unit for use for public safety purposes. To provide secondary numbers, the administering department shall work with the owner, manager or person in charge of the project to determine a logical numbering system under the following guidelines: 
1.  Existing numbered units and uses shall retain the present set of addresses with only the primary number being changed if the primary number is not in sequence with the overall system. 
2.  Buildings on a single parcel with more than one and less than five units may be given either letter (preferred) or number designations as requested by the owner. 
3.  A single building on a single parcel of land and with five or more units may be given numerical designations such as Suite 5, Apartment 5, etc., if so desired. 
4.  Multiple buildings on the same parcel of land may be given secondary numbers consisting of number designations if the buildings are accessed from a main entrance to the project. Generally the number designations should increase in a clockwise direction from the main entrance. 
5.  Mobile home parks, recreational vehicle parks and similar uses shall be given letter designations for lots or sections and number designation for individual lots or sites. 
(Res. of 3-11-85, art. V; Code 1991, § 12.02.050) 
12.10.060. - Implementation in stages of numbering system. 
A.  Because of the large and complex nature of Hall County and the existing numbering system now in place in some portions of unincorporated Hall County, this chapter shall be implemented in stages covering small sections of the entire area by the adoption of implementation resolutions for each section of the county. 
B.  It shall be the policy of the board of commissioners not to change existing numbered addresses if the existing system follows a logical and expandable order. 
(Res. of 3-11-85, art. VI; Code 1991, § 12.02.060) 
12.10.070. - Excluded structures. 
A.  The intent of this section is to exclude from this chapter those structures that do not present a significant danger to human life if destroyed by fire or other events. 
B.  The following structures shall be excluded from the provisions: 
1.  Agricultural buildings not requiring a separate mailing address such as a barn, poultry house, outbuilding or equipment storage buildings. Buildings used as dwelling units, offices or the nominal work station of an employee shall not be exempt. 
2.  Storage and accessory buildings for the use of the occupant of another building on the property. Buildings used as dwelling units, offices, or the nominal work station of an employee, or requiring a separate mailing address, shall not be exempt. 
(Res. of 3-11-85, art. VII; Code 1991, § 12.02.070) 
12.10.080. - New structures and lots. 
A.  Structure numbers will be assigned to each new lot, tract or building site on the original drawings of a final subdivision plat, mobile home park, planned unit development or other plan requiring the approval of the Hall County Planning Commission by the planning and zoning department. 
B.  No building, electrical, plumbing or mechanical permit for any new or remodeled or repaired structure will be issued by the building official of Hall County, Georgia, following the implementation of this resolution [chapter] in the affected area of Hall County until the owner, developer or builder has procured from the department of planning and zoning the official structure number or numbers. Final approval for a certificate of occupancy of any principal building erected or repaired, or use requiring said number, shall be withheld until permanent and proper numbers have been displayed in accordance with the standards of this chapter. 
(Res. of 3-11-85, art. VIII; Code 1991, § 12.02.080) 
Cross reference— Subdivisions, tit. 16. 
12.10.090. - Valid structure number required before provision of utility services. 
A.  Following the implementation of this resolution [chapter] in any area of Hall County, all utility services regulated by the Georgia Public Service Commission or any utility cooperative service organization shall withhold service from any building until the owner or other requesting party has furnished the utility with a valid structure number. 
B.  It shall be the responsibility of the Hall County Department of Special Services to notify each affected utility service of each implementation area by issuing maps and lists of official numbers assigned each structure or use. 
(Res. of 3-11-85, art. IX; Code 1991, § 12.02.090) 
Cross reference— Public services, tit. 13. 
12.10.100. - Valid structure number required before provision of certain county services. 
Every department and official under the jurisdiction of the Hall County Board of Commissioners shall not render any non-emergency service until the occupant, owner or requesting individual has provided the department with a valid structure number. Non-emergency service includes any service provided by the board of commissioners except fire, rescue, law enforcement or emergency medical service. 
(Res. of 3-11-85, art. X; Code 1991, § 12.02.100) 
Cross reference— Administration, tit. 2. 
12.10.110. - Penalties. 
Any person, firm, corporation, association or partnership violating any provision of this chapter as the same exists or as it may hereinafter be amended, or shall fail to do anything required by this chapter as the same exists or as it may hereafter be amended, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, amenable to the process of the Magistrate or State Court of Hall County, and upon conviction, shall be punished as provided in the Official Code of Hall County, Georgia section 1.50.020 for each violation in the discretion of the court. Each and every day that such violation exists shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(Res. of 3-11-85, art. XI; Code 1991, § 12.02.110; Res. of 6-10-04(1), § 1) 
12.10.120. - Effective date. 
Sixty days after the adoption of an implementation resolution for each area of unincorporated Hall County, this chapter shall take effect and be in full force and effect in that area of the county. 
(Res. of 3-11-85, art. XII; Code 1991, § 12.02.120) 
CHAPTER 12.20. - COUNTY ROAD SYSTEM[3] 

 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference— Minimum rights-of-way, ch. 12.30; approved street access required for all lots, § 16.30.060; design of streets in subdivisions, ch. 16.60; street construction requirements for subdivisions, ch. 16.70. 

12.20.010. - Established; official road map. 
The county will recognize and maintain as part of the county road maintenance system (hereinafter "system") those roads or streets within the county which are shown on the official road map of the county dated November 10, 1975, as revised from time to time, and those roads or streets which have been accepted into the system by action of the county board of commissioners, since the latest revisions of the map. A road which is accepted into the system shall be known as a publicly maintained road. 
(Res. of 10-9-89, § 1; Code 1991, § 12.04.010) 
12.20.020. - Road acceptance standards. 
The commission or its designee shall established standards for acceptance for various classes of roads for acceptance of roads into the system. These standards shall be known as the county road maintenance system acceptance standards (hereinafter "standards"). Except as provided in section 12.20.030.B, all persons applying for acceptance of a road into the system must establish compliance with the provisions of the standards. 
(Res. of 10-9-89, § 2; Code 1991, § 12.04.020) 
Cross reference— Subdivisions, tit. 16. 
12.20.030. - Contents of application for road acceptance. 
Owners of property which abuts a road adjacent to a publicly maintained road may petition the commission for acceptance of the road into the system by making application to the planning commission. 
A.  In all cases, the application shall contain the following: 
1.  The name, address, telephone number and signature of each owner adjacent to the road which is proposed for acceptance; 
2.  Proof of express dedication of the road to public use evidenced by a right-of-way deed, properly executed, witnessed and notarized in accordance with state law and acceptable for recording, conveying to the county the minimum necessary right-of-way required for the class of road involved according to then existing standards, or proof of implied dedication as evidenced by permitted open, continuous and notorious use by the public, or both; 
3.  Proof of express acceptance by the commission of such dedication evidenced by entry on the minutes of the commission or proof of implied acceptance of such dedication by acts of the county constituting maintenance, improvement, or control over the road; 
4.  Proof that the road is a road dedicated to the public and open to vehicular traffic, and is not a private road, a developer's raid [road] or a driveway; 
5.  Proof that there is an average of one house per 500 linear feet of road; and 
6.  Proof that the road serves a public purpose. 
B.  As to roads which were previously publicly maintained roads, the application shall also contain: 
1.  Proof that the road was previously a publicly maintained road, maintained by the county, which burden of proof shall be on the applicants; 
2.  A proposal for the payment of $1.00 per linear foot of roadway on each side of the right-of-way to the county to defray the cost of upgrading the road to conditions necessary to allow for maintenance, if such upgrading is necessary. 
C.  As to roads which have never been part of the system, or as to which the applicants cannot meet the burden of proof required in subsection B of this section, the application shall also contain proof that the road meets minimum standards for acceptance into the system for that class road, as provided by then existing standards. 
(Res. of 10-9-89, § 3; Code 1991, § 12.04.030) 
12.20.040. - Hearing on application for road acceptance. 
Upon submission of a properly completed application, the planning commission shall consider the application at the next practicable regular meeting and make a recommendation of the acceptance or rejection to the commission. The commission shall then, at a regularly scheduled public meeting, consider the application and hear comments from interested parties and shall accept or reject the road. 
(Res. of 10-9-89, § 4; Code 1991, § 12.04.040) 
12.20.050. - Procedure for road abandonment. 
If the commission concludes that a road dedicated to public use and maintained by the county has ceased to be used to the extent that it no longer provides a substantial benefit to the public, it may institute procedures and provide for required notice to abandon the road and dispose of the property upon which said road is located in accordance with the provisions of O.C.G.A. title 32, chapter 7. 
(Res. of 10-9-89, § 6; Code 1991, § 12.04.050) 
12.20.060. - Creation of special taxing district for road improvements. 
Pursuant to the 1993 Georgia Constitution, Article IX, Section II, Paragraph VI, a special district may be created for the purpose of providing street and road construction, maintenance, repair and/or improvement. 
A.  Creation of special taxing district. A special district may be created by resolution of the Hall County Commission within the unincorporated land district of Hall County, Georgia, which special district shall be composed of all of that land abutting the previously maintained public right-of-way proposed to be improved. The implementing resolution of the board of commissioners will contain a description to adequately describe the special taxing district. 
A.  Burden of proof. Proof that the road or street proposed to be improved was a previously maintained public way shall be on the applicants or petitioners. 
B.  Assessment provisions. The owner of each parcel of land in such special district shall be assessed a road improvement fee. Assessments for each affected property parcel shall be made in a fair and reasonable manner with assessments being directly tied to the purpose of providing adjacent road and street improvements. Such assessments shall become a lien against each parcel of real estate in such special district when assessed in the same manner as all other real estate tax assessments. 
C.  Payment of assessments. The assessments provided for in paragraph B of this section shall be included in the land owner's real estate tax assessment and shall be payable in the same manner as other real estate taxes on said parcel. 
D.  Delinquency. Failure to pay any assessment provided for in this section shall subject the responsible party to the same liens and penalties provided for failure to pay other real estate taxes on said parcel and will result in the delinquency of the entire account of said parcel. Such assessment will not be deemed paid until all real estate taxes for such parcel, including the special assessment, are paid in full. 
E.  Revenue from assessments. The proceeds of the assessments provided for herein shall be used exclusively to defray the cost of providing road and street improvements for such special district. 
F.  Petition requirements. As a prerequisite to the consideration of the creation of a special taxing district as provided herein for street and road construction maintenance, repair and/or improvement, 100 percent of the landowners of the property adjacent to the previously maintained public right-of-way to be improved must petition in the affirmative the board of commissioners of Hall County asking for the creation of a special taxing district for road and street improvement. 
(Res. of 10-8-98, § 1) 
CHAPTER 12.30. - MINIMUM RIGHTS-OF-WAY[4] 

 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference— County road system, ch. 12.20; design of streets in subdivisions, ch. 16.60. 

12.30.010. - Minimum standards for state streets, through streets and nondesignated streets. 
A.  All roads, streets and highways in the county road system built or maintained through state aid or which are designated as through streets (any road or street which connects two major traffic arteries) shall have a minimum right-of-way of 60 feet. 
B.  All other roads, streets and highways in the county road system shall have a minimum right-of-way of 50 feet. 
(Res. of 4-25-88, §§ 1, 2; Code 1991, § 12.08.010) 
12.30.020. - Exemptions. 
Whenever the commissioners, upon competent engineering advice, determine that a previously existing and platted road, street or highway, which has been proposed for acceptance into the county road system, and which has less than the required minimum 50-foot right-of-way, cannot be brought within the 50-foot minimum right-of-way standard in a practical and cost effective manner, then the commissioners may approve the acceptance of the road, so long as it meets all other acceptance criteria and a professional engineer certifies the road may safely be constructed in such a manner, at its previously platted right-of-way. In no event shall this exception apply to a state aid road or through street. 
(Res. of 4-25-88, § 3; Code 1991, § 12.08.020) 
CHAPTER 12.40. - DRIVEWAY CONSTRUCTION[5] 

 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference— Buildings and construction, tit. 15; access requirements for subdivision lots, § 16.50.040; street construction requirements for subdivisions, ch. 16.70; zoning regulations, tit. 17; off-street parking, storage and loading requirements, ch. 17.250. 

12.40.010. - Intent. 
The safe operating of motor vehicles, and the need to minimize potential nuisance factors resulting from conflicts between commercial or industrial traffic utilizing streets designed for residential traffic, are issues which directly relate to the public health, safety, and welfare of residents in the county. The appropriate design and location of driveways can significantly lessen the adverse effects related to these issues. The establishment of reasonable design standards and administrative procedures included herein shall aid in protecting the health, safety, and welfare of the residents of the county. 
(Res. of 9-14-81, § 1; Code 1991, § 12.12.010) 
12.40.020. - Purpose of design standards. 
The purpose of this chapter is: 
A.  To insure that vehicles leave or join the roadway traffic at a proper angle and in conformity with the rules of the road. 
B.  To reduce hazard to vehicles by reducing areas of conflict and points of conflict between vehicles. 
C.  To increase the capacity of roads and intersections by reducing areas of conflict between vehicles. 
D.  To provide sufficient space for the installation of traffic control devices, utilities and crosswalks. 
E.  To reduce hazard to pedestrians by reducing areas of possible conflict between pedestrians and vehicles, and to define such areas. 
F.  To provide reasonable assurance against the hazardous and indiscriminate use of highway right-of-way through encroachment. 
G.  To provide a maximum practical sight distance, especially at intersections. 
H.  To provide uniform and impartial consideration in all cases where access is required by abutting property owners. 
I.  To reduce the possibility of conflicts between commercial/industrial traffic generators and residential areas. 
(Res. of 9-14-81, § 2; Code 1991, § 12.12.020) 
12.40.030. - Definitions. 
A.  The following definitions apply to the standards set forth in these regulations and figures included as examples of driveway types: 
Buffer areas means the border area along the frontage between the traveled way and the right-of-way line and within the frontage boundary lines; areas (1), (2), (3), (4) in figures 1 and 2 of section 12.40.230. 
Buffer island means the area between the frontage right-of-way line and a line parallel to and a minimum of a four-foot distance from the right-of-way line extended away from the right-of-way line; area (5) in figures 1 and 2 in section 12.40.230. 
Common access driveway means the primary means of access to a public street, shared by and connecting three but no more than five parcels, tracts, lots, building sites or structures. 
Corner clearance (C) means, at an intersecting street or highway, the dimension measured along the edge of the traveled way between the frontage boundary line opposite the intersection of the two right-of-way lines and the tangent projection of the nearest edge of the driveway; see figure 3, section 12.40.230. 
Distance between double driveways (D) means the distance measured along the right-of-way line between the tangent projection of the inside edges of two adjacent driveways to the same frontage; D in figure 2 of section 12.40.230. 
Driveway angle (Y) means the angle of 90 degrees or less between the driveway centerline and the edge of the traveled way; see figures 1 and 2 of section 12.40.230. 
Driveway width (W) means the narrowest width of the driveway measured parallel with the edge of the traveled way; see figures 1 and 2 of section 12.40.230. 
Edge clearance (E) means the distance measured along the edge of the traveled way, between the frontage boundary line and the tangent projection of the nearest edge of the driveway; see figures 1 and 2 of section 12.40.230. 
Frontage means the length along the highway right-of-way line of a single property tract of roadside development area between the edges of the property; the distance between (1) and (2) in figures 1 and 2 of section 12.40.230. 
Frontage boundary line (abbreviated as FB line) means a line perpendicular to the highway centerline, at each end of the frontage lines, extending from the right-of-way to the edge of the through-traffic lane; line (1)—(4) or (2)—(3) in figures 1 and 2 of section 12.40.230. 
Inside radius (U) means the inside or smaller curve radius on the edge of the driveway, used when Y is substantially less than 90 degrees; see figures 2 and 3 of section 12.40.230. 
Outside radius (R) means the outside or larger curve radius on the edge of the driveway; see figures 1, 2 and 3 of section 12.40.230. 
B.  For simplicity, the above definitions are stated in terms of single radius curves of the edge of driveways or intersecting highways. Where compound curves or tapers are used, an equivalent single radius curve may be used as a control guide. 
(Res. of 9-14-81, § 6(A); Res. of 6-8-87, § 1; Code 1991, § 12.12.030) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1.20.010 et seq. 
12.40.040. - Application for permit. 
Application for a permit to construct or alter a driveway or curb cut occurring on or abutting a county road right-of-way shall be made to the building official of the county under the following circumstances: 
A.  When such driveway(s) or curb cut(s) are incidental to the development of a new structure or the development of previously undeveloped property, the driveway permit shall constitute a part of the building permit. 
B.  When such driveway or curb cut construction constitutes a separate action apart from any other construction on the same site, a driveway permit shall be secured from the building official. 
C.  When property abutting a county road right-of-way changes from one use to another and driveways and/or curb cuts have previously been extended across or to a county road right-of-way, or when the type of use or the volume of use of an existing and/or previously approved driveway is substantially changed, application for review shall be submitted and a driveway permit secured from the building official. The occupancy permit may be withheld until such driveway improvements have been approved. 
(Res. of 9-14-81, § 3; Code 1991, § 12.12.040) 
12.40.050. - Issuance or denial of permit; appeals. 
Upon reviewing an application for a driveway permit in any of the aforementioned circumstances, the building official shall take one of the following courses of action: 
A.  Issue the permit if the standards correspond with the requirements as outlined in the regulations. 
B.  Submit the application to the public works director and/or the planning director for their review, such review not to exceed five working days. The public works director and/or the planning director shall: 
1.  Recommend approval of the permit to the building official; 
2.  Recommend disapproval of the permit unless certain modifications are made which they shall delineate in writing to the building official. 
C.  Issue the permit if the applicant agrees to follow the recommendations of the public works director/planning director. 
D.  Deny the permit application. 
E.  If the driveway permit is denied by the building official, the applicant can appeal the building official's decision to the planning commission, who shall hear testimony from the applicant. The planning commission may either approve or deny the application. 
(Res. of 9-14-81, § 4; Code 1991, § 12.12.050) 
12.40.060. - General design standards. 
The location, design and construction of the driveway shall be in accordance with the following standards. These standards are in no case to be modified unless specifically authorized by the building official: 
A.  A driveway shall be located and restricted as to width as necessary driveway and its appurtenances are contained within the frontage along the highway of the property served. At public highway intersections a driveway shall not provide direct ingress or egress to or from the public highway intersection area and shall not encroach on or occupy areas of the roadway or right-of-way deemed necessary for effective traffic control or for highway signs or signals. A driveway shall be so located and constructed that vehicles approaching or using it will have adequate sight distance in both directions along the highway. 
B.  The number of driveways permitted serving a single property frontage shall be a maximum of two unless more are deemed necessary by the Public Works Director for reasonable service to the property without undue impairment of safety, convenience, and utility of the highway. 
C.  If the property has frontage on more than one street, and a driveway permit is requested, the building official may request a recommendation from the public works director, planning director, or planning commission as to the potential adverse effects which may result. If it is determined that it would cause a nuisance to the surrounding area, or a traffic hazard, or unduly congest traffic, then the permit may be denied. 
D.  The island area on the right-of-way between successive driveways or adjoining a driveway and between the highway shoulder and right-of-way line shall remain unimproved for vehicular travel or parking. Such areas shall be considered as restricted and may be filled in or graded down only as hereinafter provided in subsection H. of this section. 
E.  The surface of the driveway connecting with rural type highway sections shall slope down and away from the highway shoulder a sufficient amount and distance to preclude ordinary surface water drainage from the driveway area flooding onto the highway roadbed. 
F.  The driveway shall not obstruct or impair drainage in side ditches or roadside areas. Driveway culverts, where necessary, shall be adequate for surface water drainage along the roadway and in no case less than the equivalent of 15-inch diameter pipe. The distance between culverts under successive driveways shall be not less than ten feet except as such restricted area is permitted to be filled in under the provisions of subsection H. of this section. All driveway culverts shall be constructed of the following materials and meet Georgia Department of Transportation (D.O.T.) specifications: 
1.  Reinforced concrete pipe (RCP), D.O.T. approved Class III or better. 
2.  Corrugated metal pipe, D.O.T. approved, type II aluminized steel. This material is prohibited in live stream applications. 
3.  High density polyethylene (HDPE) pipe, D.O.T. approved, dual walled. 
G.  Driveways connecting to "L" back curb and gutter must be constructed by removing the curb and gutter and pouring a valley gutter. When curb and gutter is removed for constructing a driveway, the new connections shall be of equivalent acceptable material and curb returns shall be provided or restored in a neat, workmanlike manner. The driveway or valley gutter surface shall connect with the highway pavement and sidewalks, if any, in a neat workmanlike manner. In no case shall the driveway construction impair the flow of water in the gutter. Figures 7 and 8 depict the proper details for constructing a valley gutter. 
H.  Driveways connecting to rolled curb and gutter may be constructed by either pouring the driveway directly up to the back of the curb or by removing the curb and gutter and pouring a valley gutter. When curb and gutter is removed for constructing a driveway, the new connections shall be of equivalent acceptable material and curb returns shall be provided or restored in a neat, workmanlike manner. The driveway or valley gutter surface shall connect with the highway pavement and sidewalks, if any, in a neat workmanlike manner. In no case shall the driveway construction impair the flow of water in the gutter. Figures 7 and 8 depict the proper details for constructing a valley gutter. 
I.  Any activities that impair the flow of water in a curb and gutter is prohibited. These prohibited activities include, but are not limited to: The filling in of curb and gutter with concrete or asphalt, or the removal of curb and gutter without providing an acceptable valley gutter as described in [subsections] G. and H. above. 
J.  The restricted area between successive driveways may be filled in or graded down only when the following requirements are fully complied with: 
1.  The filling or grading down shall be to grades approved by the public works director; and, except where drainage is by means of curb and gutter, water drainage of the area shall be directed away from the highway roadbed in a suitable manner. 
2.  Culvert extension under the restricted area shall be of like size and equivalent acceptable material of the driveway culvert, and intermediate manholes adequate for clean-out purposes may be required where the total culvert length exceeds 100 feet. 
3.  Where no side ditch separates the restricted area from the roadbed, permanent provision may be required to separate the areas from the highway roadbed, to prevent its use for driveway or parking purposes, by construction of a border, curb, rail or posts deemed adequate by the public works director. 
(Res. of 2-23-12, § 1(Exh. A); Res. of 9-26-13(2), § 1(Exh. A)) 
Editor's note— Res. of 2-23-12, § 1(Exh. A), repealed former § 12.40.060, and enacted a new § 12.40.060 as set out herein. Former § 12.40.060 pertained to the same subject matter and derived from Res. of 9-14-81, § 5; Code 1991, § 12.12.060 and Res. of 11-22-00(1), § 1. 
12.40.070. - Specific design standards. 
The following specific design standards in sections 12.40.080 through 12.40.160 shall apply to driveways requiring permits as set forth in these regulations. The items are driveway width, angle of entry and exit, return radius of curb, maximum percent of frontage for driveway use, distance to side property lines, island areas, intersection clearance, parking and storage areas and driveway grade. 
(Res. of 9-14-81, 6(B); Code 1991, § 12.12.070) 
12.40.080. - Driveway widths. 
Measured parallel to the roadway[, driveway widths shall be as follows]: 

 
(Res. of 9-14-81, § 6(B)(1); Code 1991, § 12.12.080) 
12.40.090. - Angle of entry and exit. 
Driveway angles [shall be as follows]: 
A.  Residential, 60 to 90 degrees, or parallel to property line; 
B.  Apartments, 70 to 90 degrees for two-way driveways or 45 to 90 degrees for one-way streets; 
C.  Commercial, 70 to 90 degrees for two-way driveways or 45 to 90 degrees for one-way on divided roadway or 60 to 90 degrees for one-way ramp on non-divided roadway; 
D.  Industrial, 90 degrees, or as close as practicable, for two-way, or 45 degrees, one-way access on one-way street; 
E.  Rural, land access only, 60 to 90 degrees. 
(Res. of 9-14-81, § 6(B)(2); Code 1991, § 12.12.090) 
12.40.100. - Return radius of curb. 
[Return radius of curbs shall be as follows:] 

 
(Res. of 9-14-81, § 6(B)(3); Code 1991, § 12.12.100) 
12.40.110. - Maximum percentage of frontage for driveway use. 
A.  Each single driveway shall have a maximum width of 30 percent of the property frontage. Where two or more driveways are permitted, no more than 60 percent of property frontage shall be used as driveways. 
B.  No approval for a curb cut will be given where it is apparent that the intent is not to provide access but to provide parking only. A driveway approach must provide access to something definite on private property such as a parking area considerably greater in extent than the width of the driveway, or provide access to a driveway, or to a door at least eight feet wide intended for the entrance of vehicles, etc. (not applicable for residential driveways). 
(Res. of 9-14-81, § 6(B)(4); Code 1991, § 12.12.110) 
12.40.120. - Distance to side property lines. 
A.  The area within five feet of a frontage boundary line shall be a restricted area on which no driveway may be developed on public right-of-way (E). 
B.  A minimum of 1½ feet of pavement edge or curb shall be left undisturbed adjacent to each frontage boundary line to serve as an island area. This distance shall be measured between the FB line and the point of tangency of the driveway radius and the edge of the pavement measured along the edge of the pavement. 
C.  Subsection A. or B. of this section shall apply, whichever is more restrictive. 
D.  These requirements may be waived when a single driveway is approved to serve two adjacent lots. 
(Res. of 9-14-81, § 6(B)(5); Code 1991, § 12.12.120) 
12.40.130. - Island areas. 
A.  Minimum island dimensions. 
1.  Distance between double driveways (D), ten feet minimum at narrowest point; 
2.  Minimum island depth, four feet where parking abuts street right-of-way line. 
B.  Treatment of island or buffer area. In the development of private property and the construction of driveways thereto, it may be necessary to regrade the buffer area by cutting or filling. Such work shall be done in a manner to insure adequate sight distance for traffic operations, proper drainage, suitable slopes for maintenance operations, and good appearance. The buffer area outside the driveways shall be treated to prevent use by vehicles. This may be accomplished by grading, or use of curbs, rails, guide posts, low walls, low shrubs, etc., in a manner which will not impair clear sight across the area. 
C.  Visibility clearance. No landscaping, fences, terraces, or other natural or artificial features adjacent to any street shall be of a nature impairing visibility from or of approaching vehicular traffic where such visibility is important to safety, nor shall such features in any way create potential hazards to pedestrians. In particular, at vehicular entrances and exits, no off-street parking, landscaping, or other material impediment to visibility between the height of three feet and ten feet, measured from the roadway level, shall be permitted within triangular areas defined by lines connecting points described as follows: 
1.  Nonresidential use. Beginning at a point where the midline of the entrance or exit intersects the public right-of-way, thence to a point of 35 feet along the right-of-way in the direction of approaching traffic, thence to a point of 25 feet toward the interior of the lot along the midline of the entrance or exit, and thence to a point of beginning. (See figure 12.40.130 A [12.40.230 5A].) 
2.  Multifamily residential use. Beginning at a point where the midline of the entrance or exit intersects the public right-of-way, thence to a point of ten feet along the right-of-way in the direction of approaching traffic, thence to a point of ten feet toward the interior of the lot along the midline of the entrance or exit, and thence to the point of beginning. (See figure 12.40.130 B [12.40.230 5B].) 
(Res. of 9-14-81, § 6(B)(6); Code 1991, § 12.12.130) 
12.40.140. - Intersection clearance. 
The length, width and shape of corner island areas will vary for different locations. The angle of intersection, angle of driveways, width of the right-of-way on both approaches, channelization radii, and other conditions will influence the location of driveways at intersections. The location and angle of an approach in relation to the highway intersection shall be such that a vehicle leaving the service facility may be merged in the lane of traffic moving in the desired direction before crossing the intersection, and that a vehicle entering the facility from the intersection may do so in an orderly and safe manner with a minimum of interference to through traffic. 
The following conditions may be applicable in most instances: 
A.  No driveway shall be allowed to encroach upon pavement edge radii. 
B.  The following minimum distances from the intersection right-of-way line (C) shall apply where there is no conflict with the foregoing conditions: 
1.  Traffic volume A.D.T. of 1,500 or less, 20 feet; 
2.  Traffic volume A.D.T. over 1,500 but less than 10,000, 35 feet; 
3.  Traffic volume A.D.T. over 10,000 but less than 15,000, 50 feet; 
4.  Traffic volume A.D.T. over 15,000, 65 feet. 
The public works director shall have the authority to increase these distances if in his opinion such action is necessary for the protection of traffic. The public works director may also modify these requirements if justifiable on the basis of site conditions. 
(Res. of 9-14-81, § 6(B)(7); Code 1991, § 12.12.140) 
12.40.150. - Parking and storage areas. 
A.  Each roadside business establishment, when providing off-street parking or storage space, shall provide such parking or storage space off the right-of-way to prevent the storage of vehicles on the driveway or the backing up of traffic on the travel way. This is particularly needed for businesses where a number of vehicles will be leaving and entering at the same time. 
B.  Particular attention will be paid to drive-in facilities such as banks, minute car washes, drive-in restaurants, drive-in bill paying facilities, and other service facilities where motorists are served while in their vehicles, to insure that queues of vehicles will not extend out onto the public streets. 
(Res. of 9-14-81, § 6(B)(8); Code 1991, § 12.12.150) 
12.40.160. - Driveway grade. 
A.  Residential driveways: The maximum grade which shall be permitted is 17 percent. 
B.  Apartment, commercial and industrial driveways: The maximum grade which shall be permitted is eight percent. 
C.  Grades within the right-of-way shall be controlled by existing shoulder slope or existing and future sidewalk elevations. 
D.  When driveways are intended for special use vehicles, the underside clearance and/or break over angle of the subject vehicle shall dictate the maximum driveway. 
(Res. of 9-14-81, § 6(B)(9); Code 1991, § 12.12.160) 
12.40.170. - Common access driveways; general provisions. 
The following specific design standards shall apply to common access driveways requiring permits as set forth in these regulations. Even though a common access drive may provide access to parcels or lots, each resultant parcel, tract or lot must still meet the minimum public street frontage requirements for the zoning district in which it is located unless otherwise exempted as a lot of record. Parcels, tracts, lots, or building sites for which building permits are requested or upon which there is a proposed subdivision of land that will not have separate and individual driveway access to a public street within the limits of the property itself, but is proposed to be served by a common access driveway, shall install such a driveway in conformance to the following standards in sections 12.40.180 through 12.40.220. 
(Res. of 6-8-87, § 2; Code 1991, § 12.12.170) 
12.40.180. - Common access driveways; submission of plans. 
Any [person seeking an] (a) building permit or occupancy permit requested for lots of record, or (b) proposed subdivision of land, whereby three but not more than five parcels or lots are to be served by a common access driveway, shall, at the time of the permit application or proposed subdivision of property, submit all necessary plans as required by the county engineer indicating the proposed location and construction specifications for the proposed common access driveway. 
(Res. of 6-8-87, § 2; Code 1991, § 12.12.180) 
12.40.190. - Common access driveways; construction prior to plat approval or issuance of occupancy permit. 
New common access driveways shall be constructed prior to the issuance of an occupancy permit for lots of record or prior to the approval and recording of a final plat for the proposed subdivision of land. 
(Res. of 6-8-87, § 2; Code 1991, § 12.12.190) 
12.40.200. - Common access driveways; plats and required statements. 
Plats indicating the location of common access driveway easements and lots to be served shall be recorded with the clerk of superior court of the county. The plats shall include: 
A.  A statement to the effect that the driveway easement shown on the plat is not to be dedicated as a public road and not to be maintained by the county, but shall be privately maintained; and 
B.  A statement signed by the surveyor, a registered engineer or a registered landscape architect that the driveway has been constructed in accordance with the minimum standards of the county. 
(Res. of 6-8-87, § 2; Code 1991, § 12.12.200) 
12.40.210. - Common access driveways; previously existing driveways. 
Any existing easements or common driveways which have been recorded prior to the effective date of this amendment [chapter] may continue to serve existing lots which were also recorded prior to the effective date of the resolution codified in this chapter. Any new driveways which would propose access to three or more undeveloped lots of record must conform with the standards for a common access driveway in accordance with this amendment. 
(Res. of 6-8-87, § 2; Code 1991, § 12.12.210) 
12.40.220. - Common access driveways; minimum standards. 
Construction of common access driveways shall conform to the following minimum standards. Please see Figure 6 for a cross-section detail: 
A.  Easement width, 30 feet, 30 feet radius easement in cul-de-sac; 
B.  Roadbed width 20 feet; 
C.  Shoulder width, two feet; 
D.  Base width, 18 feet; 
E.  Pavement width, 16 feet; 
F.  Minimum radius at cul-de-sac transition and intersections, 20 feet; 
G.  Pavement type: 
1.  Plant mix, one inch thick over graded aggregate four inches thick (except within the public right-of-way, which shall be six inches thick); 
2.  Concrete, four inches thick (except within the public right-of-way, which shall be six inches thick); 
H.  If a common access driveway terminates in a dead end, the termination shall be either a cul-de-sac with a paved radius of 25 feet, or another termination method that allows for vehicles to turn around safely and is acceptable to Hall County Engineering; 
I.  If a common access driveway is a cul-de-sac, the maximum length of the cul-de-sac shall be 1,000 feet; 
J.  Individual driveways joining the common driveway must be placed entirely on the property that they serve; 
K.  Individual driveways joining the common driveway may only serve one lot; 
L.  Ditches: Front slope, maximum 2:1 ratio; rear slope, maximum 2:1 ratio; 1 ½ foot minimum depth; 
M.  Maximum finished driveway grade, 17 percent; driveway grades up to 20 percent may be approved by the county engineer in extreme conditions; 
N.  Pavement crown, ¼-inch per foot; 
O.  All slopes and shoulders to be grassed; 
P.  Minimum crossdrain pipe size, 18 inches; 
Q.  The driveway must intersect the public road at an angle of 65 degrees or greater; 
R.  The driveway must enter the public road at least 65 feet from any intersection of another common access driveway as measured from centerline to centerline. The driveway must enter the public road at least 65 feet from another public road intersection as measured from the centerline of the common access driveway to the closest point of right-of-way intersection; 
S.  Intersection sight distance shall be as specified in the sight distance table in section 16.60.090 of this Code. 
(Res. of 6-8-87, § 2; Code 1991, § 12.12.220; Res. of 11-22-00(1), § 2)
