CHAPTER 15.10. - STANDARD CODES AND AMENDMENTS[2] 

 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Section 1 of a resolution adopted April 11, 1996, adopted Ch. 15.10 to read as herein set out. Such provisions were treated as superseding the existing Ch. 15.10, §§ 15.10.010—15.10.110, which pertained to the Standard Building Code and derived from § 1 of a resolution adopted Nov. 14, 1988; § 1 of a resolution adopted Aug. 14, 1989; § 1 of a resolution adopted Aug. 28, 1989; §§ 1, 2 of a resolution adopted Sept. 9, 1991; §§ 1—4 of a resolution adopted Dec. 9, 1991; § 1 of a resolution adopted Oct. 26, 1992; §§ 1, 2 of a resolution adopted Oct. 18, 1993; a resolution adopted Feb. 23, 1995; and §§ 15.04.010—15.04.110 of the 1991 Code. Subsequently, Ord. of July 13, 2006, § 1, repealed Chapters 15.10—15.70. Section 2 of said ordinance enacted provisions designated as a new Ch. 15.10 to read as herein set out. See the Code Comparative Table for a detailed analysis of inclusion. 

15.10.010. - Title. 
This chapter will be known as "Standard Codes and Amendments". 
(Ord. of 7-13-06, § 2) 
15.10.020. - Standard Codes, adopted, future amendments, referenced codes and conflicts. 
A.  Minimum Standard Codes. Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 8-2-20, et. seq., the following minimum standard codes as adopted by the State of Georgia and as amended by the State of Georgia Department of Community Affairs, are incorporated by reference and adopted as part of this chapter as if fully set out herein. A copy of each code is filed in the office of the Clerk of the Hall County Commission and is authenticated by his or her signature. However, the minimum standard codes below are amended as set forth in this chapter: 
1.  International Building Code 2000 Edition, International Code Council (ICC). 
2.  National Electrical Code 2005 Edition, National Fire Protection Association (NFPA). 
3.  International Fuel Gas Code 2003 Edition (ICC). 
4.  International Mechanical Code 2000 Edition (ICC). 
5.  International Plumbing Code 2000 Edition (ICC). 
6.  International Residential Code for One and Two Family Dwellings 2000 Edition (ICC). 
7.  International Energy Conversation Code 2000 Edition (ICC). 
8.  International Fire Code 2003 Edition (ICC). 
B.  Future amendments. Any subsequent amendments to or future editions of the Codes adopted pursuant to section 15.10.020, that are enacted and adopted by the State of Georgia are hereby incorporated and adopted and shall be enforced by Hall County as if set forth verbatim in the Official Code of Hall County, Georgia. A copy of the latest edition of such codes shall be filed in the office of the Clerk of the Hall County Commission and will be authenticated by his or her signature. The provisions thereof shall be controlling within the unincorporated area of Hall County, Georgia. 
C.  Referenced codes. The codes and standards referenced in any code adopted pursuant to this chapter shall be considered to be adopted to the extent only of each such reference. Where differences occur between provisions of the Official Code of Hall County, Georgia and referenced codes and standards, the provisions of the Official Code of Hall County, Georgia shall apply. 
D.  Conflicts. Should any provision of the above adopted codes conflict with any other provision of the Official Code of Hall County, Georgia, that provision which is most restrictive shall control. 
(Ord. of 7-13-06, § 2) 
15.10.030. - Minimum Standard Codes, administration. 
A.  Administration. In addition to the provisions of the International Building Code adopted by the State of Georgia and as amended by the Georgia Department of Community Affairs, Chapter 1 of the International Building Code is hereby adopted in its entirety, except as amended in this Section, and is applicable as Chapter 1 for each Minimum Standard Code adopted pursuant to section 15.10.020.A with the exception of the International Fire Code. Said amendments are as follows: 
1.  Department of building safety. International Building Code § 103, Department of Building Safety, is deleted in its entirety and the following is inserted in lieu thereof: 
The term "department of building safety" or "building safety" as used in this Code shall refer to the Hall County Building Inspections Department or other Hall County administrative division or department as designated by the Hall County Administrator. The building official shall be designated by the Hall County Administrator. 
2.  Fees. For all Codes adopted in section 15.10.020, fees shall be administered as specified in § 108 of the International Building Code, based on the current fee schedule established by the Hall County Board of County Commissioners. 
3.  Board of appeals. International Building Code § 112 "Board of Appeals" is deleted in its entirety and the following is inserted in lieu thereof: 
(a)  Appeals-general. Whenever the building official, code official or other county official responsible for the application and enforcement of this Code shall reject or refuse to approve the mode or manner of construction proposed to be followed or materials to be used in the erection or alteration of a building or structure, or when it is claimed that the provisions of the code do not apply, or that an equally good or more desirable form of construction can be employed in any specific case, or when it is claimed that the true intent and meaning of the code or any of the regulations thereunder have been misconstrued or wrongly interpreted, the owner of such building or structure or his authorized agent may appeal from the decision of the building official, code official or other county official responsible for the application and enforcement of this Code to the Hall County Board of Commissioners in writing, setting forth the action or ruling appealed in detail, within 30 days of the action or ruling. The Hall County Board of Commissioners shall hold a hearing on the appeal within 15 days of filing and shall render a decision within 30 days of the hearing. A fee of $50.00 shall be paid for each appeal filed. 
(b)  Variance to code after hearing. The Hall County Board of Commissioners, when so appealed to and after a hearing, may vary the application of any provision of the code to any particular case when, in its opinion, the enforcement thereof would do manifest injustice, and would be contrary to the spirit and purpose of this Code or public interest, or when, in its opinion, the interpretation of the building official, code official or other county official responsible for the application and enforcement of this Code should be modified or reversed. 
(c)  Recording minutes of hearing. A decision of the Hall County Board of Commissioners to vary the application of any provision of the code, or to modify an order of the building official, code official or other county official responsible for the application and enforcement of this Code shall specify in what manner such variation of modification is made, the conditions upon which it is made and the reasons therefor and shall be recorded in the minutes of the meeting at which the decision is made. 
(d)  Reversal of decision. If a decision of the Hall County Board of Commissioners reverses or modifies a refusal, order or disallowance of the building official, code official or other county official responsible for the application and enforcement of this Code or varies the application of any provision of the code, the building official, code official or other county official responsible for the application and enforcement of this Code shall immediately take action in accordance with such decision 
4.  Violations. 
(a)  Prosecution of violation. International Building Code § 113.3, Prosecution of Violation, is deleted in its entirety and the following is inserted in lieu thereof: 
In case any building, structure, land, mechanical system, plumbing system, or other system, installation or equipment regulated by this Code is or is proposed to be used, operated, occupied, erected, constructed, reconstructed, altered, converted or maintained, or any building, structure, land, mechanical system, plumbing system, or other system, installation or equipment regulated by this Code is or is proposed to be used in violation of any provision of the this chapter, the building or code official, county attorney, or other appropriate authority of the county may, in addition to other remedies, institute injunction, mandamus, or other appropriate action or proceeding to prevent such unlawful operation, occupation, erection, construction, reconstruction, alteration, conversion, maintenance, or use to correct or abate such violation or to prevent the occupancy of such building, structure or land. 
(b)  Violation penalties. International Building Code § 113.4, Violation penalties, is deleted in its entirety and the following is inserted in lieu thereof: 
Any person who violates a provision of this chapter or fails to comply with any of the requirements thereof or who operates, occupies, erects, constructs, reconstructs, alters, converts, maintains or repairs a building, structure, land, mechanical system, plumbing system, or other system, installation or equipment regulated by this Code in violation of the approved construction documents or directive of the building official, code official or other official responsible for the application and enforcement of this Code, or of a permit or certificate issued under the provisions of this chapter, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, amenable to the process of the Magistrate or State Court of Hall County, and upon conviction, shall be punished as provided in the Official Code of Hall County, Georgia section 1.50.020 for each violation in the discretion of the Court. Each day such violation is committed or permitted to continue shall constitute a separate offense and shall be punishable as such hereunder. 
(Ord. of 7-13-06, § 2) 
15.10.040. - International Building Code, amendments. 
A.  Swimming pool enclosures, general. International Building Code § 3109.1, General, is deleted in its entirety and the following is inserted in lieu thereof: 
General. Swimming pools shall comply with the requirements of this Section and other applicable sections of this Code with the exception that nothing contained in § 3109 shall apply to any pool in existence or under construction as of May 22, 1997. 
B.  Mobile homes, manufactured homes and mobile/manufacture home parks. In addition to any other adopted provision of the International Building Code, the following provisions shall apply where applicable: 
1.  Definitions. 
(a)  "Manufactured home." For the purposes of Official Code of Hall County, Georgia section 15.10.040, "manufactured home" means a structure, transportable in one or more sections, which, in the traveling mode, is eight body feet or more in width or 40 body feet or more in length or, when erected on site, is 320 or more square feet and which is built on a permanent chassis and designed to be used as a dwelling with or without a foundation when connected to the required utilities and includes the plumbing, heating, air conditioning, and electrical systems contained therein; except that such terms shall include any structure which meets all the requirements of this paragraph except the size requirements and with respect to which the manufacturer voluntarily files a certification required by the secretary of housing and urban development and complies with the standards established under the National Mobile Home Construction and Safety Standards Act of 1974, 42 U.S.C. 5401 et seq. 
(b)  "Mobile home". For the purposes of Official Code of Hall County, Georgia § 15.10.040, "mobile home" means a structure, transportable in one or more sections, which, in the traveling mode, is eight body feet or more in width or 40 body feet or more in length or, when erected on site, is 320 or more square feet and which is built on a permanent chassis and designed to be used as a dwelling with or without a permanent foundation when connected to the required utilities and includes the plumbing, heating, air conditioning and electrical systems contained therein and manufactured prior to June 15, 1976. 
(c)  "Manufactured/mobile home park." For the purposes of Official Code of Hall County, Georgia section 15.10.040, "manufactured/mobile home park" means a parcel of land containing not less than five acres under single ownership which has been planned and improved for the placement of two or more manufactured homes or mobile homes for nontransient uses. Excepted from this definition are those parcels of land on which two or more manufactured homes or mobile homes existed prior to August, 1978, and are identified on public records maintained in the Hall County Planning Director's Office. 
(d)  Pre-owned "manufactured home" means any manufactured home that has been previously used as a residential dwelling. 
2.  Installation of manufactured homes. 
(a)  Any installation of a manufactured home in Hall County shall be performed in strict compliance with the applicable manufacturer's installation instructions, specifically including, without limitation, correctly installed tie-downs and anchors. In the absence of such instructions, installations shall be performed in accordance with the applicable rules and regulations adopted by the Georgia Safety Fire Commission. 
(b)  In those instances in which no manufacturer's installation instructions are available, the Georgia Safety Fire Commissioner's rules and regulations governing the installation of manufactured homes are to be followed. Said rules and regulations are incorporated herein by reference to become a part of this Code, and to be known as "Rules and Regulations for Manufactured Homes." 
(c)  Each newly installed manufactured home in Hall County that is installed in an approved manufactured home park shall be completely underpinned and skirted with approved masonry, metallic, nonmetallic, wooden, or other approved manufacturer's underpinning kits. Each existing mobile home or manufactured home located in a manufactured home park shall be completely underpinned and anchored in accordance with the applicable provisions for nonhurricane anchorage. 
(d)  Each existing mobile home or manufactured home in Hall County that is not located in a manufactured home park shall be completely underpinned and skirted with approved masonry, metallic, nonmetallic, wooden, or other approved manufacturer's underpinning kits. Further, each manufactured home or mobile home shall be anchored in accordance with applicable provisions for nonhurricane zone anchorage. The manufactured home or mobile home shall have removed from the body of said home the tongues (where the removing of the tongues does not affect the structural integrity of the frame) and wheels. Mobile homes and manufactured homes with current occupancy permits that are not located in manufactured home parks shall fully comply with the restriction of this paragraph. 
(e)  Each new manufactured home shall be installed such that the finished floor level of the home elevation shall not exceed an average height higher than five feet elevation from finished grades. 
(f)  Each manufactured home and mobile home in Hall County shall have beneath and descending from each outside door of the home a landing and guard rails around said landing, steps with handrails descending to the ground or grade level. The landing, steps and rails must be constructed of all-weather materials or manufactured kits. Furthermore, all construction and/or manufactured kits shall comply with the requirements of the building code resolution as adopted by Hall County, including all amendments thereto. All manufactured homes and mobile homes with current occupancy permits in Hall County shall comply with this section. Each newly installed manufactured home in this county shall comply with the requirements of this section before an occupancy permit is issued for said home. 
(g)  Each newly installed manufactured home in Hall County shall conform to the minimum construction standards required by the U.S. Housing and Urban Development Department before that manufactured home is entitled to receive any utility service to said home. It is the intent of this section to prohibit moving homes into Hall County that do not conform to the applicable U.S. Housing and Urban Development Department Construction Standards. To that end, no manufactured home shall be allowed to locate for permanent or temporary occupancy in this county unless that manufactured home complies with the minimum construction standards required by the U.S. Housing and Urban Development Department and has been inspected by the Hall County Building Inspection Department to show that all windows, doors, smoke detectors, plumbing system, electrical system, heating system and ventilation systems are in working order. 
3.  Moving used manufactured homes, site built homes or stick built homes into the county. 
(a)  No pre-owned manufactured home being moved into Hall County shall be allowed to locate for permanent or temporary occupancy in this county except as provided in this section. Provided, however, that any manufactured home that is located in Hall County as of December 9, 1991, shall not be affected by this section and said existing manufactured home shall be freely transferable and relocated in Hall County, unless said existing manufactured home was manufactured prior to U.S. Housing and Urban Development Department Construction Standards. 
(b)  In the event a mobile home was manufactured prior to U.S. Housing and Urban Development Department Construction Standards, said mobile home shall not be allowed to locate for permanent or temporary occupancy in this county, and said mobile home shall not be freely transferable and relocated in Hall County except as provided in this section. 
(c)  No mover, hauler, person, firm, corporation or other entity shall: 
1.  Move a mobile home to any location beyond the limits of the lot or parcel of land upon which it presently is located; 
2.  Move a mobile home into Hall County; or 
3.  Move a manufactured home or mobile home out of Hall County without first obtaining a relocation permit from the building official of Hall County in charge of issuing building permits. Provided, however, this relocation permit shall not be required when a manufactured home is moved from the manufacturing site to the dealer's place of business. 
(d)  Notwithstanding anything to the contrary, a manufactured home or site built home or stick built home may be moved into Hall County provided the following conditions are met: 
1.  Said home is inspected by the Hall County Building Inspection Department prior to being brought into Hall County and must pass the same test as to the condition of the home as that is required by all new or pre-owned manufactured homes. 
2.  An application for a permit to locate the home will be filed with the Hall County Planning Commission. Each application must have with it a site plan for the placement of the home. Each application will be heard by the Hall County Planning Department and then referred to the Hall County Commissioners for final approval or denial. Each application will be processed and considered by the Hall County Planning Commission and the Hall County Commissioners in the same manner as a rezoning application. 
3.  The fees to be paid with each application will be the same as in filing an application for rezoning. 
4.  The criteria for approval or denial shall be as follows: 
a.  The same criteria as is set out in section 17.370.060(c) of the Official Code of Hall County, Georgia, said criteria being incorporated fully in this section and made a part hereof. 
b.  The compatibility with existing housing in the surrounding area in terms of type, style, age, and condition. 
c.  No pre-owned manufactured home or site built home being moved into Hall County shall be allowed to locate for permanent or temporary occupancy in Hall County unless such manufactured home or site built home has been occupied by the applicant owner for the previous consecutive 12 months as his or her principal residence immediately prior to its being moved into Hall County. Furthermore no such manufactured home or site built home shall be moved into Hall County to be used for a purpose other than occupancy by its owner as his or her principal residence. 
d.  Each newly installed site built or stick built home in Hall County shall conform to the minimum construction standards required by the Standard Building Code before that home is entitled to receive any utility service to said home. It is the intent of this section to prohibit moving site built homes and stick built homes into Hall County that do not conform to the applicable Standard Building Code standards. To that end, no site built or stick built home shall be allowed to locate for permanent or temporary occupancy in this county unless that site built or stick built home complies with the minimum construction standards required by the Standard Building Code. No used stick built or site built home being moved into Hall County shall be allowed to locate for permanent or temporary occupancy in this county if the said home is more than seven years old except as provided in this section. Provided, however, that any site built or stick built home that is located in Hall County as of December 9, 1991, shall not be affected by this section and said existing site built home or stick built home shall be freely transferable and relocated in Hall County. 
e.  A manufactured home that does not meet the requirements of this section and a mobile home that is located in Hall County, Georgia, and was manufactured prior to U.S. Housing and Urban Development Department Construction Standards may be transferred to a Hall County licensed dealer authorized to buy and sell mobile homes for location at said dealer's place of business for sale or transfer outside Hall County. In no event shall this exception allow any person to transfer said mobile home to another location within Hall County, live in said mobile home or allow said mobile home to receive any utility service. 
4.  Manufactured home contractor bonds. It shall be the duty of every contractor who shall make contracts for the location of manufactured homes or relocatable homes for which a permit is required, and every contractor subletting the same, or any part thereof, to obtain where required by state law or local ordinance or resolution, a current and valid business tax certificate, business license or occupation tax certificate reflecting the payment of all occupation taxes; and it shall be the further duty of every such person to give good and sufficient bond in the sum of $10,000.00, to be approved by the county attorney, conditioned to conform to the building code and other ordinances or laws of the governing body in reference to manufactured homes and relocatable homes. 
5.  Permits. 
(a)  It shall be a condition precedent to the issuance of any permit required by this section that the owner of said manufactured or mobile home submit to the tax commissioner of Hall County proof that all state and county taxes theretofore accruing and payable with respect to such home have in fact been paid; and if said manufactured home or mobile home which is to be relocated or located is then located within any portion of the county that lies within the limits of a municipality therein, such owner shall likewise submit proof that all applicable municipal taxes have been paid before a permit may be issued. The proof required by this section shall be met when the applicant presents the tax commissioner with either the manufactured home or mobile home location decal permit or a receipt for such decal. Both of these documents are issued by the county when the owner of a manufactured home or mobile home pays the taxes due on the home. If the receipt has been lost and the decal has been permanently affixed to the manufactured home or mobile home, the applicant may provide the tax commissioner with the permit number and, upon verification by personnel in the tax office that the taxes on that manufactured home or mobile home have in fact been paid, the applicant shall be deemed to have met the proof required by this section. 
(b)  Every person, firm, partnership, corporation, or other entity owning or operating a manufactured home park, and each such entity engaged in the sale or rental of manufactured homes or mobile homes or lots upon which to place them, shall furnish the tax assessor and tax commissioner of Hall County on or before the tenth day of each month with a complete list of all manufactured homes and mobile homes parked, rented, or otherwise located as of the first day of that month upon the property of the entity or in a manufactured home park operated by the entity. 
6.  Manufactured home minimum standards. 
(a)  Exterior. All components of the exterior, including siding, windows and exterior doors of the manufactured home shall be aesthetically uniform in appearance and free of any condition that may hinder operation as originally intended or might admit moisture. 
(b)  Roof. The roof of the manufactured home shall be in sound condition with no obvious defects. 
(c)  Interior. The flooring, interior wall and ceiling shall be in sound condition and appearance. 
(d)  Egress windows. Each bedroom of a manufactured home shall have at least one operable escape window. 
(e)  Ventilation. Bathrooms and kitchen without a window must have an operable ventilation device. 
(f)  Smoke detectors. Each manufactured home shall contain one operable battery powered smoke detector in each bedroom and in the kitchen area. The smoke detectors must be installed in accordance with the manufacturer's recommendations. 
(g)  Sanitary facilities. Each manufactured home shall contain a kitchen sink. Each bathroom in the manufactured home shall contain a lavatory and water closet, at least one bathroom shall contain a tub and/or shower facilities. Each of these fixtures shall be checked when properly connected to ensure they are in good working condition. 
(h)  Electrical. The distribution panels of each manufactured home shall be in compliance with the approved listing, complete with required breakers, with all unused openings covered with solid covers approved and listed for that purpose. Connections shall be checked for tightness. The electrical panels shall be accessible. All electrical switches, receptacles and fixtures shall be properly and securely installed. 
(i)  Hot water supply. Each manufactured home shall contain a water heater in safe and working condition. 
(j)  Heating source. Each manufactured home shall have a safe central heating system in working condition. Un- vented heaters shall be prohibited. 
(k)  Skirting. Installation of skirting shall be required. Installation shall be in accordance with the building inspector. Acceptable materials may include masonry, stone, metal, or other materials manufactured for the purpose of skirting. Vinyl is prohibited. 
7.  Rules and regulations for manufactured homes. A copy of The Rules and Regulations for Manufactured Homes as set forth by the Georgia Safety Fire Commissioner is incorporated herein by reference and made a part hereof. In addition, a copy of the rules and regulations shall be placed in the bulk file of the Hall County Board of Commissioners containing the adopted International Building Code. 
(Ord. of 7-13-06, § 2; Res. of 9-9-10(2), §§ 1—7) 
15.10.050. - National Electrical Code, amendments. 
A.  Administration. National Electrical Code Chapter 1, Administration, is deleted in its entirety and the following is inserted in lieu thereof: 
The provisions of Official Code of Hall County, Georgia section 15.10.030 shall apply to this Code. 
B.  Load calculations for service and feeder conductors. National Electrical Code § 555.12, Load calculations for Service and Feeder Conductors, is deleted in its entirety and the following is inserted in lieu thereof: 
1.  General lighting and other loads. General lighting and other loads shall be calculated in accordance with National Electrical Code Article 220, and, in addition, the demand factors set forth in National Electrical Code Table 555.12 shall be permitted for each service and/or feeder circuit supplying receptacles that provide shore power for boats. These calculations shall be permitted to be modified as indicated in notes (1) and (2) to National Electrical Code Table 555.12. 
2.  Electrical services for boat docks and marinas. The U.S. Army Corp of Engineers Regulations for Electrical Services for Boat Docks attached to this resolution codified in this section and on file in the office of the county clerk is permitted to be used for demand factors for electrical services and feeders for boat docks and marinas in the county. 
(Ord. of 7-13-06, § 2) 
15.10.060. - International Fuel Gas Code, amendments. 
International Fuel Gas Code Chapter 1, Administration, is deleted in its entirety and the following is inserted in lieu thereof: 
The provisions of Official Code of Hall County, Georgia section 15.10.030 shall apply to this Code. 
(Ord. of 7-13-06, § 2)
