"Industrialized dwelling unit" means a dwelling or component thereof which is wholly or in substantial part made, fabricated, formed, or assembled in manufacturing facilities for installation or assembly and installation on a building site and has been manufactured in such a manner that all parts or processes cannot be inspected at the installation-site without disassembly, damage to, or destruction thereof and which bear the insignia of approval issued by the Commissioner of the Georgia Department of Community Affairs. 
(Res. of 6-17-02(2), § 1; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.20.600. - Inventory items. 
"Inventory items" means those items not designed or intended to function outdoors or independently, including but not limited to washing machines, clothes dryers, refrigerators, water heaters and other appliances and parts of automobiles, boats and other vehicles. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 3; Res. of 9-7-88; Code 1991, § 17.20.410; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.20.610. - Junk yard. 
"Junk yard" means the use of any space whether inside or outside a building for the storage, keeping, salvage and/or sale of junk, scrap metals or other scrap materials, including the dismantling, demolition or abandonment of one or more automobiles or other vehicles or machinery or parts thereof. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 3; Code 1991, § 17.20.420; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.20.620. - Kennel, commercial. 
"Commercial kennel" means any place in or at which more than four adult dogs (or cats) are kept for the purpose of sale, boarding, care, breeding or training and for which any fee is charged. A commercial kennel shall be located on not less than five acres of land in the residential zoning districts. The raising of four or fewer adult dogs (or cats) would be inherently allowed in all residential zones that allow a commercial kennel. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 3; Res. of 10-14-91; Res. of 11-11-91; Res. of 4-30-92; Code 1991, § 17.20.430; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.20.630. - Laboratory. 
"Laboratory" means an establishment or premises where scientific services are provided, including testing or analysis of medical, chemical, physical, mechanical, electric or electronic nature or the calibration of instruments. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 3; Code 1991, § 17.20.440; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.20.640. - Lot. 
"Lot" means a parcel of land which is designated as a single unit of property. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 3; Code 1991, § 17.20.450; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.20.650. - Lot depth. 
"Lot depth" means the mean horizontal distance between the front and rear lot lines measured in the general direction of the side lot lines. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 3; Code 1991, § 17.20.480; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.20.660. - Lot line, front. 
"Front lot line" means the front line of an interior lot separating the lot from the frontage street right-of-way. The front lot line of a corner lot shall be the lot line upon which the principal building entrance will front. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 3; Code 1991, § 17.20.500; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.20.670. - Lot line, rear. 
"Rear lot line" means the lot line [that] is generally opposite the lot line along the frontage of the lot. If the rear lot [line] is less than ten feet in length or if the lot comes to a point at the rear, the rear lot line shall be deemed to be a line parallel to the front lot line not less than ten feet long lying wholly within the lot and farthest from the front lot line. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 3; Code 1991, § 17.20.510; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.20.680. - Lot of record. 
"Lot of record" means a lot or plat which has been legally recorded with the county clerk of superior court prior to the effective date of the resolution codified in this title and which actually exists as so shown or described. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 3; Code 1991, § 17.20.515; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.20.690. - Lot width. 
"Lot width" means the distance between the side lot lines measured at the front building line. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 3; Code 1991, § 17.20.520; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.20.700. - Lot, corner. 
"Corner lot" means a lot located at the junction of and abutting on two or more intersecting streets. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 3; Code 1991, § 17.20.523; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.20.710. - Lot, interior. 
"Interior lot" means a lot other than a corner lot. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 3; Code 1991, § 17.20.526; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.20.711. - Manufactured home. 
"Manufactured home" means a dwelling fabricated in an off-site facility for installation or assembly at the building site, bearing a label certifying that it is constructed in compliance with the National Manufactured Housing Construction and Safety Standards Act of 1974 (42 U.S.C. 5401, et seq.), which first became effective on June 15, 1976. The term "manufactured home" includes a structure, transportable in one or more sections, which, in the traveling mode, is eight body feet or more in width or 40 body feet or more in length, or when erected on-site, is 320 or more square feet in floor area, and which is built on a permanent chassis and designed to be used as a dwelling with or without a permanent foundation when connected to the required utilities and includes the plumbing, heating, air-conditioning, and electrical systems contained therein, except that such term includes any structure which meets all the requirements of this definition except the size requirement and with respect to which the manufacturer voluntarily files a certification required by the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development and complies with the standards established under the National Manufactured Housing Construction and Safety Standards Act of 1974 (42 U.S.C. 5401, et seq.). 
(Res. of 6-17-02(2), § 1; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.20.720. - Minor subdivisions. 
"Minor subdivision" means the subdivision of land into a total of two conforming lots, parcels, tracts or building sites during a 12-month period. The resultant lots must meet all of the requirements (lot size, frontage, access, etc.) of the zoning district in which they are classified and the requirements of the county subdivision regulations. Minor subdivisions which conform to the aforementioned standards may be created on any lot, tract or parcel which was recorded with the county clerk of superior court prior to January 1 of each calendar year, provided the subject lot and all resultant lots comply with the standards of the county zoning and subdivision regulations. Once any lot, tract or parcel meeting the aforementioned standards has been subdivided into a total of two lots, tracts, parcels or building sites, no further subdivision of either of the two lots is permitted inherently for the 12-month period after the land was subdivided. Any additional subdivision beyond two lots per 12-month period shall require consideration by the county planning commission as a use subject to planning commission approval. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 3; Res. of 2-22-88; Res. of 4-14-94; Code 1991, § 17.20.530; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.20.730. - Mobile home. 
"Mobile home" means a dwelling manufactured prior to June 15, 1976, transportable in one or more sections, which, in the traveling mode, is eight body feet or more in width or 40 body feet or more in length, or when erected on-site, is 320 or more square feet in floor area, and which is built on a permanent chassis and designed to be used as a dwelling with or without a permanent foundation when connected to the required utilities and includes the plumbing, heating, air-conditioning, and electrical systems contained therein. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 3; Code 1991, § 17.20.540; Res. of 6-17-02(2), § 1; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.20.740. - Manufactured home park. 
"Manufactured home park" means a parcel of land containing not less than five acres under single ownership which has been planned and improved for the placement of two or more manufactured homes or mobile homes for nontransient uses. Excepted from this definition are those parcels of land on which two or more manufactured homes or mobile homes existed prior to August, 1978, and are identified on public records maintained in the Hall County Planning Director's Office. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 3; Code 1991, § 17.20.550; Res. of 6-17-02(2), § 1; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.20.750. - Modular home. 
"Modular home" means a detached single-family dwelling which is fabricated entirely or in part at some location other than its permanent site and which may be a complete unit or closed segments thereof. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 3; Code 1991, § 17.20.560; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.20.760. - Motel. 
"Motel" means a building or group of buildings containing guest rooms and having separate outside entrances for each guest room, to be used primarily for automobile transients, and including such terms as "auto court" and "motor lodge," but not "boarding house," as defined in this chapter. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 3; Code 1991, § 17.20.570; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.20.761. - Multi-family dwelling unit. 
"Multi-family dwelling unit" means a residential building designed and used exclusively for permanent rather than transient occupancy by three or more families in separate dwelling units living independently of each other. 
(Res. of 10-24-02, § 3; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.20.770. - Nonconforming use. 
"Nonconforming use" means any building or use which lawfully exists at the time of adoption of the resolution adopted in this chapter and which does not conform with the use regulations of the district in which it is located. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 3; Code 1991, § 17.20.580; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.20.780. - Occupy. 
"Occupy" means to use land or buildings for any length of time for a purpose for which the land or a building or part thereof is used or is intended to be used. Any variation of the term "occupy" shall be encompassed by this definition. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 3; Res. of 9-7-88; Code 1991, § 17.20.590; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.20.781. - Occupancy, permanent. 
"Permanent occupancy" means occupancy or use by an owner, or by a tenant for periods of 30 consecutive days or more. Such occupancy is characteristic of single-family, two-family and multiple-family dwelling units, including mobile homes, industrialized homes, manufactured homes, town homes and condominiums. The county commission may allow for transient occupancy of units permitted for permanent occupancy in the event of natural disasters or large community events that put a special burden on the local transient housing market. 
(Res. of 10-24-02, § 4; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.20.782. - Occupancy, transient. 
"Transient occupancy" means occupancy or use by a paying guest or tenant for a period of less than 30 consecutive days or by the offering or advertising of a residence as being available in whole or in part to be used for such occupancy. Such occupancy is characteristic of hotels, motels, boardinghouses and rooming houses. 
(Res. of 10-24-02, § 5; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.20.787. - Overlay District. 
A zoning district that encompasses one or more underlying traditional use districts or zones and that imposes additional requirements and/or allows additional permitted uses above those required or allowed by the underlying zone[s]. An overlay district can be coterminous with existing zoning districts or contain only parts of one or more such districts. Where an overlay district's principal purpose is to impose additional requirements on otherwise permitted land uses, it is customary for such a district to be created at the instance of the county. By contrast, where the principal purpose of an overlay district is to allow an additional use that would not otherwise be permitted in the underlying zone(s), then it will customarily be a private applicant who will institute the necessary map amendment process. 
(Res. of 3-25-04, § 1) 
17.20.790. - Park, community. 
"Community park" means a parcel of land owned by a unit of government or a private organization used or intended to be used for recreational or leisure time activities. Such parks may include food and/or recreational sales as accessory uses. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 3; Code 1991, § 17.20.600; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.20.800. - Planned unit development. 
"Planned unit development" means the development of a tract of land ten acres or more by which clustered housing and/or commercial, office or industrial development may be permitted without the customary subdivision of lots. A comprehensive development plan for such a project shall be submitted to the planning commission for their review and approval. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 3; Code 1991, § 17.20.610; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.20.810. - Plat. 
"Plat" means a sketch, map or survey of a lot, tract or parcel of land, including lot lines, street rights-of-way and easements, with the dimensions of these features inscribed thereon. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 3; Code 1991, § 17.20.620; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.20.820. - Plat, development. 
"Development plat" means a preliminary design which shows the proposed layout of a subdivision in sufficient detail to indicate its workability and conformation to the design requirements of the subdivision regulations in all aspects, but [which] is not in final form for recording and [on which] the details are not completely computed. The development plat shall be approved by the planning commission prior to any development. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 3; Code 1991, § 17.20.630; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.20.830. - Plat, final. 
"Final plat" means a finished drawing of a subdivision showing completely and accurately all legal and engineering information and certification necessary for recording. The final plat of a subdivision shall be approved by the planning commission and the streets shown on the plat shall be approved by the board of commissioners previous to recording. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 3; Code 1991, § 17.20.640; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.20.840. - Public use. 
"Public use" means a use conducted by a unit of government. 
(Res. of 1-27-92; Code 1991, § 17.20.648; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.20.850. - Public way. 
"Public way" means a street or road which has been dedicated for public use by deed, plat and/or prescription. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 3; Code 1991, § 17.20.650; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.20.860. - Recreational or cultural use of a commercial nature. 
"Recreational or cultural use of a commercial nature" means a building or use which provides entertainment, education, recreation and/or amusement for profit such as but not limited to a health spa, dance hall, bowling alley, skating rink, shooting range, fortune telling, amusement park, private zoo, sports stadium or arena, art gallery, concert hall, swimming pool or drive-in theater. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 3; Code 1991, § 17.20.660; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.20.870. - Residence. 
"Residence" means a building containing only dwelling units and which meets all the applicable requirements of the Standard Building Code for conventional construction. The term "residence" or any combination thereof shall not be deemed to include a hotel, boarding house, rooming house, motel or other accommodations used for transient occupancy, and shall not for the purpose of this chapter [title] include a mobile home or modular home. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 3; Code 1991, § 17.20.670; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.20.880. - Residence, duplex or two-family. 
"Duplex or two-family residence" means a detached residence designed for or occupied exclusively by two families living independently of each other. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 3; Code 1991, § 17.20.690; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.20.890. - Residence, multi-family. 
"Multi-family residence" means a detached residence designed for or occupied exclusively by three or more families living independently of each other. This includes, but is not limited to, townhouses and apartments. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 3; Res. of 4-15-93; Code 1991, § 17.20.700; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.20.900. - Residence, single-family. 
"Single-family residence" means a detached residence other than a mobile home, modular home or travel trailer designed for or occupied by one family. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 3; Code 1991, § 17.20.705; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.20.910. - Restaurant. 
"Restaurant" means any establishment, however designated, at which food is sold for consumption on the premises. However, a snack bar or refreshment stand at a public or non-profit community swimming pool, playground, park or marina operated solely for the convenience of patrons of the facility shall not be deemed a restaurant. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 3; Code 1991, § 17.20.710; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.20.920. - Residential business. 
"Residential business" means an occupation or profession conducted within a dwelling, and which is carried on by an occupant thereof and which is clearly incidental and secondary to the use of the dwelling for residential dwelling purposes. The business may require access by the public. The residential business is designed to be less restrictive than a home office or home occupation but more restrictive than a rural business in regard to access by the public, size, visibility, number of employees and types of business. Planning commission approval is required in accordance with the conditions outlined in section 17.350.130. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 3; Res. of 7-10-89; Code 1991, § 17.20.720; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.20.930. - Resubdivision. 
"Resubdivision" means a legal subdivision which has been altered by changing of a line, bearing or other measurement which either reduces or enlarges the number of lots or size of lots originally created and which is subsequently platted and recorded in a legal manner. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 3; Code 1991, § 17.20.730; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.20.940. - Retail. 
"Retail" means the sale of merchandise for personal or household consumption, including processing incidental or subordinate to selling. 
(Res. of 1-27-92; Code 1991, § 17.20.735; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.20.950. - Right-of-way. 
"Right-of-way" means access over or across particularly described property for a specific purpose or purposes. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 3; Code 1991, § 17.20.740; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.20.960. - Rural business. 
"Rural business" means an occupation or profession conducted within a dwelling, an accessory structure or outside and which is carried on by a resident of that property and which is clearly incidental and secondary to the use of the property for residential dwelling purposes. The rural business is designed to be less restrictive than a home office, home occupation or residential business in regard to access by the public, size, visibility, number of employees and types of business. Planning commission approval is required for a rural business in accordance with the conditions outlined in section 17.350.140. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 3; Res. of 7-10-89; Code 1991, § 17.20.750; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.20.970. - School, nursery and kindergarten. 
"School, nursery and kindergarten" means a school designed to provide early childhood education for children ages three through six. Such schools shall provide at least 100 square feet of outdoor play area for each child; such play areas shall be enclosed by a fence of at least three feet six inches in height. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 3; Code 1991, § 17.20.760; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.20.980. - Scrap materials. 
"Scrap materials" means any items normally considered as salvage, scrap, junk, or as useless or worthless materials. This includes, but is not limited to, pieces, fragments, and parts of items no longer usable as originally intended, materials left over from fabricating, leftover bits of food and empty containers. 
(Res. of 8-12-93; Code 1991, § 17.20.765; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.20.990. - Service station, automobile. 
"Automobile service station" means a building and/or lot where gasoline, oil, grease, batteries, tires and other automobile accessories may be dispensed at retail and where the business of general motor vehicle service and minor repair is conducted but where no part of the premises is used for the storage of dismantled or wrecked vehicle parts. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 3; Code 1991, § 17.20.770; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.20.1000. - Setback. 
"Setback" means the minimum horizontal distance between the street, rear or side lines of the lot and the front, rear or side lines of the building or structure attached thereto. The term "required setback" means a line beyond which a building or structure attached thereto is not permitted to extend under the provisions of this title establishing minimum depth and width of yards. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 3; Code 1991, § 17.20.780; Res. of 1-24-02(2), § 2; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.20.1010. - Shopping center. 
"Shopping center" means a group of commercial establishments planned, developed and owned or managed as a unit with on-site parking and of similar architectural characteristics. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 3; Code 1991, § 17.20.790; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.20.1020. - Sign. 
"Sign" means every billboard, poster panel, free-standing ground sign, roof sign, projecting sign, pylon sign, illuminated sign, and sign painted on a wall, window, marquee, awning or canopy and shall include any announcement, declaration, demonstration, display, ribbon, banner, illustration or insignia used to advertise or promote the interests of any person when the same is placed in view of the general public. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 3; Res. of 9-10-90; Code 1991, § 17.20.800; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.20.1030. - Sign area. 
"Sign area" means the actual face or advertising area of a sign on one side only. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 3; Code 1991, § 17.20.810; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.20.1040. - Sign, billboard. 
"Billboard sign" means a free-standing or attached outdoor advertising structure promoting any business, product, service, industry or use other than that performed on the property on which the sign is placed. The billboard may or may not be illuminated and may be any size up to the maximum size permitted by these regulations. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 3; Code 1991, § 17.20.820; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.20.1050. - Sign, business. 
"Business sign" means a sign directing attention to a business, commodity, service or other activity conducted on the premises upon which the sign is located. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 3; Code 1991, § 17.20.830; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.20.1051. - Single-family detached dwelling unit. 
"Single-family detached dwelling unit" means a residential building, whether site-built or a manufactured home or an industrialized building, designed and used exclusively for permanent rather than transient occupancy by one family. 
(Res. of 6-17-02(2), § 1; Res. of 10-24-02, § 1; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.20.1052. - Site-built single-family detached dwelling unit. 
"Site-built single-family detached dwelling unit" means a single-family detached dwelling constructed on the building site from basic materials delivered to the site, and which is constructed in accordance with all requirements of the Building Code as adopted by Hall County. 
(Res. of 6-17-02(2), § 1; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.20.1053. - Site-built two-family dwelling unit. 
"Site-built two-family dwelling unit" means a two-family dwelling constructed on the building site from basic materials delivered to the site and which is constructed in accordance with all requirements of the building codes as adopted by Hall County. 
(Res. of 6-17-02(2), § 1; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.20.1060. - Slow rate land treatment system. 
"Slow rate land treatment system" means a system for wastewater treatment by spray irrigation (land application). The term refers to the advanced treatment of wastewater by irrigation onto land to support vegetative growth. When properly sited, designed and operated as defined by state and local regulations, there is no direct discharge to surface waters. The irrigated wastewater evaporates and transpires to the atmosphere or enters the groundwater through percolation. Organic constituents in the wastewater are stabilized by soil bacteria. Organic and ammonia nitrogen are taken up by plants, nitrified by soil bacteria, lost to the atmosphere through denitrification, and leached into the groundwater. Phosphorus and other constituents are adsorbed in the soil profile and taken up by plants. Properly sited, designed and operated wastewater irrigation systems produce a percolate water of high quality and thus protect ground and surface water resources. For purposes of this regulation, the use may include ponds (lagoons) for the temporary storage of the treated wastewater before application to the spray fields. The treated wastewater stored in the lagoons must have been treated to a level that could be sprayed without further treatment. These ponds shall have liners to prevent seepage. This land use is permitted only with the approval of the county commission after a recommendation by the planning commission. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 3; Res. of 1-14-91; Res. of 4-26-91; Code 1991, § 17.20.835; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.20.1070. - Stable, commercial. 
"Commercial stable" means any place established for gain or profit at which more than four adult horses are kept for the purpose of training, boarding, sale or breeding or where instruction pertaining to the same is given for a fee. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 3; Code 1991, § 17.20.836; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.20.1080. - Storage facility, self-service. 
"Storage facility, self-service," means a building consisting of multiple small self-contained stalls or lockers that are leased or owned for the storage of customers' goods or wares. 
(Res. of 1-27-92; Code 1991, § 17.20.838; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.20.1090. - Street. 
"Street" means a public or dedicated thoroughfare or a private right-of-way or easement shown on a recorded plat and which has been approved by the planning commission. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 3; Code 1991, § 17.20.850; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.20.1100. - Street right-of-way. 
"Street right-of-way" means a line defining the outer edges of a street boundary and separating the street from abutting property or lots or a proposed street line shown on any plan approved by the planning commission. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 3; Code 1991, § 17.20.853; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.20.1110. - Street, arterial. 
"Street, arterial" means a major street, highway or state route with intersections at grade and direct access to abutting property, and on which geometric design and traffic control measures are used to expedite the safe movement of through traffic between major traffic generators. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 3; Res. of 4-26-91; Code 1991, § 17.20.856; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.20.1120. - Street, collector. 
"Collector street" means any street designed and located to collect traffic from intersecting minor streets while still giving access to abutting property, and to conduct such traffic to and from a variety of destinations outside a single subdivision, neighborhood or business district. See also "street, residential collector." 
(Res. of 11-25-91; Code 1991, § 17.20.858; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.20.1130. - Street, connector. 
"Connector street" means a street supplementary to the major state and U.S. highway systems running throughout the country and primarily a means of intercommunication between this system and smaller areas. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 3; Code 1991, § 17.20.860; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.20.1140. - Street, local. 
"Local street" means a street intended solely to provide access to immediately adjacent land; in residential areas, a residential access or residential subcollector street. See also "street, residential access." 
(Res. of 11-25-91; Code 1991, § 17.20.862; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.20.1150. - Street, marginal access. 
"Marginal access street" means a special-purpose street provided parallel and adjacent to a collector or higher order street for safety, by providing access to abutting properties and separation from through traffic on the higher order street. 
(Res. of 11-25-91; Code 1991, § 17.20.863; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.20.1160. - Street, minor. 
"Minor street" means a local street. 
(Res. of 11-25-91; Code 1991, § 17.20.864; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.20.1170. - Street, residential access. 
"Residential access street" means the lowest order street in the hierarchy of streets; a street having the sole purpose of providing frontage for service and access to private lots. These streets carry only traffic having either destination or origin on the street itself. The elimination of through traffic and the geometric design of the street are means to promote safety and to create a desirable residential neighborhood. This street is designed to carry average daily traffic (ADT) of no more than 200 for each outlet to another street (e.g., a cul-de-sac or other single-access street will carry 200; a loop street will carry 200 per outlet, or 400). See also "street, local." 
(Res. of 11-25-91; Code 1991, § 17.20.865; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.20.1180. - Street, residential collector. 
"Residential collector street" means the next level above a residential subcollector street in the hierarchy of streets; a street which conducts and distributes traffic between other residential streets of lower order in the streets hierarchy and either higher order streets or major activity centers. This is the highest order of street appropriate to a residential neighborhood, and residential frontage along it is normally prohibited or severely restricted. This street is designed to carry average daily traffic (ADT) of no more than 3,000 at any point. 
(Res. of 11-25-91; Code 1991, § 17.20.866; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.20.1190. - Street, residential subcollector. 
"Residential subcollector street" means the next level above a residential access street in the hierarchy of streets; an access street which provides frontage for residential lots and may carry a small amount of residential through traffic collected only from tributary residential access streets. This street is designed to carry average daily traffic (ADT) of no more than 500 for each outlet to another street (e.g., a cul-de-sac or other single-access street will carry 500; a loop street will carry 500 per outlet, or 1,000). 
(Res. of 11-25-91; Code 1991, § 17.20.867; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.20.1200. - Structure. 
"Structure" means anything constructed or erected the use of which requires permanent or semipermanent location on the ground, or which is attached to something having permanent location on the ground. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 3; Code 1991, § 17.20.880; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.20.1210. - Subdivision. 
"Subdivision" means the division of a tract or parcel of land into two or more lots, building sites or other divisions for the purpose of sale, legacy, a new street or a change in existing streets, and includes resubdivision. Where appropriate to the context, subdivision also relates to the process of subdividing or to the land or area subdivided. The term shall also include the opening of a new street or road. The combination or recombination of portions of previously platted lots where the total number of lots is not increased and the resultant lots meet the standards of the county subdivision regulations is not included within this definition. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 3; Res. of 1-11-82; Res. of 2-22-88; Code 1991, § 17.20.890; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.20.1220. - Temporary sales office. 
"Temporary sales office" means a real estate office which is located within an approved recorded subdivision and is restricted in use to the sale of approved lots within the boundaries of that subdivision. The conditions applicable to the sales office are found in section 17.350.170 of the Official Code of Hall County, Georgia. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 3; Res. of 7-10-89; Code 1991, § 17.20.900; Res. of 3-27-97, § 1; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.20.1230. - Townhouse. 
"Townhouse" means residential structures containing three or more attached single-family units designed as a single structure having common or party walls. Each unit shall have its own front door which opens to the outdoors, and the units shall have two floors, but without access between adjoining units. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 3; Res. of 3-28-83; Code 1991, § 17.20.910; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.20.1231. - Two-family dwelling unit. 
"Two-family dwelling unit" means a residential building designed and used exclusively for permanent rather than transient occupancy by two families in separate dwelling units living independently of each other. 
(Res. of 6-17-02(2), § 1; Res. of 10-24-02, § 2; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.20.1240. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Res. of 3-11-99, § 2, repealed § 17.20.1240, which pertained to transmission towers and derived from Res. of 1-13-92 and Code 1991, § 17.20.915. 
17.20.1250. - Travel trailer. 
"Travel trailer" means a vehicular portable structure not over eight feet by 35 feet and designed as a temporary dwelling for travel, recreational and vacation uses, which may or may not have kitchen equipment, toilet, lavatory and bathing facilities, but, if such facilities are included, a sewage holding tank for sanitary waste is required. Any vehicle designed or converted to a design with plumbing connections for attachment to outside sewage systems shall not be included in this definition. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 3; Code 1991, § 17.20.920; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.20.1260. - Travel trailer park. 
"Travel trailer park" means a parcel of land which has been planned and developed to accommodate two or more travel trailers, tents or other camping units for temporary occupancy of not over 60 days' duration. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 3; Code 1991, § 17.20.930; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.20.1270. - Turnaround. 
"Turnaround" means the circular pavement paved area intended to facilitate turning around of vehicles at the end of a cul-de-sac. 
(Res. of 11-25-91; Code 1991, § 17.20.934; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.20.1280. - Use, permitted. 
"Permitted use" means those uses specifically listed in this title as "uses permitted inherently," not to include uses herein defined as "nonconforming use." 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 3; Code 1991, § 17.20.940; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.20.1290. - Use, principal. 
"Principal use" means the principal purpose for which a lot or building is designed, arranged, intended, occupied or maintained. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 3; Code 1991, § 17.20.950; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.20.1300. - Uses subject to approval of the planning commission. 
"Uses subject to approval of the planning commission" or similar terms contained in this title mean that the use may be permitted in the zoning district upon the specific approval of the individual application by the planning commission. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 3; Code 1991, § 17.20.960; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.20.1305. - Vacation home. 
Vacation home means any residential structure used for transient occupancy including but not limited to cabins, single-family dwellings and other such residential structures as permitted provided: 
a.  The owner has paid all required excise tax as per section 3.40.020 of this Code for all transient occupancy, 
b.  The owner has registered as per section 3.40.060 of this Code, 
c.  The owner has complied with all other applicable provisions of chapter 3.40 of this Code, 
d.  The owner has obtained a business license for said vacation home, 
e.  The owner has complied with all applicable provisions of title 5 of this Code for business licenses and regulations, and 
f.  Other than vehicles parked in garages or carports, all parking at the residence shall not exceed four vehicles which vehicles: 
(1)  Shall not be parked on the street; 
(2)  Shall be parked only on designated hard surfaced areas with gravel, concrete or asphalt surfacing; and 
(3)  Shall not be permitted outside such surfaced areas in paragraph a.f.(2) of this section (i.e., no parking in yards). 
(Ord. of 5-27-10, § 1(Exh. A)) 
Editor's note— Ord. of May 27, 2010, § 1(Exh. A), repealed former § 17.20.1305, and enacted a new § 17.20.1305 as set out herein. Former § 17.20.1305 pertained to similar subject matter. See the Code Comparative Table for complete derivation. 
17.20.1310. - Variance. 
"Variance" means a modification of the strict terms of zoning regulations granted by the zoning board of adjustment where such modification will not be contrary to the public interest, and where, owing to conditions unique to the individual property on which the variance is sought and not as a result of any action on the part of the property owner, a literal enforcement of this resolution [title] would result in unnecessary and undue hardship; provided, however, that no variance shall be granted which shall authorize a land use not otherwise permitted in a particular district. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 3; Res. of 7-10-89; Code 1991, § 17.20.970; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.20.1320. - Vehicle. 
"Vehicle" means any device or contrivance for carrying or conveying persons or objects, said device being designed to be self-propelled by its own motor or power. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 3; Res. of 4-27-90; Code 1991, § 17.20.975; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.20.1330. - Water system. 
"Water system" means a potable water supply and treatment system other than individual or community water systems, owned by a unit of government. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 3; Code 1991, § 17.20.980; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.20.1340. - Water system, community. 
"Community water system" means a potable water supply and treatment system other than an individual or public water system serving more than one building, residence or other facility designed or used for human occupancy or congregation. The system is one which is owned by a person or legal unit other than a unit of government. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 3; Code 1991, § 17.20.990; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.20.1350. - Water system, individual. 
"Individual water system" means a potable water system other than a community or public water system serving a single building, residence or other facility designed or used for human occupancy or congregation. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 3; Code 1991, § 17.20.1000; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.20.1360. - Yard. 
"Yard" means a required open space located on the same lot as the principal building, and which is unoccupied and unobstructed from the ground upward except for tree or shrub growth and fences or walls, or where encroachments, utilities and accessory uses are expressly permitted. A yard requirement may also be referred to as a "setback." 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 3; Code 1991, § 17.20.1010; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.20.1370. - Yard sale. 
"Yard sale" means sales of used household belongings by an individual at his principal residence or by a group of individuals combining such items for a group yard sale at one of their principal residences. Such sales may be held no more than four times in a calendar year, with each individual sale lasting no more than three consecutive days. All merchandise must be the property of the person(s) holding the sale and not be purchased for the purpose of resale. The term also includes garage sales, basement sales, or other similar usage. Such sales are exempt from the screening requirements of section 17.260.010. All other sales of merchandise are considered retail sales, and the merchandise is considered as inventory subject to the screening requirements of section 17.260.010. 
(Res. of 8-12-93; Code 1991, § 17.20.1015; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.20.1380. - Yard, front. 
"Front yard" means a yard situated between the front building line and the front [lot] line extending the full width of the lot. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 3; Code 1991, § 17.20.1020; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.20.1390. - Yard, rear. 
"Rear yard" means a yard situated between the rear building line and rear lot line and extending the full width of the lot. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 3; Code 1991, § 17.20.1030; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.20.1400. - Yard, side. 
"Side yard" means a yard situated between a side building line and a side lot line and extending from the front yard to the rear yard. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 3; Code 1991, § 17.20.1040; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
CHAPTER 17.30. - ZONING APPLICATION FEE 

 

17.30.010. - General provisions; fees established; refunds. 
A.  General provisions. 
1.  Fees for the administration of the zoning regulations shall be collected previous to action by any commission or board or final action by any administrative officer. An application shall not be considered complete until the required fee is paid. 
2.  Should the zoning board of adjustment find in favor of the appellant on an action of alleged error of an administrative official, the assessed fee shall be refunded. 
B.  Applications to planning commission. 
_____ 
1.  Rezoning application fee. 

 
2.  Conditional uses and uses permitted subject to the approval of the Planning Commission. 

 
_____ 
3.  Site plan review of mobile home parks, $0.10 per linear foot of new street proposed and $5.00 per mobile home space proposed. 
4.  Determination of unclassified use: None. 
C.  Applications to Hall County Planning Commission include: 
1.  Conditional uses. 
2.  Variance from the terms of this title. 
3.  Enlargement, change or continuance of nonconforming uses, or 
4.  Alleged error of an administrative official. 
5.  Applications to the Hall County Planning Commission in V-C, R-I, R-I-L, R-II, AR-III, and AR-IV zones: $350.00. 
6.  Applications to the Hall County Planning Commission in R-TF, R-MF, O-I, S-S, H-B, I-I, I-II, PRD, POD, PCD, PID, P-C, and MHP zones: $400.00. 
7.  Zoning certification letter: $25.00. 
D.  [ Appeals. ] Appeals to the county board of commissioners: $200.00. 
E.  Refund of application fees. (See also section 17.380.140.) 
1.  Rezoning and uses permitted subject to the approval of the county commissioners: 
a.  Withdrawal prior to notification of adjacent property owners by public advertisement: 50% of application fee. 
b.  Withdrawal after notification of adjacent property owners by public advertisement but prior to a planning commission decision: 25% of application fee. 
c.  Withdrawal after a planning commission decision: None. 
2.  Conditional uses and uses permitted subject to approval of the planning commission: 
a.  Withdrawal prior to notification of adjacent property owners by public advertisement: 50% of application fee. 
b.  Withdrawal after notification of adjacent property owners by public advertisement: None. 
3.  Applications to the zoning board of adjustment: 
a.  Withdrawal prior to notification of adjacent property owners by public advertisement: 50% of application fee. 
[b.  Reserved.] 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 4; Res. of 8-14-89; Code 1991, § 17.30.010; Res. of 11-11-98, § 1; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1; Res. of 3-25-04, § 2; Res. of 1-12-12(4), Exh. A) 
CHAPTER 17.40. - ESTABLISHMENT OF DISTRICTS 

 

17.40.010. - General provisions. 
No building or land shall hereafter be used or occupied except in conformity with the regulations herein specified for the district in which it is located [and] without first obtaining an occupancy permit, except as provided for signs in this title. No building, structure or part thereof shall be constructed, erected, enlarged, altered, repaired, changed, converted, moved or demolished without first obtaining a building permit and other permits as may be required by law, except as hereinafter provided. In the enforcement of the provisions of this title, the building official may withhold building or occupancy permits until all provisions of this resolution [title] are complied with or his decision is appealed to and reversed by the zoning board of adjustment. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 5(D); Res. of 9-7-88; Res. of 7-10-89; Res. of 4-27-90; Res. of 8-26-91; Code 1991, § 17.40.010; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.40.020. - Use districts. 
For the purpose of these regulations, the area of jurisdiction within the county is divided into districts designated as follows: 

 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 5(A); Res. of 7-10-89; Res. of 12-28-87; Res. of 12-9-91; Code 1991, § 17.40.020; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1; Res. of 3-25-04, § 3) 
17.40.030. - Adoption of official zoning map and district boundaries. 
A.  The map maintained in electronic format by the Hall County Geographic Information System is adopted as the official zoning map of Hall County, Georgia, and incorporated herein by reference. 
1.  Copies of the map shall be printed and sold to the general public of the county, and the charges therefore being sufficient to cover the expense of printing the maps and the cost of distribution. 
2.  The official zoning map of Hall County, Georgia, will be in the custody and on file in the GIS office of the planning department of Hall County, Georgia for public inspection and review. 
3.  The boundaries of those districts are hereby established as shown on the map in electronic formatted map designated as the official zoning map, Hall County, Georgia, as amended from time to time. 
4.  If, in accordance with the provisions of this chapter, changes are made in district boundaries or other matters portrayed on the official zoning map in electronic format, such changes shall be entered on the official zoning map in electronic format promptly after the Hall County Board of Commissioners has approved the amendment. 
5.  Such changes shall be the responsibility of the Hall County Planning Department and shall be made under the supervision of the Hall County Planning Director or his designee within the Hall County Planning Department. 
6.  In the event that an official zoning map of Hall County becomes damaged, destroyed, lost or difficult to interpret because of the nature or number of changes and additions thereon, the Hall County Board of Commissioners may by resolution adopt one or more new official zoning maps which shall supersede the prior official zoning map. The new official zoning map or maps may correct drafting or other errors or omissions in the prior official zoning map or maps, but no such correction shall have the effect of amending the original official zoning map or maps, and said map or maps shall be identified by the signature of the Hall County Planning Director who shall certify that the official zoning map or maps supersedes and replaces the previous official zoning map adopted as a part of the resolution of Hall County, Georgia. Unless the previous official zoning map or maps has been lost, or has been totally destroyed, the prior map or maps or any significant remaining parts thereof, shall be preserved, together with all available records pertaining to its adoption or amendment. 
B.  Where uncertainty exists with respect to the boundaries of any of the aforesaid districts as shown on the zoning map, the following rules shall apply: 
1.  Where district boundaries are indicated as approximately following the center lines of streets or highways or railroad right-of-way lines or such lines extended, such center lines or railroad right-of-way lines or such lines extended shall be construed to be such boundaries. 
2.  Where district boundaries are indicated as approximately following the county line or the corporate limit line of any incorporated place or the militia district line of any militia district or the land lot line of any land lot, such county line, corporate limit line, militia district line or land lot line shall be construed to be such boundaries. 
3.  Where district boundaries are indicated as approximately parallel to the center lines of streets or highways, such district boundaries unless otherwise specifically indicated shall be construed as being parallel thereto and at a distance of 300, 500 or 1,000 feet from the center line of such streets and highways, each above district boundary being shown at scale on the official zoning map of the county. 
4.  Where district boundaries are indicated as approximately following the center line of stream beds or river beds, such center lines or such lines extended shall be construed to be such boundaries. 
5.  Where district boundaries are indicated as approximately parallel to the shoreline of the Buford Dam Reservoir, such district boundaries shall be construed as being parallel thereto and at a distance of 500 feet from the nearest point of the 1070 contour line unless otherwise indicated 
(Res. of 3-11-10, § 1(Exh. A)) 
Editor's note— Res. of March 11, 2010, § 1(Exh. A), deleted former § 17.40.030, and enacted a new § 17.40.030 as set out herein. Former § 17.40.030 pertained to district boundaries and derived from Res. of 8-28-78, § 5(B); Code 1991, § 17.40.030; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1 and Res. of 2-27-03(2), § 1). 
17.40.040. - District boundary lines dividing lot of single ownership. 
Where a district boundary line as appearing on the zoning map divides a lot in single ownership at the time of the enactment of these regulations, the requirements for the district in which the greater portion of the lot lines [lies] shall be extended to the balance of the lot, provided that such extension will not include any part of such lot more than 35 feet beyond the district boundary line, and provided further that this provision shall not apply to a through lot. In the case of a through lot, the restrictions of the district applying to the adjoining lots which front on the same street as the proposed use of the lot shall apply, a through lot being a lot that runs from street to street. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 5(C); Code 1991, § 17.40.040; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.40.050. - Standards for single-family and two-family dwelling units 
Except as specifically excepted by this resolution, all single-family and two-family dwellings, including site-built dwelling units, industrialized dwelling units, and manufactured homes, shall meet or exceed the following requirements in order to be constructed, assembled, moved into, or relocated within Hall County. 
A.  Foundation. 
1.  The dwelling shall be attached to a permanent foundation constructed in accordance with the Building Code or State regulations, as applicable. 
2.  Upon placement, wheels, axles, and hitches, shall be removed. 
3.  The area beneath the ground floor of the dwelling shall either be a slab foundation or shall be enclosed around the exterior of the dwelling with a foundation wall or a curtain wall constructed of masonry at least 4 inches thick, penetrated by openings only for installed vents and access doors. 
B.  Exterior siding. Exterior siding materials shall consist of any combination of wood, brick, stone, stucco, or similar materials, or lap siding of hardboard, vinyl, vinyl-covered or painted metal, or similar materials. 
C.  Roofs. 
1.  All roof surfaces shall have a minimum pitch of 4:12 (four inches of rise for every 12 inches of run), except that mansard and gambrel roofs must meet this requirement only for those surfaces that rise from the eaves. 
2.  All roof surfaces exposed to view shall be covered with asphalt or fiberglass shingles, wood shakes or singles, standing seam (noncorrugated) metal, or corrugated metal that simulates standing seam or other architectural roof products, clay tiles, slate, or similar materials. 
3.  Minimum roof overhang shall be 6 inches, excluding gutters, along all sides of the dwelling. 
D.  Minimum dimensions. The exterior of a dwelling unit shall be greater than sixteen feet in length and in width. 
E.  Variances. The owner or other person interested in the property, may apply for a variance under the procedures provided by this resolution from the standards contained in this section for a single-family or two-family dwelling upon a finding that all of the following standards are met: 
1.  The materials to be utilized or the architectural style proposed for the dwelling unit will be compatible with and harmonious or superior to existing dwellings in the vicinity; and 
2.  Such variance will provide an adequate balance between the protection of the health, safety and welfare of the general public and the right to unfettered use of private property. 
F.  Compliance with Codes. All site-built dwelling units shall be constructed in accordance with all applicable requirements of the Building Code as adopted by Hall County. All manufactured homes shall meet the standards established by the National Manufactured Housing Construction and Safety Standards Act of 1974 (42 U.S.C. 5401, et. seq.). All industrialized dwelling units shall comply with all applicable provisions of state law. 
(Res. of 6-17-02(2), § 2; Res. of 8-22-02, § 1; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.40.060. - Application of standards for single-family and two-family dwelling units. 
Except as specifically excepted by this section, the standards of section 17.40.050 will be applied to existing conditions as follows: 
A.  Existing registered manufactured home parks. Class B manufactured homes may be utilized in all existing manufactured home parks of 12 units or more that are designated as registered with the Hall County Planning Department, regardless of the underlying zoning of the existing manufactured home park. 
B.  Replacement of existing manufactured homes. Existing legally permitted manufactured homes in zoning districts that allow Class A manufactured homes, may be replaced with a Class B manufactured home that is no less conforming to the standards of section 17.40.050 than the existing home to be replaced. Determination of conformity to said standards includes minimum dimension, roof pitch, roof overhang, foundation, and roof and siding material. 
C.  Sale of existing inventory. A manufactured home, regardless of classification, that was in the documented inventory of a legally licensed new or used manufactured home dealer in Hall County as of June 17, 2002, may be permitted for installation on any site allowing for Class A or Class B manufactured homes, through December 31, 2002. 
(Res. of 8-22-02, § 2; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1)

CHAPTER 17.130. - OFFICE AND INSTITUTIONAL DISTRICT (O-I) 

17.130.010. - Purpose. 
A.  The purpose of this district is to establish and maintain areas which are generally in corridors along major limited access highways and which are adjacent to residentially zoned or residentially developed areas and which are so situated as to lend themselves to land uses and activities which may generate traffic and which may particularly benefit from proximity, accessibility or visibility from a major limited access highway but which are the least incompatible of non-residential uses with adjacent residentially zoned or developed areas. To this end development is limited to light business and institutional uses and certain residential types and public facilities. The restrictions set forth herein are designed to protect the district and adjacent or surrounding residential areas, to present an appearance of openness and uncluttered, orderly development and to establish such standards for intensity of use and character of development as are compatible with the purpose of the district. 
B.  Prior to rezoning in the O-I district, a site plan and a landscaping plan shall be submitted to the planning commission for review and approval, except those initiated by a governmental unit. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 11; Code 1991, § 17.130.010; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.130.020. - Permitted uses. 
Permitted uses in the O-I district include: 
A.  Advertising agencies. 
B.  Artist studios for arts, crafts, dance, drama, music and photography. 
C.  Banks. 
D.  Business services. 
E.  Day care centers. 
F.  Finance or credit offices. 
G.  Funeral homes. 
H.  Home occupations. 
I.  [Deleted.] 
J.  Institutional, except penal, including those of a religious, educational or philanthropic nature, such as museums, art galleries, libraries, schools. 
K.  Nursery schools or kindergartens. 
L.  Nursing home, convalescent home. 
M.  Offices, with a gross floor area not exceeding 25 percent of lot area. 
N.  [Deleted.] 
O.  Subdivisions. 
P.  County uses. 
Q.  Family day care home. 
R.  Group day care home. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 11(A); Res. of 5-10-82; Res. of 2-22-88; Res. of 7-25-88; Res. of 10-14-91; Res. of 11-11-91; Res. of 1-27-92; Code 1991, § 17.130.020; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1)

A.  Cluster developments. 
B.  Planned unit developments on a minimum of ten acres. 
C.  Townhouse developments. 
D.  Municipal and other public uses. 
E.  Veterinary clinics or animal hospitals, provided that all animals are housed within the clinic building, with exercise yards but no outside pens or runways, in a manner that eliminates any objectionable noise or order to adjacent properties. 
F.  Site-built single-family detached dwelling units. 
G.  Site-built two-family dwelling units. 
H.  Class A single-family manufactured home. 
I.  Class A single-family industrialized dwelling units. 
J.  Class A two-family manufactured home. 
K.  Class A two-family industrialized dwelling units. 
L.  Multi-family dwelling units. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 11(B); Res. of 7-25-88; Res. of 11-11-91; Res. of 1-27-92; Code 1991, § 17.130.030; Res. of 6-17-02(2), § 20; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1)

In the O-I district, conditional uses subject to zoning board of adjustment approval (see chapter 17.350) and required public hearing include: 
A.  Additional parking on other than principal lot. 
B.  Caretaker and/or employee residences. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 11(C); Res. of 7-10-89; Code 1991, § 17.130.040; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1)

CHAPTER 17.170. - HEAVY INDUSTRIAL DISTRICT (I-II) 

 

17.170.010. - Permitted uses. 
Uses permitted in the I-II district include: 
A.  Any commercial use or industrial use which involves manufacturing, processing, or assembly operations or the storage and sale of heavy materials, products, or equipment, but not including uses which may cause injurious or obnoxious noise, vibrations, smoke, gas, fumes, odor, dust, fire hazard, or other objectionable conditions to nearby areas or those uses listed in section 17.170.020. 
B.  Agricultural or horticultural uses. 
C.  Automobile repair garage. 
D.  County uses. 
E.  Offices. 
F.  [Deleted 1-13-92.] 
G.  Retail or retail service establishments. 
H.  Service stations. 
I.  Outdoor storage of materials and inventory, not including uses as included in section 17.170.020. 
J.  Subdivisions (non-residential). 
K.  Truck terminals. 
L.  Wholesaling and warehousing. 
M.  Family day care home. 
N.  Group day care home as an accessory use. 
O.  Construction trailer, provided the conditions of chapter 17.210 are met. 
P.  Adult establishments. 
Q.  [ Reserved. ] 
R.  Astrologers, clairvoyants, fortune tellers, palmists, phrenologists and related occupations to the list of occupations licensed by the board of commissioners in the Heavy Industrial District (I II). 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 15(A); Res. of 11-13-89; Res. of 10-14-91; Res. of 12-23-91; Res. of 2-10-92; Res. of 11-4-92; Code 1991, § 17.170.010; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1; Res. of 2-8-07(5), § 3) 
17.170.020. - Uses permitted subject to approval of county commission. 
In the I-II district, uses permitted subject to approval of the county commission, after review and recommendation by the planning commission and a required public hearing, include: 
1.  Airports and landing fields. 
2.  Animal or food processing plants, including but not limited to poultry, veal or beef. 
3.  Commercial incinerators, including but not limited to those handling garbage and medical waste. 
4.  Commercial slaughter of animals. 
5.  Distillation of bones, coal, petroleum, animal refuse, grain, tar and wood. 
6.  Fertilizer manufacture. 
7.  Foundry or forging of iron, steel, brass, copper and other metals, but not including the extrusion of metals. 
8.  Grain elevators or commercial feed mills. 
9.  Junk and salvage yards and scrap metal processor. 
10.  Land fills, including but not limited to sanitary landfills. 
11.  Manufacture or bulk storage of acid, including but not limited to hydrochloric, nitric and sulfuric. 
12.  Manufacture or refining of asphalt. 
13.  Manufacture of cement, cement products, concrete, clay products, lime, gypsum, brick, tile or plaster of Paris. 
14.  Manufacturing, processing or storage in bulk of chemical and pharmaceutical products. 
15.  Manufacture or storage in bulk quantities of explosives, including but not limited to fireworks. 
16.  Manufacture or storage of gas, including but not limited to butane, propane, chlorine or other toxic, noxious or pyrophoric gases. 
17.  Manufacture of glue or gelatin. 
18.  Manufacture of paint, oil, shellac, turpentine or varnish. 
19.  Manufacture, storage or wholesaling of petroleum or its related products. 
20.  Mineral extraction, including but not limited to quarrying stone, crushing and mining. 
21.  Municipal, state and other public uses. 
22.  Paper and pulp mills. 
23.  Refining or manufacture of tallow, grease or lard from or of animal fat. 
24.  Rendering plants. 
25.  Rifle, pistol and skeet ranges. 
26.  Smelting of metal ores, including but not limited to tin, copper, zinc or iron. 
27.  Stock yards. 
28.  Tanning, curing or storage of raw hides or skins. 
29.  Slow rate land treatment systems. 
30.  Other similar uses which, due to their historical impact on air and water quality, use of hazardous materials, tendency to emit excessive levels of noise, vibration, odor, smoke, particulate matter, fumes, and/or radiations, and general threat to the community's living and working environment, are deemed by the planning commission, subject to appeal to the county commission, to be a significant risk to the public health, safety or welfare. 
31.  Private directional signs for churches (defined under section 17.270.030) up to 36 square feet in area. 
32.  Re-establishment of a nonconforming use after a period of two years. 
33.  Day care center as an accessory use. 
34.  Telecommunications facilities, provided the conditions of chapter 17.410 are met. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 15(B); Res. of 11-13-89; Res. of 1-14-91; Res. of 3-11-91; Res. of 5-28-91; Res. of 10-14-91; Res. of 1-13-92; Res. of 2-10-92; Code 1991, § 17.170.020; Res. of 3-11-99, § 8; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.170.030. - Conditional uses subject to approval of zoning board of adjustment. 
In the I-II district, conditional uses subject to approval of the zoning board of adjustment include: 
A.  Additional parking on other than principal lot. 
B.  Caretaker and/or employee residence. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 15(C); Res. of 11-13-89; Code 1991, § 17.170.030; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
CHAPTER 17.180. - PLANNED DEVELOPMENT DISTRICT[11] 

 

Footnotes: 
--- (11) --- 
Cross reference— Zoning board of adjustment, ch. 2.40; subdivisions, tit. 16; modification of subdivision standards for planned developments, § 16.40.080. 

17.180.010. - Intent. 
A.  It is the intent of this district to permit and encourage the development of property which would: 
1.  Allow greater flexibility with respect to development standards and site planning considerations; 
2.  Be in the best interest of Hall County in terms of its long range development plans; and 
3.  Permit the establishment or mixture of uses which without proper design and planning might not be compatible with surrounding uses or zoning districts. 
B.  This district is to be utilized as a "floating zone" which shall mean that areas will not be pre-designated as planned development districts but rather each such designation shall result from a specific and separate application for amendment. Planned development districts are separate zoning districts and shall follow the same amendment procedures as other districts. Unless otherwise stated in this section, the development standards and the land uses which are presented with the application for amendment shall, if approved, become the standards for the subject property and shall become a part of the zoning regulations. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 15.A; Res. of 11-12-79; Code 1991, § 17.180.010; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.180.020. - General conditions. 
An area may be considered for rezoning to a planned development district if any one of the following conditions exist: 
A.  More than one land use is proposed for development on a single parcel; 
B.  Separate land uses which would not otherwise be permitted to locate within the same zoning district are proposed for development on one or more adjacent parcels under single or separate ownership; 
C.  Exception or variation from the size, setback, frontage, density, uses or other standards which are required in the other conventional zoning districts are being proposed as part of a comprehensive development plan. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 15.A; Res. of 11-12-79; Code 1991, § 17.180.020; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.180.030. - Special requirements. 
All proposed planned development district applications shall conform to the following specific requirements: 
A.  With the exception of the PCFD classification (see 17.180.060.A [17.180.100.A] for PCFD area requirements), the site proposed for planned development district classification must contain an area of five acres or more unless specifically approved by the county commission due to special and unusual circumstances. No tract of land shall be considered for a planned development classification which has an area less than one acre except when such tract abuts a nonresidential zoning district or abuts a district with the same zoning classification as that for which the application is filed. In no case shall the minimum tract size be less than the minimum lot area requirements for the comparable conventional district (see section 17.240.010 for area requirements) as specified for each planned development classification in this chapter. (Note: The comparable conventional zoning districts listed in the regulations are R-I for a PRD, O-I for a POD, S-S for a PCD and I-I for a PID.) 
B.  The site must abut a public street for a distance of at least 100 feet. 
C.  A suitable plan shall be prepared for the development, and this plan shall include the following elements where applicable: 
1.  A plot plan drawn to scale by a registered engineer, architect, land surveyor or landscape architect showing the exact dimensions of the parcel or parcels of land under consideration and including the following: 
a.  A site plan drawn to scale and indicating all property dimensions, platting and street systems, proposed building sites, sizes, types of use proposed for buildings, plans for protection of abutting properties, means of ingress and egress, access and circulation arrangements, off-street parking and loading facilities, proposed reservations or dedications for streets and other public facilities and, if requested, a contour map of the site; 
b.  The plan shall give the name of the developers and of the development (if any), a north arrow and scale; 
c.  If the proposal includes the subdivision of land for any purpose or for the provision of new public streets, a proposed lot and street layout shall be submitted as part of the application. Any proposed variation from the standards set forth in the subdivision regulations shall be listed and explained. If the plan is approved, a preliminary plat and final plat shall be submitted as provided by the subdivision regulations. 
2.  A written report shall also be submitted which will explain the type, nature, size, intent and characteristics of the proposed development. This report shall include, where applicable: 
a.  A general description of the proposed development and its location; 
b.  The proposed standards for development, including restrictions on the use of the property, density standards, yard (setback) requirements and any proposed restrictive covenants; 
c.  An explanation of why the proposed development standards are necessary if the above proposed standards vary from existing standards in the zoning regulations; 
d.  Plans for the provision of utilities, including water, sewer and drainage facilities; 
e.  Plans and methods for protection of abutting properties; 
f.  Data stating the total number of acres (or square feet) proposed for each type of land use, including public facilities, within the proposed development; 
g.  Additional relevant data as may be required by the planning commission. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 15.A; Res. of 11-12-79; Res. of 1-28-91; Res. of 11-10-94; Code 1991, § 17.180.030; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
Cross reference— Minimum tract size and frontage for zoning change, § 17.380.020. 
17.180.040. - Administrative procedures for planned development districts. 
A.  Any request pertaining to the establishment of a planned development district shall be considered an amendment to the zoning regulations and shall be administered and processed in accordance with the regulations set forth in chapter 17.380. 
B.  All data, plans and specifications presented as part of the planned development district shall, if approved, be adopted as an amendment to the zoning regulations and shall be the standards of development for that particular planned development. 
C.  All further development on the property shall conform to the standards adopted for the district regardless of any change in ownership. Any proposed changes to the approved standards shall be treated as amendments to the zoning regulations and must be considered in accordance with the procedures set forth in chapter 17.380. Appeals based upon hardship or an alleged misinterpretation of the ordinance [this title] by the building official shall be processed in accordance with procedures set forth in chapter 2.40. In no case shall the approved land uses be appealed. 
D.  The violation of any provision of the planned development standards as submitted and approved under the provisions herein shall constitute a violation of these regulations. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 15.A; Res. of 11-12-79; Res. of 7-10-89; Code 1991, § 17.180.040; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
Cross reference— Zoning board of adjustment, ch. 2.40. 
17.180.050. - Planned development district classifications. 
The following shall be classified as planned development districts subject to the provisions of this article [chapter] and to the special provisions for each district: 
A.  PRD: Planned residential development; 
B.  POD: Planned office development; 
C.  PCD: Planned commercial development; 
D.  PID: Planned industrial development; 
E.  PCFD: Planned commercial farm development. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 15.A; Res. of 11-12-79; Code 1991, § 17.180.050; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.180.060. - Planned residential development (PRD). 
A.  Characteristics. A planned residential development may allow for a more flexible placement, arrangement and orientation of residential structures, the accompanying flexibility in the subdivision of land and the grouping of open space and accessory facilities such as garages and parking. It may also provide for a mixture of housing types (single-family, two-family, multi-family, etc.) according to a carefully drawn plan. The proposed residential development should make maximum use of natural features and, through proper site planning measures, it should conform to the existing character and development pattern of the surrounding area. Every effort should be made to preserve and protect any existing residential uses from adverse impacts which might result from a higher density development. 
B.  Required plans. All of the general and special requirements for planned developments shall be provided. The following special items shall also be addressed: 
1.  The site plan shall indicate the proposed size, location, number of units and number of bedrooms of all residential structures. 
2.  All streets and common open spaces not proposed for dedication to the county shall have the proposed maintenance and ownership agreements explained in detail. 
3.  The architectural style and proposed siting of all multi-family structures or zero lot line attached single-family structures shall be indicated. 
4.  The development controls for the development shall be detailed (lot coverage, setbacks, building heights, lot sizes, etc.). If standards are not specifically proposed then the applicable standards in the residential-I (R-I) district shall apply. 
5.  Limited commercial uses may be included within the development, however, they shall be only of convenience neighborhood retail nature intended to serve the needs of the residents of the development unless otherwise specifically approved. Retail uses shall be specified as part of the proposal and limited to 10,000 square feet of floor area. Such uses shall be permitted only in planned residential developments of five acres or larger. 
6.  A proposed development schedule [is] required, [and] development and a listing of proposed uses shall be provided. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 15.A(1); Res. of 11-12-79; Code 1991, § 17.180.060; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.180.070. - Planned office development (POD). 
A.  Characteristics. A planned office development should contain orderly, well-designed office and institutional uses upon a site that results in minimum impact upon the surrounding area. The site plans and building designs should produce a development that can be constructed to achieve maximum utilization of space while maintaining a low-intensity office character protected from more intensive commercial and industrial development and protecting any nearby residential uses. Such a development may also include a limited number of residential and commercial uses. 
B.  Required plans. All of the general and special requirements for planned developments shall be provided. The following special items shall also be addressed: 
1.  The site plan shall indicate the proposed size, location, number of stories and estimated number of employees in each office building. 
2.  The development controls for the district shall be detailed (lot coverage, setbacks, building heights, lot sizes, etc.). If standards are not specifically proposed, then the applicable standards in the office institutional districts (O-I) together with screening and buffer requirements shall apply. 
3.  If residential uses are proposed in conjunction with the planned office development, then the applicable requirements of the planned residential development district or planned commercial development district shall be provided. 
4.  A proposed development schedule and a listing of proposed uses shall be provided. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 15.A(2); Res. of 11-12-79; Code 1991, § 17.180.070; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.180.080. - Planned commercial development (PCD). 
A.  Characteristics. A planned commercial development shall provide for the maximum attainable commercial usage of property while employing the best aspects of prior site planning and development controls to insure: 
1.  Protection of surrounding residential uses; 
2.  Safe access by motorists; 
3.  Minimum traffic congestion; and 
4.  A development which is consistent with long-range plans of the county. 
A limited number of carefully planned residential uses may also be included in a planned commercial development. 
B.  Required plans. All of the general and special requirements for planned developments shall be provided. The following special items shall also be addressed: 
1.  The site plan shall indicate the proposed size, location and number of stories of each commercial structure. 
2.  The entrances, exits and number and location of all parking spaces shall be shown in detail, together with all loading and no parking zones. 
3.  The proposed methods and location of all buffers shall be described. 
4.  The proposed exterior lighting shall be shown. 
5.  All proposed signs, advertising or identification graphics shall be indicated, showing their number, size, height and location. 
6.  The type and number of uses proposed for the commercial development shall be indicated. 
7.  The development controls for the district shall be stated (lot coverage, setbacks, building heights, lot sizes, etc.). If standards are not specifically proposed, then the applicable standards in the suburban shopping district (S-S) shall apply. 
8.  If residential uses are proposed in conjunction with the planned commercial development, then the applicable requirements of the planned residential development shall be provided. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 15.A(3); Res. of 11-12-79; Code 1991, § 17.180.080; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.180.090. - Planned industrial development (PID). 
A.  Characteristics. A planned industrial development should consist of land which has been designated for a planned, organized and controlled industrial use or for multiple but compatible industrial uses in a planned industrial park. The standards employed should be designed to encourage the formation and continuance of a compatible environment for the planned industrial uses and the surrounding land uses. Carefully planned office and commercial uses may be incorporated as part of a planned industrial development. 
B.  Required plans. All of the general and special requirements for planned developments shall be provided. The following specific items shall also be addressed: 
1.  A site plan indicating the proposed site preparation and grading, streets and parking areas, loading zones, outdoor storage areas, rail facilities, storm drainage, water, gas and sewage systems and all buffer areas. 
2.  The development controls for the district shall be detailed (lot coverage, setbacks, building heights, lot sizes, etc.). If standards are not specifically proposed, then the applicable standards in the light industrial (I-I) district, together with the screening and buffer requirements, shall apply. 
3.  If office or commercial uses are proposed in conjunction with the planned industrial development, then the applicable requirements in the planned office development or the planned commercial development [district] shall be provided. 
4.  A proposed development schedule and listing of proposed uses shall be provided. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 15.A(4); Res. of 11-12-79; Code 1991, § 17.180.090; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.180.100. - Planned commercial farm district (PCFD). 
A.  Characteristics and intent. 
1.  The land within the county designated as planned commercial farm district (PCFD) shall be represented by large district areas of at least 35 acres or more that are devoted to intensive agricultural production in the areas of food crops, fiber crops, animal feed, poultry, livestock and commercial timber production. Individual farms within the district area cannot be smaller than five acres. Areas within this zone are not intended to be used for small-scale farming, gardening, small poultry operation or idle pasture land that are more appropriately located in the agricultural-residential or other zoning districts. The land should be in use for good faith farming or agricultural uses worthy of protection and preservation. 
2.  The use of areas designated as PCFD may result in odors, dust, noise or other effects that may not be compatible with single-lot residential development. Specific setback and buffer requirements designed for PCFDs shall apply just as they do within commercial and industrial districts to minimize the adverse effects of the farm uses. 
3.  In order for a parcel to be considered for rezoning to PCFD, the parcel must have qualified for and be under House Bill 230, the Preferential Agricultural Assessment.
