17.240.020. - Exceptions to lot size requirements. 
The minimum lot sizes listed in table 17.240.010 shall not apply to lots containing only structures that are part of public utilities systems and not designed to accommodate persons other than for periodic maintenance. Said lots shall be large enough to include the structure, any parking and service area, and any required buffers, tree protection requirements or landscaping. Additionally, the lot shall be large enough to permit all structures to comply with the minimum setbacks of the zoning district or special setbacks as required by the county commission during the approval process. 
(Res. of 12-9-93; Code 1991, § 17.240.015; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.240.030. - Corner lot setbacks. 
A.  On corner lots in residential and agricultural districts, the minimum setback adjacent to the side of the residence shall be 30 feet from the property line or 55 feet from the center line of the street, whichever is greater. 
B.  In all other districts [on] a corner lot which abuts on two intersecting streets, the minimum setback for side yard purposes for each district measured from the center line of the side street shall be the same as the front yard setback in section 17.240.010. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 16(B); Code 1991, § 17.240.020; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.240.040. - Setbacks from arterial streets. 
No structure may be placed less than 100 feet from the center line of an arterial street (as defined in section 17.20). Arterial streets shall be so designated by the county commission. (See appendix B.) 
(Res. of 3-11-91; Res. of 2-10-92; Code 1991, § 17.240.025; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.240.050. - Accessory building setbacks. 
Setbacks for accessory utility buildings not exceeding 144 square feet in floor area may be a minimum of five feet from side and rear property lines. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 16(C); Code 1991, § 17.240.030; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.240.060. - Poultry houses, barns, commercial kennels, equestrian centers, composting operations, and structures for storage of organic waste or raising of exotic animals. 
No commercial poultry house, structure for the keeping of livestock for commercial purposes, or structure for the storage of organic waste shall be constructed closer than 200 feet from side and rear property lines. Commercial or on-farm composting operations must also maintain a minimum 200-foot setback from side and rear property lines for the operation. In AR-III and AR-IV zones, the side and/or rear setback for such structures or composting operations may be reduced to 100 feet when the property that is adjacent on that property line is zoned PCFD. The front setback for such structures or composting operations shall remain the same as for any other structure within the same district. 
In a commercial kennel, no structure, including outside runs, for the keeping of dogs or cats shall be constructed closer than 200 feet to a property line. 
In an equestrian center, no structure for the keeping of horses, including stables, shall be constructed closer than 200 feet to a property line. No other structures or facilities, including but not limited to riding trails, show/training rings or jumps, shall be located closer than 50 feet to a property line. 
In the raising of exotic animals, no structure, including outside runs or pens used to house those animals, shall be constructed closer than 200 feet to a property line unless specifically approved by the zoning board of adjustment based on a finding, in addition to the other criteria used to review variance requests, that the type of animal being raised does not generate byproducts such as but not limited to noise, odor, disease or a threat to life. In AR-III and AR-IV zones, the side or rear setback may be reduced to 100 feet when the property that is adjacent on that property line is zoned PCFD. The front setback for such structures shall remain the same as for any other structure within the same district. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 16(D); Res. of 3-12-84; Res. of 12-8-86; Res. of 7-8-91; Res. of 10-14-91; Res. of 5-11-92; Code 1991, § 17.240.040; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
Cross reference— Animals generally, tit. 6; animals in residential districts, ch. 17.290. 
17.240.070. - Setbacks adjacent to Lake Lanier. 
The minimum setback requirement shall not apply to side or rear yard property lines which adjoin or abut the Corps of Engineers property line provided that the owner's sewage treatment system is located wholly on private property or is otherwise permitted by the county health department. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 16(E); Res. of 10-14-85; Code 1991, § 17.240.050; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.240.080. - Exceptions to front setback requirements. 
The setback requirements for these regulations for dwellings shall not apply to any lot where the average setback on developed lots located wholly or in part within 100 feet on each side of such lot and within the same block and zoning district and fronting on the same street as such lot is less than the minimum required setback. In such cases the setback on such lot may be less than the required setbacks on the developed lots. This section shall not be construed to allow less setback on lots which extend [across] a developed area but, rather, to allow the filling in of a developed area. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 16(F); Res. of 3-11-91; Res. of 2-10-92; Code 1991, § 17.240.060; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.240.090. - Exceptions to front, side and rear setbacks in the R-I, R-II and V-C zoning districts. 
Those lots zoned R-I, R-II and V-C, which lie in subdivisions which were approved under section 101.2(b) of the county subdivision regulations [section 16.30.070.B] to be constructed without installing curbing and related storm drainage, shall have the following setback requirements unless otherwise exempted by this regulation: 
Front yard: 65 feet from the center line of the road or 40 feet from the property line, whichever is greater. 
Side yard: 15 feet. 
Rear yard: 25 feet. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 16(G); Res. of 8-27-90; Code 1991, § 17.240.065; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.240.100. - Lots of record. 
Whenever a lot or plat has been legally and duly recorded with the county clerk of superior court prior to the effective date of the resolution codified in this chapter [August 28, 1978] and actually exists as so shown or described, it shall be deemed a lot of record. In addition, lots legally recorded after August 28, 1978, that met zoning standards in place at the time of recordation, but do not meet standards currently in place are also considered lots of record. Although said lot may not contain sufficient land area or lot frontage to meet the minimum lot size requirements of this chapter, such lot may be used as a building site provided that all other requirements of the district are met and that building plans are consistent with all state and local health codes. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 16(H); Code 1991, § 17.240.070; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1; Res. of 12-14-06(5), § 1) 
17.240.105. - Modification of lots of record. 
The following modifications to lots of record can be made, or are deemed to be made by certain actions: 
A.  The line between two adjoining lots of record that are non-conforming as to lot size may be modified only such that neither lot becomes smaller. When such a non-conforming lot of record adjoins a lot that meets or exceeds lot size standards, the line may be modified only such that the non-conforming lot does not become smaller, and the conforming lot is not made non-conforming. 
B.  When a building is constructed across the line between two lots of record under the same ownership that are non-conforming as to lot size or frontage, the lots shall be deemed to have been combined. For buildings constructed after August 28, 1978 that were built too close to such a line to meet required setbacks without a variance having been issued, such lots are also deemed to be combined. However, a setback variance may be considered in the situation where a building does not cross the line. 
C.  A lot that is non-conforming in one dimensional criteria, but conforming to other criteria, may be modified such that no conforming dimension is made non-conforming, and the non-conforming dimension is not made non-conforming to a greater extent. For example, if a non-conforming lot of record has less than the required lot frontage, but has excess lot area, the lot area can be reduced as long as it maintains the minimum area, but the lot frontage can not be reduced. 
(Res. of 12-14-06(5), § 2) 
17.240.110. - Lot density exceptions. 
Residential zones. In all residential zoning districts except planned development districts, only one principal structure and its customary accessory buildings, including agricultural buildings, may be erected on any parcel recorded as a separate lot or tract with the clerk of superior court unless otherwise specifically permitted by either: 
A.  Approval of a site plan for multi-family development, in zones permitting such uses, by the planning commission; or 
B.  Approval of a caretaker or hardship special exception by the zoning board of adjustment. 
Non-residential zones. In all other zoning districts except planned development districts, only one principal structure and its customary accessory buildings for each 15,000 square feet of land area may be erected on any parcel. A minimum of 20 percent of the site must be retained as open space. That open-space area must be maintained as either a natural or landscaped area. 
Nonconforming uses. Any building containing a nonconforming use is considered a principal structure. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 16(I); Res. of 2-14-83; Res. of 5-11-87; Res. of 7-10-89; Res. of 4-26-91; Res. of 4-15-93; Code 1991, § 17.240.080; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.240.120. - Lot width requirements. 
Except as provided for in chapter 17.320 and for the planned development districts, minimum lot width at the building line shall be 75 feet in all residential zones and 100 feet in all other zones when the lot is served by an approved public or community water system as defined by the county health department. Said community water system shall comply with the county's Standard Construction Practices for Water and Wastewater Systems (see chapter 13.20). Except as provided for in chapter 17.320 and for the planned development districts, minimum lot width at the building line shall be 150 feet when the lot is served by an individual well. 
(Res. of 10-23-89; Res. of 4-15-93; Code 1991, § 17.240.090; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.240.130. - Street frontage requirements. 
A.  No principal building shall be placed or erected on a lot or parcel which does not abut: 
1.  A street or road shown on the official county road map or otherwise maintained by a governmental unit; or 
2.  An existing public way not maintained by the county; or 
3.  A newly created street which meets the standards of the county subdivision regulations. 
B.  Exceptions to subsection A of this section: 
1.  A parcel recorded as a separate lot or tract with the clerk of superior court prior to the effective date of the resolution codified in this chapter. 
2.  A parcel recorded as a result of a judicial decree. 
3.  A landlocked parcel separated from public road frontage only by the right-of-way of an active railroad, provided the following criteria are met: 
(a)  The parcel has an area of ten acres or more. 
(b)  The parcel is cut from a landlocked lot of record, not from a parcel that has frontage in accordance with subsection A. 
(c)  The parcel is in an industrial zoning district. 
(d)  The railroad line is parallel to the public road at the point of driveway access, not intersecting with it. 
(e)  The railroad has granted a written easement for driveway access to the parcel across that right-of-way. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 16(K); Res. of 8-25-94; Code 1991, § 17.240.100; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
Cross reference— Approved street access required for all lots, § 16.30.060. 
17.240.140. - Street frontage requirements on cul-de-sacs. 
Any lot that has at least 60 percent of its frontage on the turn-around portion of a cul-de-sac shall have a minimum frontage of 40 feet measured on the chord. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 16(L); Res. of 4-26-91; Code 1991, § 17.240.105; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.240.150. - Flag lot width and frontage standards. 
The minimum required lot frontage as established by the county zoning regulations shall be maintained as the minimum lot width for all of that portion of the lot between the front property line (frontage) and the actual building site on the lot even if the building site is a greater distance from the front property line than the minimum required front setback. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 16(M); Res. of 10-23-89; Code 1991, § 17.240.110; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
Cross reference— Similar provisions, § 16.100.110. 
17.240.160. - Development standards for property having access to divided four-lane highways. 
A.  All property abutting and proposing access from a divided four-lane highway, regardless of zoning classification, shall be developed in conformance with the following minimum standards of frontage and access points: 
1.  Frontage. Lots which are created after January 11, 1982, which abut a divided four-lane highway shall have a minimum of 500 feet of frontage abutting the four-lane divided highway; and 
2.  Access points. 
a.  One access point per lot may be permitted provided that approval from the Georgia Department of Transportation shall be required prior to the final approval and recording of a plat of the lot. 
b.  Additional access points may be approved by the planning commission upon a finding that: 
i.  The additional access is essential to the use of the property; and 
ii.  Alternative access from another road, joint access with adjoining property or the construction of a frontage road is not feasible; and 
iii.  Additional access would not be detrimental to existing or proposed uses in the area; and 
iv.  The Georgia Department of Transportation will approve the proposed access; and 
c.  The existence or approval of access for residential or agricultural purposes does not obligate or require the county or the Georgia Department of Transportation to approve access for a change in use to non-residential or non-agricultural uses. 
B.  If the property abutting the four-lane divided highway does not propose direct access to the highway, then the property must abut some other public road and have the minimum frontage abutting said road as required in the applicable zoning district. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 16(N); Res. of 1-11-82; Code 1991, § 17.240.120; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
Cross reference— Streets, sidewalks and public places, tit. 12. 
CHAPTER 17.250. - OFF-STREET PARKING, STORAGE AND LOADING REQUIREMENTS[15] 

 

Footnotes: 
--- (15) --- 
Cross reference— Vehicles and traffic, tit. 10; driveway construction, ch. 12.40; parking area standards for CD overlay district, § 17.230.050; approval of additional parking on other than principal lot, § 17.350.100. 

17.250.010. - Purpose. 
In order to facilitate the movement of police, fire and hospital vehicles, to lessen congestion in the streets, and to prevent obstructing traffic and blocking streets, alleys and entrances to buildings, the following regulations are established. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 17; Res. of 1-27-92; Code 1991, § 17.250.010; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.250.020. - Off-street parking. 
Off-street automobile storage or parking space shall be provided on every lot on which any of the following uses (in table 17.250.020A) are established. Such space shall be provided with vehicular access to a street or alley, and shall be provided in accord with Hall County's adopted driveway construction standards, and shall be equal in number to at least the minimum requirements for the specific use set forth below. Each fraction occurring in the total spaces required for a particular use shall be construed to mean one additional space. 
In the case of any building, structure or premises the use of which is not specifically mentioned herein, the provisions for a use which is so mentioned and to which said use is similar shall apply. The building official shall make the determination, subject to an appeal to the planning commission. 
On-street parking by residents of districts V-C, R-I, R-II, R-TF, R-MF, AR-III, AR-IV and PRD is prohibited on a permanent basis. 
All off-street parking areas that make it necessary for vehicles to back out directly into a public road, street or highway are prohibited except for single-family residential units and, if approved by the Hall County engineering department, duplexes and multi-family units. 
All off-street parking facilities shall be constructed of dust-free materials which will have a surface resistant to erosion, drained so as to prevent damage to abutting properties or public streets and periodically maintained by the owner, and such facilities shall be arranged for convenient access and safety to pedestrians and vehicles. 
No parking area shall be used for the sale, repair, dismantling or servicing of any vehicles, equipment, materials or supplies. 
Each automobile parking space for other than residential purposes shall be clearly marked and shall be provided entrances, exits and driveways adequate to connect each parking space with a public right-of-way. 
Minimum dimensions for off-street parking and maneuvering space or driveways shall be as provided in the tables below (tables 17.250.020B and 17.250.020C). The parking design may include up to 40 percent of the spaces designed for small cars. Those spaces designed for small cars shall be restricted to use by small cars and clearly marked to indicate that restriction. 
_____

(2)  May also apply to boundary curb where bumper overhang is allowed.

(Res. of 8-28-78, § 17(A)(1), (2), (5)—(10); Res. of 11-26-90; Res. of 1-27-92; Code 1991, § 17.250.020; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1; Res. of 4-8-2010, § 1(Exh. A)) 
17.250.030. - Off-site parking. 
If off-street parking and storage cannot be reasonably provided upon the same lot on which the principal use is conducted, the zoning board of adjustment may permit such spaces to be provided on other off-street property (see section 17.350.100). Such vehicle parking spaces shall be associated with the permitted use and shall not thereafter be reduced or encroached upon in any manner. Information shall be provided to justify use of premises for additional parking. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 17(A)(3); Res. of 7-10-89; Res. of 1-27-92; Code 1991, § 17.250.040; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.250.040. - Combined parking spaces. 
The required parking space for any number of separate uses may be combined in one lot, but the required space assigned to one use may not be assigned to another use at the same time, except that one-half of the parking space required for churches, theaters, or assembly halls whose peak attendance will be at night or on Sundays may be assigned to a use which will be closed at nights or on Sundays. 
A maximum of 50 percent of the required off-street parking for places of noncommercial assembly may be met by utilizing parking facilities which normally serve businesses operating only during daytime hours if the parking facilities are within 300 feet of the place of public assembly. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 17(A)(4); Res. of 1-27-92; Code 1991, § 17.250.050; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.250.050. - Off-street loading and unloading space. 
Every building or structure used for business, trade or industry shall provide space as indicated herein for the loading and unloading of vehicles off the street or public alley. Such space shall have access to a public alley or, if there is no alley, to a public street. 
The off-street loading facilities shall in all cases be provided on the same lot or parcel of land as the structure they are intended to serve, and in no case shall said off-street loading space be part of the area used to satisfy the off-street parking requirements of this resolution [title]. Each space provided shall have a minimum 14-foot overhead clearance.
