A.  Livestock. Horses, cows, pigs, ponies, donkeys and other domestic livestock may be kept, raised or bred for home use and enjoyment provided that only one such animal shall be permitted for each 15,000 square feet of land area and shall be adequately contained within that property. 
B.  Domestic pets. Cats, dogs, rabbits or other generally recognized domestic pets may be kept or bred by persons residing on the property for their use and enjoyment. 
C.  Fowl. Ducks, quail, chickens, turkeys, squabs, pheasants, etc., may be raised for home use, provided such fowl are adequately contained within that property. 
D.  These permitted use provisions for animals in residential districts are meant to apply only outside of the residence on an individual lot and are not intended to restrict the type or number of animals within a residence. 
E.  Notwithstanding any provision in this chapter to the contrary, buildings or other structures which are located in residential districts and are used to accommodate or restrain animals noted in subsections A and B of this section shall be located no less than 50 feet from all property lines. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 20(A); Res. of 9-7-88; Code 1991, § 17.280.020; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.290.030. - Prohibited uses. 
A.  The keeping, breeding, or training of any animals or fowl for monetary gain or profit shall be deemed a commercial business and is expressly prohibited in all residential districts except where such operations may qualify as a home occupation. 
B.  Notwithstanding any provision in this chapter to the contrary, the killing, slaughtering and/or butchering of livestock, fowl or other domestic or farm animals, whether for personal consumption or for resale or gift, is expressly prohibited in all residential districts, V-C, R-1, R-11, R-TF, R-MF, PDR, and shall include AR-III and AR-IV districts where the subject parcel is three acres or less and the principal use is residential and not a bona fide "farm" or "agricultural" use as is otherwise defined in Sections 17.20.030, 17.20.440 and/or 17.20.450 of this Code. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 20(B); Code 1991, § 17.280.030; Res. of 9-14-00, § 1; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.290.040. - Penalty. 
Any person, firm, corporation, association or partnership violating any provision of this chapter as the same exists or as it may hereinafter be amended, or shall fail to do anything required by this chapter as the same exists or as it may hereafter be amended, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, amenable to the process of the Magistrate or State Court of Hall County, and upon conviction, shall be punished as provided in the Official Code of Hall County, Georgia section 1.50.020 for each violation in the discretion of the court. 
(Res. of 9-14-00, § 2; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1; Res. of 6-10-04(1), § 1) 
CHAPTER 17.300. - MINIMUM STANDARDS FOR APARTMENTS[20] 

 

Footnotes: 
--- (20) --- 
Cross reference— Business licenses and regulations, tit. 5; buildings and construction, tit. 15. 

17.300.010. - Purpose. 
To prevent the construction of undesirable apartment uses in the county, to prevent the overcrowding of land, to avoid the undue concentration of population within certain districts and to insure the adequate protection of the surrounding area, the following minimum standards for apartment development shall apply. These requirements are designed to guide apartment development in districts where they are permitted by inherent right and in districts where they are permitted subject to the approval of the planning commission. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 21; Code 1991, § 17.290.010; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.300.020. - Design standards and restrictions. 
A.  Apartment construction shall be according to a comprehensive development plan with adequate provisions for access and for adequate protection of the surrounding properties. 
B.  When more than one apartment house is constructed, the buildings shall collectively and individually adhere to the setback requirements of the district in which they are located, plus five feet per story over two stories. 
C.  When more than one apartment house is constructed, external walk areas shall be lighted. 
D.  When more than one apartment house is built, no apartment shall be closer than 20 feet from any other apartment house. 
E.  No apartment shall be constructed at a distance of less than 40 feet from adjoining property lines. 
F.  Off-street parking shall be provided at a rate of 1½ spaces per unit. 
G.  Notwithstanding any other provisions of this chapter, apartment projects hereafter constructed shall provide on-site open space areas equal to 25 percent of the total land area, excluding parking areas. 
H.  In the event that swimming facilities are designed as a part of the project, these facilities shall be enclosed by a fence not less than four feet high. 
I.  All areas not utilized for building, off-street parking or off-street loading facilities shall be landscaped and maintained in a suitable manner. 
J.  There shall be off-street loading, unloading and service areas provided. These areas shall be screened through landscaping or permanent construction from adjoining areas. 
K.  An apartment shall meet all other requirements of the zoning regulations and the building code as applicable. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 21(A); Code 1991, § 17.290.020; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
CHAPTER 17.310. - STANDARDS FOR MANUFACTURED HOME AND TRAVEL TRAILER PARKS[21] 

 

Footnotes: 
--- (21) --- 
Editor's note— Res. of June 17, 2002(2), § 25, amended the title of Ch. 17.310 to read as herein set out. See the Code Comparative Table. 
Cross reference— Business licenses and regulations, tit. 5; health and safety, tit. 8; public services, tit. 13; mobile homes, § 15.10.110; street construction requirements for subdivisions, ch. 16.70; water and sewer system requirements for subdivisions, ch. 16.80; mobile home park district, ch. 17.200. 

17.310.010. - Manufactured home parks; minimum design standards and restrictions. 
A.  The minimum land area of any manufactured home park shall be five acres. Each space within the park shall have a minimum area of not less than 8,000 square feet if separate individual sewage disposal facilities are located within the bounds of the manufactured home space. In cases where shared or central sewage disposal facilities are utilized, the space size may be reduced to 6,000 square feet. All manufactured home space lot lines and the type of sewage disposal proposed for each space shall be clearly delineated on a site plan prior to approval by the planning commission. 
B.  No manufactured home within the park shall be located closer than 40 feet to adjoining property lines, and the front setback for each manufactured home shall be at least 25 feet from the front lot line. 
C.  Manufactured homes shall be separated from each other and from other buildings and structures by at least 25 feet. 
D.  Off-street parking for the park shall be provided at a rate of two parking spaces per each manufactured home lot. 
E.  All manufactured home lots shall abut upon an interior driveway. All interior driveways shall have not less than a 30-foot right-of-way and have unobstructed access to a public street or highway. 
F.  All interior streets within the park shall be graded, based, and paved in accordance with the typical cross section (see table [figure] 17.310.010). If a proposed street is to be greater in length than 300 feet, a plan profile for the road system shall be submitted along with the site plan. The county engineer shall approve all road construction specifications and make a report to the planning commission regarding the finished road at the time the final plat is submitted. 
G.  The park street system shall be adequately maintained and lighted by the owner. The lighting units shall be so spaced and equipped to provide for the safe movement of pedestrians and vehicle traffic at night. 
H.  Parks designed to accommodate 25 or more manufactured homes shall provide one or more recreation areas. The size of the recreation area shall be based upon a minimum of 100 square feet for each manufactured home space. Recreation areas shall be so located as to be free of traffic hazards and should, where topography permits, be centrally located. 
I.  In the event that a swimming pool is developed or planned as a part of the park, this facility shall be enclosed by a chain link, masonry or wood fence not less than four feet high. 
J.  All park grounds shall be maintained with grass, trees, and/or shrubs to enhance the appearance of the park and to prevent soil erosion or the creation of dust during dry weather. 
K.  No individual lot in any park may be sold or control of that lot transferred with the intent or effect of a sale unless that lot and park shall meet all requirements of the county subdivision regulations and the park owner shall hold a valid subdivision recording permit. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 22(A); Res. of 3-26-79; Res. of 12-28-87; Code 1991, § 17.300.010; Res. of 6-17-02(2), § 27; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
[FIGURE 17.310.010.] ROAD CONSTRUCTION REQUIREMENTS  MANUFACTURED HOME PARKS 
 Road Construction Requirements Manufactured Home Parks 
(Res. of 6-17-02(2), § 27; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.310.020. - Manufactured home parks; service buildings. 
Accessory structures and community service facilities are hereby permitted for the convenience and well-being of park residents. Such structures may include but are not limited to the following uses: 
A.  Park management offices, repair shops, and storage. 
B.  Community sanitary facilities. 
C.  Community laundry facilities. 
D.  Community postal facilities. 
E.  Indoor community recreation areas. 
F.  Commercial uses supplying essential goods or services for the use of park residents. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 22(B); Code 1991, § 17.300.020; Res. of 6-17-02(2), § 27; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.310.030. - Manufactured home parks; water supply and sewage disposal. 
Every park must have a public, community or private water and sewer system, which shall be approved by the county health department and the local water department when appropriate. Water and sewer approval shall be obtained prior to submission of a site plan to the planning commission. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 22(C); Code 1991, § 17.300.030; Res. of 6-17-02(2), § 27; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
Cross reference— Sewage collection and disposal, ch. 13.10; construction standards for water and wastewater systems, ch. 13.20. 
17.310.040. - Travel trailer parks; minimum design standards and restrictions. 
A.  The minimum land area of any travel trailer park shall be five acres. Each space within the park shall have a minimum area of not less than 5,000 square feet, and lot lines shall be clearly delineated. 
B.  Lots may be set at an angle, set parallel to the street or varied in other ways provided that the arrangement is approved by the planning commission. 
C.  Each lot within the park shall have a minimum of 25 feet of street frontage and shall have a minimum depth of 100 feet. 
D.  Off-street parking for the park shall be provided at a rate of one parking space per each travel trailer lot. 
E.  All travel trailer lots shall abut upon an interior driveway. All interior driveways shall have unobstructed access to a public street or highway. 
F.  All interior streets within the park shall be graded, stabilized and covered with a dust-free material which shall be durable and well drained under normal use and weather conditions. 
G.  No permanent structures and no non-motorized vehicles except those falling under the definition of "travel trailer" shall be permitted on any approved lot within the park. 
H.  Parks designed to accommodate 15 or more travel trailers, campers, etc., shall provide one or more recreation areas. The size of the recreation area shall be based on a minimum of 200 square feet for each travel trailer space. No recreation area shall be smaller than 3,000 square feet. 
I.  In the event that a swimming pool is developed or planned as a part of the park, this facility shall be enclosed by a chain link, masonry or wood fence not less than four feet high. 
J.  All park grounds shall be maintained with grass, trees and/or shrubs to enhance the appearance of the park and to prevent soil erosion or the creation of dust during dry weather. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 22(D); Res. of 12-28-87; Code 1991, § 17.300.040; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.310.050. - Travel trailer parks; service buildings. 
Community service facilities and accessory structures are hereby permitted for the convenience of park patrons. Such structures may include but are not limited to the following uses: 
A.  Park management offices. 
B.  Community sanitary facilities. 
C.  Community laundry facilities. 
D.  Indoor community recreation areas. 
E.  Commercial uses supplying essential goods or services for the exclusive use of park patrons. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 22(E); Code 1991, § 17.300.050; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.310.060. - Travel trailer parks; water supply and sewage disposal. 
Every park must have a public, community or private water and sewer system, which shall be approved by the county health department and the local water department when appropriate. Water and sewer approval shall be obtained prior to submission of the site plan to the planning commission. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 22(F); Code 1991, § 17.300.060; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
Cross reference— Sewage collection and disposal, ch. 13.10; construction standards for water and wastewater systems, ch. 13.20. 
CHAPTER 17.330. - DETERMINATION OF UNCLASSIFIED USES 

 

17.330.010. - Procedure; criteria. 
In the event an applicant wishes to use property for a use which is not specifically identified under inherent uses, conditional uses, or uses permitted subject to the approval of the planning commission, or uses permitted subject to the approval of the county commission, and where such use is not specifically prohibited from the district, the following provisions shall apply: 
A.  The building official shall submit to the planning commission a written request for a determination of the unclassified use. 
B.  The planning commission shall review the request as submitted and determine if the proposed use is of a similar character to the district in which it is proposed. 
C.  If the planning commission determines that the use is of a similar character and meets the intent of the uses permitted inherently within the district, then they shall instruct the building official to issue a permit. 
D.  In the event that the planning commission determines that the proposed use in the district is consistent with the character and intent of the conditional uses, or uses subject to the approval of the planning commission, or uses subject to the approval of the county commission, within the district, then the applicant shall apply for a conditional use or use subject to approval in the normal manner. 
E.  In no event shall the provisions of this chapter be used to allow an incompatible use or a use specifically prohibited by this title within a certain district. 
F.  Once a use has been allowed or disallowed by the planning commission, it shall then be considered classified under the appropriate category in the district. 
(Res. of 7-10-89; Code 1991, § 17.320.010; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
CHAPTER 17.340. - NONCONFORMING USE[23] 

 

Footnotes: 
--- (23) --- 
Cross reference— Nonconforming billboards, § 17.270.140. 

17.340.010. - Criteria for continuation of nonconforming use. 
A.  Any structure or use of land existing at the time of enactment or subsequent amendment of the resolution codified in this title, but not in conformity with its use regulations and provisions, may be continued with the following limitations. It shall not be: 
1.  Changed to another nonconforming use; 
2.  Re-established after discontinuance of that use for one year; 
3.  Enlarged beyond its size at the time the use or structure became nonconforming. This includes, but is not limited to, the size of the building, the number of employees, operation during other hours of the day or night, the use of additional land, and additional or more powerful equipment; 
4.  Rebuilt, altered, repaired or replaced after damage exceeding 75 percent of the fair sale value of the structure immediately prior to damage. A nonconforming mobile home may not be replaced after it is removed from the property. 
B.  Any building containing a nonconforming use is considered a principal structure. (See section 17.240.110.) 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 24(A), (B); Res. of 5-28-91; Code 1991, § 17.330.010; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.340.020. - Continuation of nonconforming use in hardship cases. 
The zoning board of adjustment may grant, with the exception of slow rate land treatment systems ([see definition in] chapter 17.20), which require county commission approval as a use subject to approval of the county commission (chapter 17.380), the change, re-establishment or enlargement of a nonconforming use or the enlargement, rebuilding, alteration, repair or replacement of a nonconforming structure upon the following findings: 
A.  The change, re-establishment, enlargement, rebuilding, alteration, repair or replacement would be no more detrimental to the surrounding area than the existing or previous use. 
B.  The structure cannot economically be modified so as to be suitable for uses permitted in the district. 
C.  The structure would have to be removed to permit development of the property for conforming uses. 
D.  The structure has such value that removal to permit development of conforming uses would cause economic hardship to the owner. 
E.  The proposed change, re-establishment, enlargement, rebuilding, alteration, repair or replacement would not cause substantial detriment to the public good or impair the purposes and intent of this title. 
F.  The requirements of this title for rezoning would prevent the current zoning from being changed to a classification that would allow the proposed change, re-establishment, enlargement, rebuilding, alteration, repair or replacement. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 24(C); Res. of 5-28-91; Code 1991, § 17.330.020; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.340.030. - Information required for application to continue nonconforming use. 
Applications submitted to the zoning board of adjustment requesting a change, re-establishment, enlargement, rebuilding, alteration, repair or replacement of a nonconforming use or structure shall include the following information: 
A.  The applicant shall bear the burden of providing conclusive evidence to the zoning board of adjustment that the use or structure is legally nonconforming. This evidence may include, but is not limited to, business licenses, tax receipts, or utility bills. 
B.  The applicant shall submit a plat or an accurate site plan, drawn to scale, showing the dimensions of the lot, size and location of all structures and their distance from all property lines, the names of all streets upon which the property is located, and parking spaces. 
C.  If the request is for a commercial use or structure, a written description shall be submitted to describe the business. This description shall include hours of operation, number of employees, equipment used, products made and/or sold, type of signs, and other information as needed for the board to reach a decision. 
D.  The applicant shall provide evidence to the zoning board of adjustment of how the proposed change, re-establishment, enlargement, rebuilding, alteration, repair or replacement will comply with the current zoning, health and building requirements. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 24(D); Res. of 5-28-91; Code 1991, § 17.330.030; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.340.040. - Additional conditions placed on continuance of nonconforming use. 
If the requested change, re-establishment, enlargement, rebuilding, alteration, repair or replacement is approved, the zoning board of adjustment may place conditions on the approval to insure protection of the surrounding area. The applicant is responsible for conformance with these conditions. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 24(E); Res. of 5-28-91; Code 1991, § 17.330.040; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.340.050. - Re-establishment of discontinued use. 
In cases where the request is to re-establish a discontinued use, the zoning board of adjustment may not approve the re-establishment of any use which has been discontinued for more than two years. For uses discontinued longer than two years, the county commissioners may approve re-establishment of the use as provided in chapter 17.380. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 24(F); Res. of 5-28-91; Code 1991, § 17.330.050; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.340.060. - Appeals. 
Any decision of the zoning board of adjustment may be appealed to the board of commissioners of the county, in accordance with chapter 2.40. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 24(G); Res. of 5-28-91; Code 1991, § 17.330.060; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
CHAPTER 17.350. - CONDITIONAL USES AND USES SUBJECT TO APPROVAL OF PLANNING COMMISSION OR ZONING BOARD OF ADJUSTMENT[24] 

 

Footnotes: 
--- (24) --- 
Cross reference— Zoning board of adjustment, ch. 2.40; planning commission, ch. 2.60. 

17.350.010. - Authority of planning commission and zoning board of adjustment. 
The planning commission or zoning board of adjustment may authorize, under conditions prescribed herein, conditional uses and permitted uses expressly identified in a particular zoning district. However, the planning commission or zoning board of adjustment reserves full authority to deny any request for such a use or to impose conditions authorized on the use as it deems appropriate to protect the general health, safety and welfare of the county and its citizens. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 25(A); Res. of 7-10-89; Res. of 9-28-92; Code 1991, § 17.340.010; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.350.020. - Review procedure. 
A.  The planning commission or zoning board of adjustment shall hold a public hearing on all applications for conditional uses and permitted uses and consider the merits of the applications. 
B.  After hearing testimony from all interested parties, the planning commission or zoning board of adjustment shall have 30 days to render its decision. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 25(B); Res. of 7-10-89; Res. of 9-28-92; Code 1991, § 17.340.020; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.350.030. - Notice of public hearing. 
The requirements and procedures for notice of public hearing presented in sections 17.380.070 through 17.380.110 shall be given. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 25(C); Res. of 7-10-89; Res. of 9-28-92; Code 1991, § 17.340.030; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.350.040. - Submission requirements. 
An application shall be submitted to the planning department at least 30 working days prior to the date of the planning commission meeting or zoning board of adjustment meeting at which the application is to be considered. The completed application shall be accompanied by payment of such fee prescribed in chapter 17.30 hereof to cover administrative and advertising costs. The following items of information shall be supplied by the applicant as set forth in chapter 17.350. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 25(D); Res. of 7-10-89; Res. of 9-28-92; Code 1991, § 17.340.040; Res. of 11-11-98, § 1; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.350.050. - Review criteria. 
A conditional use or permitted use may be granted when the planning commission or zoning board of adjustment finds from a preponderance of the evidence produced at the public hearing that the proposed use is suitable for the subject property considering the general lines of inquiry established under section 17.380.060.C. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 25(E); Res. of 7-10-89; Res. of 9-28-92; Code 1991, § 17.340.050; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.350.060. - Burden of proof. 
The applicant for a conditional use or a permitted use shall have the burden of proof, which shall include the presentation of evidence and the burden of persuasion of all questions of fact which are to be determined by the planning commission or zoning board of adjustment as authorized herein. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 25(F); Res. of 7-10-89; Res. of 9-28-92; Code 1991, § 17.340.060; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.350.070. - Conditions of approval. 
The planning commission or zoning board of adjustment may place any reasonable conditions or stipulations upon any approved use as deemed necessary (such as hours of operation, parking, maximum building size, lot size, outside displays, signs, landscape and buffer improvements, screens, etc.) to further insure the orderly operation of the proposed use and its compatibility with the surrounding properties. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 25(G); Res. of 7-10-89; Res. of 9-28-92; Code 1991, § 17.340.070; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.350.080. - Expiration of approval. 
A.  No application approved by the planning commission shall be effective for a period of longer than 12 months unless action is taken by the applicant to implement the use proposed in the application by obtaining the proper permit and/or license, and development plat approval, and proceeding with the building, occupancy or establishment of business within 12 months from the date of approval by the planning commission. For applications approved by the zoning board of adjustment, if no action is taken by the applicant to implement the purpose of the application by obtaining the proper permit and/or license and proceeding with the building occupancy or establishment of a business within six months from the date of approval by the zoning board of adjustment, said approval shall become null and void. 
B.  Extensions may be considered by the planning commission not exceeding 180 days each upon written application without notice or hearing. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 25(H); Res. of 7-10-89; Res. of 9-28-92; Code 1991, § 17.340.080; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.350.090. - Appeals to board of commissioners. 
Any decision of the planning commission or the zoning board of adjustment may be appealed to the board of commissioners of the county in accordance with chapter 17.370 hereof. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 25(I); Res. of 7-10-89; Res. of 9-28-92; Code 1991, § 17.340.090; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.350.100. - Additional parking on other than principal lot. 
A.  If vehicle parking or storage space required under chapter 17.250 cannot be reasonably provided upon the same lot on which the principal use is conducted, the zoning board of adjustment may permit such spaces to be provided on other off-street property. Additional parking on other than the principal lot shall be subject to the conditions set forth below. The applicant shall bear the burden of providing conclusive evidence to the zoning board of adjustment that these conditions have been met. The zoning board of adjustment may modify the conditions listed below to be more restrictive, or place additional conditions, which may also be more restrictive than the conditions listed below, on any approval granted the applicant. If the additional parking on other than the principal lot is approved, the applicant is responsible for the operation of the said parking area in conformance with these conditions. The applicant shall submit a written description of the proposed parking area demonstrating that it will comply with each of the conditions listed below. Additionally, the applicant will submit a site plan showing the dimensions of the parking site and showing the parking spaces with dimensions (including a realistic representation of landscaping and screening when screening is a requirement under the zoning regulations) within the site. The principal use has the responsibility to maintain the required number of parking spaces as required by the zoning regulations. 
B.  Conditions. 
1.  The proposed additional parking area must be within 400 feet of the main entrance to the principal use building. 
2.  The proposed additional parking area must be in a zoning district that would allow the principal use. 
3.  The proposed additional parking area must conform to all dimensional requirements, including road frontage, of the zoning district in which it exists. 
4.  The proposed additional parking area must have frontage on and access to a county-maintained road or be directly abutting the primary use property with internal access to the primary use property. 
5.  The proposed additional parking area must be associated with the principal use and must serve that use exclusively. 
6.  The proposed additional parking area shall not, after approval, be reduced or encroached upon in any manner. 
7.  The proposed additional parking must conform to the criteria concerning off-street parking set forth in section 17.250.020 of the zoning regulations. 
8.  If the proposed additional parking area is separated from the principal use by a street or road, provisions for pedestrian safety must be provided. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 25(J)(1); Res. of 7-10-89; Res. of 9-28-92; Code 1991, § 17.340.100; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
Cross reference— Off-street parking requirements, ch. 17.250. 
17.350.110. - Hardship manufactured homes. 
A.  Hardship manufactured homes shall be subject to the conditions set forth below. The applicant shall bear the burden of providing conclusive evidence to the zoning board of adjustment that these conditions have been met. The zoning board of adjustment may modify the conditions listed below to be more restrictive, or place additional conditions, which may also be more restrictive than the conditions listed below, on any approval granted the applicant. If the hardship mobile home is approved, the applicant is responsible for the operation of said manufactured home in conformance with these conditions. The applicant shall submit a written description of the proposed manufactured home demonstrating that it will comply with each of the conditions listed below. Additionally, the applicant will submit a site plan showing the dimensions of the lot, the location of the proposed manufactured home on the lot and its distance from all property lines. 
B.  Conditions. 
1.  The lot which contains the hardship manufactured home shall be an approved, recorded lot and shall front a publicly maintained road, or it shall be a lot of record as defined in chapter 17.20 of the zoning regulations. 
2.  The proposed manufactured home shall only be occupied by a relative by blood, marriage, or adoption of the owner of the property, or by a legally appointed guardian of the person upon whose condition the hardship is based. 
3.  The proposed hardship manufactured home shall meet the minimum setback requirements of the zoning district in which the manufactured home is to be located. 
4.  A hardship means as follows: 
a.  A medical condition of the applicant which requires proximity of a separate residence to provide necessary medical attendance; 
b.  Partial or total destruction of the principal residence on the tract which makes an alternative residence necessary; 
Written documentation such as a letter on professional stationary and signed by the attending physician in the case of a medical hardship, or verification of the circumstances surrounding the destruction of the principal residence shall be submitted by the applicant. 
5.  Only one hardship manufactured home is permitted on a single tract of land. 
6.  Hardship manufactured homes may be approved only in the zoning districts in which manufactured homes are inherently permitted under zoning regulations. 
7.  The manufactured home shall be removed from the property when the specified hardship ceases to exist. The manufactured home shall not be rented or otherwise occupied once the hardship has ceased to exist. 
8.  A permit for a hardship manufactured home shall be valid for only 12 months. Such permit may be extended an additional 12 months upon application filed in sufficient time for review by the zoning board of adjustment prior to expiration of the permit. A 12-month extension may be granted only two times. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 25(J)(2); Res. of 7-10-89; Res. of 9-28-92; Code 1991, § 17.340.110; Res. of 6-17-02(2), § 28; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
Cross reference— Mobile homes, § 15.10.110. 
17.350.120. - Caretaker or employee residences. 
A.  Caretaker and/or employee residences shall be subject to the conditions set forth below. The applicant shall bear the burden of providing conclusive evidence to the zoning board of adjustment that these conditions have been met. The zoning board of adjustment may modify the conditions listed below to be more restrictive or place additional conditions, which may also be more restrictive than the conditions listed below, on any approval granted the applicant. If the caretaker and/or employee residence is approved, the applicant is responsible for the operation of said residence in conformance with these conditions. The applicant shall submit a written description of the proposed residence demonstrating that it will comply with each of the conditions listed below. Additionally, the applicant will submit a site plan showing the dimensions of the lot, the proposed location of the residence and its distance from all property lines. 
B.  Conditions. 
1.  The lot which contains the caretaker and/or employee residence shall be an approved, recorded lot and shall front a publicly maintained road or it shall be a lot of record as defined in chapter 17.20 of the zoning regulations. 
2.  The proposed residence shall only be occupied by a bona fide caretaker, employee or the owner himself. 
3.  The proposed residence shall meet all setback requirements for the zoning district in which it is located. 
4.  The proposed residence shall be permitted only if the residence is necessary to the property's orderly operation or safety. 
5.  Only one caretaker and/or employee residence is permitted on a piece of property at a time, except that in the AR-III and AR-IV zoning districts one caretaker and/or employee residence may be permitted for each five acres. 
6.  The proposed residence shall only be of a type inherently permitted in the zoning district in which it is to be located, unless otherwise specified by the zoning regulations. 
7.  If the proposed residence is for security purposes, this must be documented by evidence of police records or sheriff's reports of previous incidents. 
8.  If the proposed residence is for caretaker purposes, the need, purpose and duties of the caretaker must be documented in writing. 
9.  If the proposed residence is for employee purposes, the need, purpose and duties of the employee must be documented in writing. 
10.  The applicant for a caretaker/employee residence must demonstrate in writing how his circumstances are unique and different from those of other similar uses in the area to warrant approval of his application. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 25(J)(3); Res. of 7-10-89; Res. of 9-28-92; Code 1991, § 17.340.120; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
Cross reference— Business regulations, tit. 5. 
17.350.130. - Residential businesses. 
A.  Residential businesses are designed to be less restrictive than a home occupation but more restrictive than a rural business in regard to access by the public, size, visibility, number of employees and types of business. Residential businesses shall be subject to the conditions set forth below. The applicant shall bear the burden of providing conclusive evidence to the planning commission that these conditions have been met. The planning commission may modify the conditions listed below to be more restrictive or place additional conditions, which may also be more restrictive than the conditions listed below, on any approval granted the applicant. If the residential business is approved, the applicant is responsible for the operation of the said residential business in conformance with these conditions. The applicant shall submit a written description of the proposed business demonstrating that the proposed business will comply with each of the conditions listed below. Additionally, the applicant will submit a floor plan showing the dimensions of the residence and showing the area with dimensions to be involved in the business. 
B.  Conditions. 
1.  Residential businesses may include but are not limited to beauty shops, barber shops, professional offices and minor repair services. In R-I, the use is restricted to those uses where no customers/clients are coming to the site. 
2.  Residential businesses shall not include the repair and/or maintenance of motor vehicles, large scale manufacturing or any use which will create noise, noxious odors or any hazard that may endanger the health, safety or welfare of the neighborhood. 
3.  The residential business shall not involve group instruction or group assembly of people on the premises. 
4.  The occupation or profession must be conducted entirely within the dwelling. 
5.  The dwelling must be the bona fide residence of the principal practitioner and the residential business shall be valid only as long as the original principal practitioner resides in the dwelling, is conducting the business and has a current business license. 
6.  Residential businesses shall be limited to no more than 35 percent of the total heated floor area of the residence. The proposed size of the residential business shall be specified at the time of application. 
7.  Any additions or alterations to the residence which will be used for the residential business must be of an architectural style in keeping with the surrounding residential and agricultural development. 
8.  The portion of the residence in which the business is conducted shall be completely enclosed in a manner that the business is not visible from the surrounding property. 
9.  Only one employee in excess of family members residing on the premises shall be permitted. For uses where no customers/clients are coming to the site, the number of employees permitted at any one time may be increased to three. 
10.  Property on which the residential business is proposed must have frontage on a public road. 
11.  Parking for customers/clients must be provided on site as provided in chapter 17.300 [17.250]; location of the parking is to be approved by the planning commission. 
12.  Only one non-illuminated sign not to exceed one square foot is permitted; the location is to be approved by the planning commission. No sign is permitted in the R-I zone. 
13.  No outside storage or display shall be allowed. 
14.  Days and hours of operation allowing access by the public, employees, customers or clients shall be Monday through Saturday, daylight hours only. No access by the public, customers or clients is permitted in the R-I district. 
15.  No more than one home occupation, residential business or rural business is allowed in a residence at one time. 
16.  The principal practitioner will be permitted to park one commercial vehicle in the approved parking area. The commercial vehicle is limited to a passenger car, a van or a light truck (up to one ton). 
17.  Any utility trailer needed for the orderly operation of the business must be specifically requested and approved by the planning commission. The request must include the proposed use and size of the trailer. 
18.  The planning commission may place any reasonable conditions on the application deemed necessary to insure the orderly operation of the proposed business and its compatibility with the surrounding properties. 
19.  Pickups from and deliveries to the site in regard to the business shall be restricted to vehicles having no more than two axles and shall be restricted to no more than two pickups or deliveries per day. The pickups and deliveries are restricted to daylight hours only. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 25(K)(2); Res. of 7-10-89; Res. of 6-24-91; Res. of 9-28-92; Res. of 10-27-94; Code 1991, § 17.340.140; Res. of 4-11-96, § 1; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
Cross reference— Business regulations, tit. 5. 
17.350.140. - Rural businesses. 
A.  [ Generally. ] Rural businesses are designed to be less restrictive than a residential business in regard to access by the public, size, visibility, number of employees and types of business. Rural businesses shall be subject to the conditions set forth below. The applicant shall bear the burden of providing conclusive evidence to the planning commission that these conditions have been met. The planning commission may modify the conditions listed below to be more restrictive or place additional conditions, which may also be more restrictive than the conditions listed below, on any approval granted the applicant. 
B.  [ Compliance. ] If the rural business is approved, the applicant is responsible for the operation of the said rural business in conformance with these conditions. The applicant shall submit a written description of the proposed business demonstrating that the proposed business will comply with each of the conditions listed below. Additionally, the applicant will submit a site plan/floor plan showing the area to be involved in the business. 
C.  Intent. A rural business shall be a small office or small-scale retail sales or service-type business which shall be secondary or incidental to the primary use of property for agricultural or residential purposes. Such business shall be primarily directed toward providing local or neighborhood services to rural-residential areas. Rural businesses are intended to be of a smaller size, intensity and scale than commercial uses which would be more commonly found in commercial or business zoning districts. Rural businesses shall be similar to other home businesses except that the activity can occur in an accessory structure detached from the principal residence or in a screened area outside of the dwelling. In addition, an applicant for a rural business must have established residency and be living in a residence upon the subject property prior to any application being filed for consideration by the planning commission. 
D.  Uses permitted. 
1.  Offices; 
2.  Beauty shops, barber shops; 
3.  Retail sales or services of a specialty nature, antique shops, specialty foods, custom furniture, custom-made sporting goods, and meat cutting as a retail service to the public, provided, however, that no slaughtering or wholesale meat cutting or processing is permitted; 
4.  Small repair shops for appliances, machinery, farm equipment or automobiles with the following limitations: 
a.  Repair shops shall not create noise, noxious odors or any hazard which would adversely affect the health, safety or welfare of the adjoining property owners or the neighborhood in general; 
b.  Repair shops shall operate during daylight hours only; 
c.  No more than two vehicles shall actually be serviced, actively worked on or repaired at any one time. Any pieces of machinery, equipment or vehicles stored for service or awaiting pickup after servicing shall be parked within an area reserved for that purpose (maximum 1,000 square feet) and so designated at the time of approval by the planning commission. The storage area must be located to the side or rear of the shop building. Unless specifically modified by the planning commission, that area shall be enclosed by a minimum six-foot-high slatted chain-link fence that provides a complete screening of the storage area. Such modification may be granted by the county planning commission when the requested modification does not contravene the intent of these regulations. All pieces of machinery, equipment or vehicles awaiting service or pickup shall be tagged showing the date of service and the name and address of the owner of the vehicle; 
d.  All spare parts (new or used) shall be stored within a structure, and the storage space shall be included in the total space allocated for the rural business; 
e.  The shop and storage area shall be located a minimum of 50 feet from any property line, unless this requirement is specifically modified by the planning commission. This modification must be granted based on a hardship as determined under the criteria listed in section 2.40.040.A. 
E.  Uses prohibited. 
1.  Retail sales of gasoline, service stations, car washes; 
2.  Truck terminals, heavy equipment rental; 
3.  Industrial or manufacturing uses which require specialized equipment not ordinarily associated with agricultural and residential uses, i.e., forges, large milling machinery, or poultry or meat processing and packing equipment (except as provided above); 
4.  Drive-in theaters, restaurants, entertainment facilities, skating rinks, or any use which, as a result of its normal operation, would generate large amounts of vehicular traffic; 
5.  Any use which clearly is out of scale or character with an agricultural or residential area. 
F.  Conditions. 
1.  The dwelling must be the bona fide residence of the principal practitioner and the rural business shall be valid only as long as the original principal practitioner resides in the dwelling, is conducting the business and has a current business license. 
2.  Rural businesses shall be limited to no more than 1,000 square feet if in a structure, and 1,000 square feet of land if outside a structure. Should the use require both inside and outside area, the total area used cannot exceed 1,000 square feet. If the rural business is to be in the residence, no more than 45 percent of the heated floor space or 1,000 square feet, whichever is less, may be used for the business. The proposed size of the business shall be specified at the time of application. 
3.  Any additions or alterations to the residence which will be used for the rural business must be of an architectural style in keeping with the surrounding residential and agricultural development. Any structure built to house the business must be located to the side or rear of the residence, or, if the structure would be in front of the residence, it must be at least 100 feet from the front property line in addition to meeting the applicable side and rear setbacks. The structure must be readily and easily usable for customary agricultural and residential uses. 
4.  Any outside area other than parking area in which the business is conducted shall be completely enclosed in a manner that the business is not visible from the surrounding property as set forth in chapter 17.260, Screening, Fencing and Outdoor Storage Requirements. 
5.  Only one employee in excess of family members residing on the premises shall be permitted. 
6.  Property on which the rural business is proposed must have frontage on a public road. 
7.  Parking for customers/clients must be provided on-site as provided in chapter 17.300 [17.250]; location of the parking is to be approved by the planning commission. 
8.  Only one non-illuminated sign not to exceed 16 square feet is permitted; the location is to be approved by the planning commission. Said location must be at least 15 feet from all property lines. 
9.  Days and hours of operation requiring access by the public, customers and/or clients shall be Monday through Saturday, daylight hours only. 
10.  No more than one home occupation, residential business or rural business is allowed in a residence at one time. 
11.  Rural businesses shall be located on property containing at least three acres of land. 
12.  No equipment which would not ordinarily be found in agricultural or residential use may be used in the rural business. 
13.  The planning commission may place any reasonable conditions on the application deemed necessary to insure the orderly operation of the proposed business and its compatibility with the surrounding properties. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 25(K)(3); Res. of 7-10-89; Res. of 12-19-90; Res. of 6-24-91; Res. of 11-11-91; Res. of 9-28-92; Code 1991, § 17.340.150; Res. of 4-11-96, § 1; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
Cross reference— Business regulations, tit. 5. 
17.350.150. - Subdivision amenities. 
A.  Subdivision amenities will be subject to the conditions set forth below. The applicant will bear the burden of providing conclusive evidence that these conditions have been met. The planning commission may modify the conditions listed below to be more restrictive or place additional conditions that may also be more restrictive than the conditions listed below. 
B.  If the subdivision amenities are approved, the applicant is responsible for the operation of the said amenities in conformance with these conditions. The applicant will submit a description of the proposed amenities demonstrating that they will comply with each condition listed below. Additionally, the applicant will submit a site plan showing the dimensions of the amenity site, and showing the proposed uses with dimensions (including a realistic representation of proposed landscaping and screening) within the site. 
C.  Conditions. 
1.  Subdivision amenities will be for the exclusive benefit of and under the control of a homeowners' association whose membership includes and is limited to all lot owners of the subdivision in which the amenity site is to be located. 
2.  If the parcel(s) designated for the amenity site does not conform to the minimum dimensional area requirements of the zoning district in which it exists, it will be noted on the plans submitted for approval and designated on the recorded plat as a non-buildable lot except as approved for the amenities. 
3.  No improvements (excluding parking lots) will be located closer than 50 feet from a lot line, except that the planning commission may allow the setback on improvements to be reduced to 20 feet when an adequate buffer is provided along the property line. Said buffer shall be a brick or stone wall or a solid wooden fence meeting the requirements of chapter 17.260. 
(a)  The planning commission may permit the substitution of a vegetated buffer to comply with the general buffer requirements of chapter 17.260. A site plan describing the details of the proposed buffer shall be submitted with the application. 
(b)  All buffers located near the intersection of two roads or the intersection of the amenity site driveway and a public street shall comply with the vision clearance requirements of chapter 17.260. 
(c)  Under no circumstances may improvements (excluding parking lots) be located closer than 50 feet from a lot line when that lot line is adjacent to an arterial or collector road. 
4.  Parking lots shall be located no closer than 50 feet from a lot line, except that the planning commission may allow the setback to be reduced to a minimum of ten feet when an adequate buffer is provided along the property line. The buffer is to be constructed within the setback area. 
(a)  When the parking is adjacent to a road, the buffer shall consist of earthen berms or vegetation to a minimum height of three feet. The berms will be designed [so] as not to cause draining or erosion problems. 
(b)  When the parking is adjacent to a building lot, it shall be screened by a wall or fence as provided in chapter 17.260. The planning commission may allow the substitution of a vegetated buffer as described in chapter 17.260. 
5.  Facility lighting shall be of the type that prevents direct view of the light source from adjacent residences. 
6.  Off-street parking in accordance with chapter 17.250 shall be provided sufficiently to accommodate projected normal usage during peak outdoor recreation seasons. 
7.  If the parcel does not conform to the minimal requirements of the county health department for a building lot, it shall be noted on the plans submitted for approval. 
8.  The completed covenants for the subdivision and the documents establishing the property owners association shall be submitted for review. These documents shall include a provision that would assure maintenance of the amenity package through adequate assessment of the subdivision property and would provide for establishing a lien against any property failing to pay said assessment. These documents shall be recorded simultaneously with the final plat and/or prior to the sale of any lots within the subdivision. 
D.  The planning commission shall hear request for variances as provided for in the above conditions at a public meeting. 
E.  The planning commission shall serve as a board of appeals regarding planning staff decisions and interpretations regarding amenity sites. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 25(K)(4); Res. of 7-10-89; Res. of 11-11-91; Res. of 9-28-92; Res. of 4-21-93; Code 1991, § 17.340.160; Res. of 3-27-97, § 2; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
Cross reference— Subdivisions, tit. 16. 
17.350.160. - Utility substations. 
A.  Substations for electrical transformers, gas regulators and telephone subscriber carrier sites [may be permitted] provided the following conditions are met: 
1.  Exterior lighting shall be of the type which prevents direct view of the light source from adjacent residences. 
2.  The substation shall be screened in a manner to hide it from view from the adjacent property. The screening material shall be a vegetative buffer as provided for in section 17.260.020 or a masonry wall (brick or finished block). 
3.  The equipment contained on the site shall be enclosed by a locked security fence of a minimum height of six feet. A masonry wall used for screening may also serve as the security fence. 
[B.  Reserved.] 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 25(K)(5); Res. of 7-10-89; Res. of 4-26-91; Res. of 9-28-92; Code 1991, § 17.340.170; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
Cross reference— Public services, tit. 13. 
17.350.170. - Temporary sales offices. 
A.  Temporary sales offices shall be subject to the conditions set forth below. The applicant shall bear the burden of providing conclusive evidence that these conditions have been met. The planning commission to [may] modify the conditions listed below to be more restrictive or place additional conditions which may also be more restrictive than the conditions listed below on any approval granted the applicant. If the temporary sales office is approved, the applicant is responsible for the operation of the said sales office in conformance with these conditions. The applicant shall submit a written description of the proposed office demonstrating that it will comply with each of the conditions listed below. Additionally, the applicant will submit a site plan showing the dimensions of the lot and showing the proposed sales office with dimensions (including a realistic representation of any proposed landscaping and screening) and its location within the site. 
B.  Conditions. 
1.  The lot which contains the temporary sales office shall be an approved, recorded lot within an approved, recorded subdivision and shall front a publicly maintained road. 
2.  The temporary sales office is restricted in use to the sale of approved lots within the boundaries of that subdivision in which the office is located. The office may not be used for any other use other than a sales office. The storage of construction materials or equipment is prohibited. 
3.  The temporary sales office shall be housed in a structure that meets the following conditions: 
a.  The structure will either be a site-built structure or a DCA-approved commercial unit and will meet all local building codes and health regulations for a sales office. 
b.  DCA units will be underpinned. The curtain will be unpierced except for required ventilation and access and constructed of either masonry or a simulated rock or brick material manufactured for such purpose. It will be installed so that it encloses the area located under the house to the ground level. Such wall will be required to meet the standards specified in ANSI A225.1 or county building codes, whichever is the greater requirement. 
c.  For DCA units, the tongue, axles, transporting lights, and towing apparatus will be completely hidden by the underpinning or removed after placement on the lot and before occupancy. Bolted-on tongues will be removed. 
d.  A porch or landing at least three feet square and in compliance with county building codes is provided at each exit door. 
e.  In R-I and PRD zoning districts, the roof will be finished with a material that is residential in appearance, including but not limited to wood, asphalt composition, or fiberglass shingles, but excluding corrugated aluminum, corrugated fiberglass, or metal. 
f.  In R-I and PRD zoning districts, the exterior siding cannot have a high-gloss finish and must be residential in appearance, including but not limited to clapboards, simulated clapboards such as conventional vinyl or metal siding, wood shingles, shakes, or similar material, but excluding smooth, ribbed or corrugated metal or plastic paneled. 
4.  The temporary sales office shall only be located on a specific lot within the subdivision. The staff may approve alternate locations on specified lots provided those lots meet the requirements of this regulation. Only one sales office may be located within a subdivision at a time. 
5.  One small, unattended kiosk not to exceed 144 square feet may be permitted in addition to the sales office on a specified lot. The staff may approve alternate locations on specified lots provided that no more than one kiosk is located within the subdivision at a time. The kiosk is restricted in use to containing sales information (maps, brochures, etc.) for the convenience of the purchaser and shall not have facilities which would allow it to be used as a sales office. The information provided in the kiosk is restricted to information concerning only the subdivision in which the kiosk is located. 
6.  Exterior lighting shall be of the type which prevents direct view of the light source from adjacent residences. 
7.  Off-street parking in accordance with chapter 17.250 shall be provided sufficient to accommodate projected normal usage. The location of said parking shall be approved by the staff. 
8.  The temporary sales office shall be allowed to remain within the subdivision only until 75 percent of the recorded lots are developed with homes. The planning commission may approve an extension of the time limit up to the time that 90 percent of the lots are developed with homes. 
9.  The area around the structure will be landscaped to create an attractive appearance. The landscaping plan will be submitted to the staff for approval. 
C.  The planning commission shall hear requests for variances as provided for in the above conditions at a public hearing. The applicant will bear the cost of advertising the request. 
D.  The planning commission shall serve as a board of appeals regarding planning staff decisions and interpretations regarding sales office sites. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 25(K)(6); Res. of 7-10-89; Res. of 7-13-92; Res. of 9-28-92; Code 1991, § 17.340.180; Res. of 3-27-97, § 2; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
Cross reference— Subdivisions, tit. 16. 
CHAPTER 17.360. - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT[25] 

 

Footnotes: 
--- (25) --- 
Cross reference— Administration generally, tit. 2; site plan review for development in CD district, § 17.230.140 et seq. 

17.360.010. - Building permit application procedure. 
A.  The method of enforcing this title and the procedure to be followed in making application to the building official for building permits shall be as follows: 
1.  Before any building, structure or part thereof shall be constructed, erected, enlarged, altered, repaired, changed, converted, moved or demolished, application for a building permit shall be made to the building official (except that, in districts AR-III and AR-IV, prefabricated or partially prefabricated utility buildings not exceeding 144 square feet may be erected without a permit provided said building adheres to the required property line setbacks). When an application for a building permit is made, the applicant shall be required to show that the proposed structure will meet the requirements of the county zoning regulations. The applicant shall present a site plan showing the property lines of the lot, the size and location of all existing and proposed structures and the distance of those structures from the closest property line. Said site plan may be drawn by the applicant. However, in situations when a clear determination that the structure meets the requirements of the county zoning regulations cannot be made, the county building official may require that the site plan be drawn by a registered engineer, architect, land surveyor or landscape architect. Additionally, the applicant shall provide a clear location of the property lines relative to the footings or structure prior to any inspection of said footings or structure. 
2.  Before any land may be used for a conditional use exception which is permitted in this title, application shall be made to the zoning board of adjustment or planning commission, whichever is appropriate, and that application shall show: 
a.  The actual dimensions of the lot built upon or to be built upon; 
b.  The size and location of the building or buildings to be constructed; 
c.  The size and location of any proposed extension; 
d.  The names of all streets upon which the property is located; 
e.  The zoning districts in which the property is located; 
f.  Such other information as may be necessary to provide for enforcement of this title or upon which to base an inspection prior to passing on the application as required by the building official or planning director. 
3.  When granting conditional uses, the planning commission or zoning board of adjustment shall instruct the building official to issue a permit. 
4.  If the application and the accompanying papers do not comply in all respects with the regulations of this title and the Standard Building Code, it shall be disapproved by the building official and the applicant notified in writing. The building official may, at his discretion, before disapproving any application, return such application to the applicant, who may amend the said application, plans or specifications in order to make the proposal comply with the regulations of this title. In such event the building official shall proceed to pass upon the application as if it were an original one. 
5.  If the application filed, together with the plans and specifications, conforms in all respects with the requirements of this title, the building official shall within a reasonable time issue the permit applied for. 
6.  If an application is disapproved, the applicant shall be notified in writing with the reason for the disapproval. 
7.  Whenever a permit is granted under the provisions of this title, it shall be exercised by the grantee therein named within six months from the date of its issuance, and if not exercised by the grantee within that time the privilege and all rights granted shall become null and void and of no effect. 
8.  The zoning board of adjustment may grant extensions to subdivision 7 of this subsection, if the grantee explains just cause for the delay to the satisfaction of the board. 
[B.  Reserved.] 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 26(A); Res. of 7-10-89; Res. of 4-27-90; Res. of 8-26-91; Code 1991, § 17.350.010; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
Cross reference— Buildings and construction, tit. 15. 
17.360.020. - Appeals. 
Any person or persons aggrieved by any decision of the building official or planning director may appeal said decision to the county zoning board of adjustment. A written notice of appeal shall be submitted to the enforcing officer directly involved within 30 days from the officer's decision. Costs of the appeal shall be established by the board at their discretion and may be changed from time to time as necessary. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 26(B); Res. of 7-10-89; Code 1991, § 17.350.020; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
CHAPTER 17.370. - APPEALS[26] 

 

Footnotes: 
--- (26) --- 
Cross reference— Powers and duties of zoning board of adjustment, § 2.40.040; powers and duties of planning commission, § 2.60.030; appeal of decision on site plan for development in CD overlay district, § 17.230.160. 

17.370.010. - Right to appeal. 
A.  In the event of a denial of a proposed amendment, any conditional use or use subject to the approval of the planning commission or zoning board of adjustment or any other zoning decision, the applicant shall have the right to have an appeal of the decision before the board of commissioners of the county. 
B.  In the event of a grant of a proposed amendment, industrial use, variance, any conditional use or use subject to the approval of the planning commission or zoning board of adjustment or any other zoning decision, any affected person shall have the right to have an appeal of the decision before the board of commissioners of the county. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 29(A)(1); Res. of 2-22-88; Res. of 7-10-89; Code 1991, § 17.360.010; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.370.020. - Notice of appeal. 
In order to have an appeal, the appellant must submit a written notice of appeal within five working days of the decision to the planning commission office. The appellant must submit justification and reasons for the appeal. Such justification should make specific reference to such relevant criteria as listed in section 17.380.060.C. The appeal fee set forth in chapter 17.30 shall be paid at the time of filing said written notice of appeal. The planning director, upon receipt of the written notice of appeal and fee, shall notify the county administrator of the appeal and submit the notice and record of the application to the county administrator. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 29(A)(2); Res. of 2-22-88; Res. of 7-10-89; Res. of 12-19-90; Code 1991, § 17.360.020; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.370.030. - De novo appeal. 
The appeal shall be de novo with the applicant having the right to submit any relevant evidence that the applicant desires. However, the evidence submitted to the lower administrative board shall be part of the record and resubmitted to the board of commissioners. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 29(A)(3); Res. of 2-22-88; Res. of 7-10-89; Code 1991, § 17.360.030; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.370.040. - Required public notice. 
The required public notice set forth in sections 17.380.070 through 17.380.110 [shall be given]. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 29(A)(5); Res. of 2-22-88; Res. of 7-10-89; Code 1991, § 17.360.040; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.370.050. - Date of public hearing before board of commissioners. 
The county administrator shall place an appeal on the agenda of the first public meeting of the board of commissioners of the county arising after the relevant notice provisions of sections 17.380.070 through 17.380.110 have been complied with. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 29(A)(5); Res. of 2-22-88; Res. of 7-10-89; Code 1991, § 17.360.050; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.370.060. - Payment of costs of appeal; decision by board of commissioners. 
The appellant shall bear the costs of preparing the necessary documents as required by the county to properly appeal the matter before the board of commissioners, in addition to the appeal fee. The board of commissioners shall decide such appeals all in accordance with the provisions of section 17.380.130. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 29(A)(6); Res. of 2-22-88; Res. of 7-10-89; Code 1991, § 17.360.060; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.370.070. - Denial of appeal. 
If an appeal of a conditional use, a use permitted subject to approval of the planning commission or an application requiring approval by the zoning board of adjustment is denied by the board of commissioners, then the same property may not again be considered for any zoning application and no application shall be filed until the expiration of at least six months immediately following the denial of the appeal and may not be considered for an application of the same type and no application shall be filed (conditional use, etc.) until the expiration of at least 12 months immediately following the denial of the appeal. 
(Res. of 2-22-88; Res. of 5-22-89; Res. of 7-10-89; Code 1991, § 17.360.070; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
CHAPTER 17.380. - AMENDMENTS 

 

17.380.010. - General procedures. 
All applications, requests and petitions for permits, certificates of zoning compliance, variances, conditional uses, planned developments, classifications and reclassifications of property, notices of appeal, amendments to this resolution [title] and other similar matters, together with all supporting documents required for such application, request or petition and fees therefor, shall be filed with the planning department in the appropriate form as specified herein. All data, drawings, narratives and other supporting documentation required herein must be provided for in an application to be officially received for staff review and scheduling of consideration by the planning commission in accordance with the scheduling provisions established herein. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 30(A)(1); Res. of 2-22-88; Res. of 7-10-89; Code 1991, § 17.370.010; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.380.020. - Minimum tract size and frontage for zoning change. 
Except in an application for rezoning to a nonresidential zoning district or as otherwise noted in section 17.180.030 of the Official Code of Hall County, Georgia, no tract of land shall be considered for rezoning which has an area less than one acre unless such tract abuts a nonresidential zoning district within county or municipal jurisdiction. Application for rezoning may also be considered when a lot of record meets the minimum area and road frontage required by the zoning district in which the rezoning is sought. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 30(A)(2); Res. of 2-22-88; Res. of 7-10-89; Res. of 11-10-94; Code 1991, § 17.370.020; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1; Res. of 12-14-06(6), § 1) 
Cross reference— Minimum tract size and frontage for planned development district, § 17.180.030. 
17.380.030. - Initiation of proposed amendments. 
These zoning regulations of the county, including the official zoning map, may be amended from time to time by the board of commissioners of the county. Amendments to the zoning regulations, including the official zoning map, may be proposed by the board of commissioners of the county, or the county planning commission, or by any individual, firm or organization or their duly appointed agent or attorney; provided, however, no amendment shall become effective unless it shall have been proposed by or have first been submitted to the county planning commission for review and recommendation. Application for uses subject to the approval of the county commission shall have first been submitted to the county planning commission for review and recommendation before consideration by the county commission. 
(Res. of 2-22-88; Res. of 7-10-89; Code 1991, § 17.370.030; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.380.040. - Filing of proposed amendments. 
All proposed amendments, whether an amendment to the text or modification in the district boundaries on the official zoning map, and uses subject to approval of the county commission, shall be submitted to the planning department office of Hall County at least 30 working days in advance of the next regular meeting of the planning commission. The planning director shall arrange a suitable date for a hearing before the planning commission. 
(Res. of 8-28-78, § 30(B)(2); Res. of 2-22-88; Res. of 7-10-89; Code 1991, § 17.370.040; Res. of 3-27-97, § 1; Res. of 11-11-98, § 2; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.380.050. - Submission requirements. 
A.  Any person or persons requesting a change in the official zoning map or use subject to approval of the county commission shall file an application with a plat or map of the property attached thereto, together with payment of such fees set forth in chapter 17.30 to cover administrative and advertising costs, in the planning department office. Such person or persons or their authorized agent shall appear in person at the public hearing held to consider the district change. 
B.  All applications for a change of zoning classification or use subject to approval of the county commission shall include: 
1.  A narrative statement identifying the existing and proposed use of the property and addressing each of the criteria set forth in section 17.380.060.C of this section [chapter]. 
2.  A site plan drawn to scale designating the area covered by the application and identifying existing and proposed buildings and uses, adjacent existing land uses, zoning on contiguous parcels, including those across an abutting public right-of-way, and any other significant site improvements proposed to accommodate the proposed use or buffer adjacent uses, etc., or a plat of the subject property where no specific land use is proposed. In cases where only a plat or map is provided and no land use is proposed, the planning commission and county commission shall evaluate the application based on the most intense possible land use permitted in the proposed district. 
3.  For any application for a slow rate land treatment system (see chapter 17.20), the following additional requirements apply. 
Prior to consideration by the county planning commission for their recommendation to the county commission, the county engineering department shall have completed a review of the proposal for site acceptability relative to topography, soil classifications, public or private access, proposed effluent treatment levels and natural, undisturbed buffer zones for surface waters, floodplains, wetlands, wells, residential and other protected areas in addition to other criteria deemed appropriate by the planning commission or county commission. The following information shall be submitted to the county engineer for review of a zoning application and subsequent submittal of a report to the planning commission for consideration of the zoning of any land for a wastewater land application system. 
a.  The design development report submitted to the environmental protection division certified by a professional engineer experienced in the design of land application systems and registered to practice in the State of Georgia. 
b.  A plan for the disposal of excess biological solids. 
c.  Certification from a professional geologist, registered to practice in the State of Georgia, certifying that the land application site is not located within two miles of a significant groundwater recharge area as defined by the environmental protection division. 
d.  A detailed history of all the owner's previous activities, within the State of Georgia in the field of land application, including every other facility it has operated and including a detailed account of all past violations of federal, state, or county laws or regulations, and all past and pending litigation, favorable or unfavorable. 
4.  For any application proposing the development of 100 or more residential dwelling units, a traffic impact study shall be submitted prior to consideration of the application by the planning commission. At the applicant's expense, the traffic impact study shall be prepared by a professional engineer in accordance with requirements established by the Hall County Engineering Department. The engineering department shall review the traffic impact study and forward any comments to the Hall County Planning Commission. 
(Res. of 2-22-88; Res. of 7-10-89; Res. of 4-26-91; Code 1991, § 17.370.050; Res. of 11-11-98, § 1; Res. of 2-27-03(1), § 1) 
17.380.060. - Planning commission and Hall County Commission consideration and decision. 
A.  1.  The planning commission shall hold a public hearing on all zoning applications or applications for a use subject to approval of the county commission after appropriate public notice has been given as provided herein to consider and decide the merits of each application. 
2.  The planning commission shall hold the required public hearing not less than 16 days nor more than 60 days from the date of the filing of the zoning application. 
B.  After hearing testimony from all interested parties, the planning commission shall have 30 days within which to make its decision to grant or deny the application. If the planning commission fails to make a decision within the specified period, it shall be deemed to have denied the application. 
C.  The planning commission shall study the need and justification for the change based on a determination of the facts applicable to the particular case, and the following general lines of inquiry shall be considered, to wit: 
1.  Whether the zoning proposal will permit a use that is suitable in view of the use, development and zoning of adjacent and nearby property. 
2.  Whether the zoning proposal will adversely affect the existing use or usability of adjacent or nearby property. 
3.  Whether the property to be affected by the zoning proposal has a reasonable economic use as currently zoned. 
4.  Whether the zoning proposal will result in a use which will or could cause an excessive or burdensome use of existing streets, transportation facilities, utilities, schools, police protection, fire protection, public health facilities or emergency medical service. 
5.  Whether the zoning proposal is in conformity with the policy and intent of the future land use plan for the physical development of the area. 
6.  The extent to which property values are diminished by the existing zoning restrictions. 
7.  The extent to which the destruction of the subject property's value under the existing zoning promotes the health, safety, morals or general welfare of the public. 
8.  The relative gain to the public as compared to the hardship imposed upon the individual property owner. 
9.  The length of time the property has been vacant as zoned considered in the context of land development in the area in the vicinity of the property. 
10.  Whether there are other existing or changing conditions affecting the use or development of the property which give supporting grounds for either approval or disapproval of the zoning proposal. 
11.  Whether the change would create an isolated district unrelated to the surrounding districts, such as "spot zoning." 
12.  Whether the present zoning district boundaries are illogically drawn in relation to existing conditions in the area. 
13.  Whether the change requested is out of scale with the needs of the county as a whole or the immediate neighborhood. 
14.  Whether it is impossible to find adequate sites for the proposed use in districts permitting such use and already appropriately zoned. 
15.  Whether the need for rezoning could be handled instead by a variance request to the zoning board of adjustment. 
16.  Whether there would be an ecological or pollution impact resulting from major modifications to the land if the request is granted. 
17.  Whether there is reasonable evidence based upon existing and anticipated land use that would indicate a mistake was made in the original zoning of the property. 
When the application is for site-built houses, modular homes and mobile homes more than seven years old being moved into Hall County for the purpose of permanent or temporary occupancy, in addition to the 17 items listed above, the planning commission shall also consider the compatibility of the proposed residential unit with the existing housing in the area surrounding the proposed location of that residence in terms of the type of housing, the style of housing, the age of housing and the condition of housing. 
D.  When the application is for pre-owned site built houses, industrialized homes or manufactured homes to be moved into Hall County for the purpose of permanent or temporary occupancy, in addition to the 17 items listed in section 17.380.060 C. above, the planning commission shall consider the compatibility of the proposed residential unit with the existing housing in the area surrounding the proposed location of that residence in terms of the type of housing, the style of housing, and the condition of such housing.
